Objectives

After studying this chapter, you should be able to

  • 1A Categorize typical internal and external users of financial information
  • 1B Distinguish between financial accounting and management accounting, and between generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) and statutory accounting principles (SAP)
  • 1C Explain the impact of the set of global accounting standards known as IFRS Standards on life insurers in the United States and around the world
  • 1D Distinguish between private and public accounting and describe how the role of the controller has changed in recent years
  • 1E Describe the roles of various governmental and professional organizations in the regulation of accounting and financial reporting
  • 1F Describe financial tools that regulators in the United States use to evaluate insurer solvency

pages.title: Accounting and Financial Reporting
pages.contents:
Accounting and Financial Reporting

Accounting is a system or set of rules and methods for collecting, processing, reporting, and monitoring financial information about a company. Accounting can focus on the company as a whole, or it can focus on segments, product lines, or divisions within the company. Closely related to accounting is financial reporting, which is the process of presenting financial information about a company’s financial position, operating performance, and flow of funds into and out of a company.

The accounting function consists of processes and activities that help answer five key business questions, which are presented in Figure 1.1.

To provide answers to these five questions, the accounting function monitors and measures a company’s business transactions. A business transaction is a transaction to which a company must assign an objective monetary value, whether the impact on the company is large or small, actual or expected. In the context of accounting, virtually all business transactions are financial in nature, because they involve either a transfer of funds or some other resource that has monetary value.

The answers to the questions in Figure 1.1 directly affect an insurer’s primary financial goals, which are solvency and profitability:

  • Solvency is a company’s ability to meet its financial obligations when they become due. Generally, a company is considered solvent if it owns more than it owes.

  • Profitability is the overall degree of success a company has in generating positive returns for its owners, including the company’s ability to generate profits and increase the value of the company. A company tends to be profitable if it earns more than it spends.

One of the most important goals of an insurer’s accounting function is to generate reports that allow interested parties to evaluate an insurer’s solvency and profitability.

pages.title: Users of Accounting Information
pages.contents:
Users of Accounting Information

So, who are these “interested parties”? We can divide them into internal users and external users.

 

Internal Users

Internal users of a company’s accounting information include the company’s employees, directors, and officers. A company’s internal users typically have a direct financial interest in the company, which means they can gain or lose money as a result of the company’s financial performance.

EXAMPLE

Example. Caridad is the chief financial officer (CFO) for the Sandpiper Life Insurance Company. Kurt works in Sandpiper’s policyowner service department. Darren is a manager in Sandpiper’s accounting function.

Analysis. Caridad, Kurt, and Darren are all internal users of Sandpiper’s accounting information. In addition, each has a direct financial interest in Sandpiper’s financial performance. If Sandpiper’s financial performance suffers, all three could risk stagnant salaries—or even worse, they could lose their jobs.

 

External Users

External users of a company’s accounting information are people and organizations outside the company who use the company’s financial information to make various decisions about the company. External users can have either a direct or an indirect financial interest in the company’s performance. External users who have a direct financial interest in an insurer’s performance include

  • Individual policyowners

  • Group policyholders

  • Beneficiaries

  • Insureds

  • Stockholders

  • Agents

  • Reinsurers

  • Creditors

EXAMPLE

Example. Shu-Ling Lee is insured by a Sandpiper policy, and her husband and children are beneficiaries of that policy. Kara owns stock in Sandpiper. Winifred and Fingal are independent agents who sell Sandpiper’s life insurance policies.

Analysis. The Lee family, Kara, Winifred, and Fingal are external users of Sandpiper’s financial information. If Sandpiper fails to perform well, each could suffer financially; therefore, they all have a direct financial interest in Sandpiper’s performance.

External users who have an indirect financial interest in a company’s financial information are generally seeking a company’s financial information on behalf of others. Examples of such users include competing companies, external auditors, federal agencies, state insurance departments, independent rating agencies, and tax authorities. State insurance departments play a particularly important role as external users of a company’s financial information: they evaluate the company’s financial information to ensure that it will be able to pay its benefit obligations, which may arise decades into the future.

EXAMPLE

Example. Sujatha works in the life insurance division of the federal tax office. Riley works for a rating agency that compiles data about the Sandpiper Life Insurance Company. Casper works for the insurance commissioner’s office in the jurisdiction in which Sandpiper is located. He is on the team that conducts financial condition examinations of Sandpiper.

Analysis. Sujatha and the tax office that employs her, Riley and the rating agency that employs him, and Casper and the insurance commissioner’s office that employs him are external users of Sandpiper’s financial information. All of these parties have an indirect financial interest in Sandpiper’s financial information.

Sometimes an individual or entity is both an internal and external user of an insurer’s financial information. For example, insurance company employees may also be policyowners, insureds, or stockholders. In addition, an external user of an insurer’s financial information may have a direct and an indirect financial interest in the insurer.

EXAMPLE

Example. Sarah serves on the board of directors of the Sandpiper Life Insurance Company and owns several Sandpiper life insurance policies. Sandpiper stockholder Andrew is also a Sandpiper employee. Dorothy works for a federal agency that oversees Sandpiper and other life insurance companies, and she is also the beneficiary of a Sandpiper life insurance policy.

Analysis. Sarah and Andrew are both internal users and external users of Sandpiper’s financial information. Dorothy is an external user who has both a direct financial interest and an indirect financial interest in Sandpiper’s financial performance.

pages.title: Fields of Accounting
pages.contents:
Fields of Accounting

The various users of financial information need to answer different questions as they analyze a company’s financial information. Two major fields of accounting have emerged to focus on the varied interests of these diverse users: financial accounting and management accounting.

 

Financial Accounting

Financial accounting is the field of accounting that focuses primarily on reporting a company’s financial information to meet the needs of the company’s external users. Using financial accounting, a company’s accountants communicate the results of the company’s numerous business transactions on financial statements. Financial statements are summary reports of a company’s financial condition on a specified date or of its performance during a specified period. Common financial statements, which we discuss in a later chapter, are the (1) balance sheet, (2) income statement, (3) cash flow statement, and (4) statement of owners’ equity. A company’s financial statements focus on the company’s historical, or past, financial performance and must comply with applicable laws, regulations, and accounting standards.

For our purposes, accounting standards are guidelines or rules that describe how business transactions should be measured, presented, and disclosed in financial statements. For U.S. life insurers, three important accounting standards associated with financial accounting are generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP), statutory accounting principles (SAP), and the IFRS Standards. Many U.S. insurers currently prepare two sets of financial statements—one set based on GAAP and a second set based on SAP. Some U.S. insurers even have to prepare a third set based on the IFRS Standards.

 

Generally Accepted Accounting Principles

Generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) are a set of financial accounting standards, conventions, and rules that all publicly traded companies must follow when summarizing transactions and preparing their financial statements. A publicly traded company, or public company, is a company whose stocks or bonds are offered for sale to the public. GAAP focuses on a company’s profitability, and financial statements prepared on a GAAP basis are generally referred to as GAAP financial statements or GAAP statements.

In the United States, an important report prepared using GAAP is the Annual Report, which is a document that a company’s management sends to interested parties to explain the company’s financial performance during the past year. We discuss this report in detail in a later chapter.

 

Statutory Accounting Principles

Statutory accounting principles (SAP) are accounting standards that all life insurers in the United States must follow when preparing the Annual Statement and other specified financial reports that they submit to state insurance regulators. The Annual Statement is a financial report that every insurer in the United States must file annually with the National Association of Insurance Commissioners (NAIC) and the insurance regulatory organization in each state in which the insurer conducts business. We discuss the NAIC later in this chapter, and we present more detail on the Annual Statement later in the text.

SAP focuses on a company’s solvency, and financial statements prepared according to SAP are generally referred to as STAT financial statements, STAT statements, or statutory financial statements.

Note that non-U.S. insurers that conduct business in the United States must also comply with statutory reporting requirements for each state in which they conduct business.

IFRS Standards

For many years, international companies had to comply with separate, and sometimes conflicting, financial reporting requirements in each country in which they conducted business. These different reporting requirements made it difficult for investors and regulators to compare the financial statements of companies operating in different countries. In response to this situation, the standard-setting organization known as the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) developed a single set of global accounting standards known as IFRS Standards. The goal of these standards is to promote consistency, comparability, and more complete disclosure of the information contained in corporate financial statements.

Companies that issue publicly traded securities in countries that have adopted the IFRS Standards must prepare their financial statements according to these standards. At the present time, the United States generally does not require the use of the IFRS Standards for domestic companies with publicly traded securities. However, foreign companies whose stock is traded in the United States are now permitted—but not required—to use these standards. Note that a U.S. insurer may be required to use these standards in certain situations, such as if the insurer is a subsidiary of a foreign company, or if it plans to raise capital from other countries.

Although the United States has not adopted the IFRS Standards, more than 100 countries around the world require the use of these standards for public companies.

Management Accounting

Management accounting is the field of accounting that focuses primarily on identifying, measuring, analyzing, and communicating financial information to a company’s internal users, particularly company managers, so that they can decide how to best use the company’s resources. Reflecting this focus, management accounting includes activities designed to analyze operating costs, oversee budgets, and evaluate the profitability of various products and services.

Unlike financial accounting, which focuses on evaluating a company’s past performance, management accounting focuses on planning the company’s future performance. In addition, financial accounting is subject to specific accounting standards—such as GAAP, SAP, and IFRS—whereas management accounting is not. Lastly, only financial accounting is required by law.

Later in this textbook, we discuss management accounting in more detail. Figure 1.5 compares management accounting and financial accounting.

pages.title: Performing the Accounting Function
pages.contents:
Performing the Accounting Function

The accounting profession generally recognizes two main areas of accounting: private accounting and public accounting. The two areas are generally distinguished from one another by whether their services are made available to the general public.

 

Private Accounting

Accountants who work in private accounting are company employees who prepare financial accounting reports and statements for the company’s external users, as well as management accounting reports for the company’s internal users.

Private insurance company accountants typically

  • Establish and maintain the insurer’s accounting records, as well as provide guidance on the insurer’s accounting policies

  • Keep records associated with all business transactions involving the insurer’s receipt or disbursement of money

  • Develop and maintain adequate internal controls to safeguard the insurer’s assets and to ensure the accuracy of financial statements

  • Prepare and analyze financial statements and financial reports

  • Interpret and analyze operating costs and budgeted amounts

The head of a company’s accounting function is typically the controller or comptroller. Although the controller usually reports to the company’s chief financial officer (CFO), reporting relationships among the controller and other company officers and employees vary among companies.

Figure 1.6 shows how the role of the controller has been changing in recent years.

 

Public Accounting

Public accounting is performed by public accountants, who work for, or are affiliated with, a public accounting company or governmental regulatory authority. In the United States, accountants who work in public accounting generally earn the professional accounting credential known as the Certified Public Accountant (CPA) designation.

Although public accountants can perform activities related to both financial and management accounting, in this text, we emphasize public accountants’ financial accounting activities. For example, insurance companies hire public accountants to perform annual audits of their financial statements. An audit is the examination and evaluation of a company’s accounting records, policies, and procedures to ensure that certain requirements are met. We discuss auditing in detail later in the text.

pages.title: Regulatory Agencies and Organizations
pages.contents:
Regulatory Agencies and Organizations

Because the insurance industry manages large amounts of money and because many people rely on insurers for financial protection, the public can be negatively affected if insurers do not adhere to prudent standards in their business transactions. Therefore, the financial health of the insurance industry is deemed to be in the public interest. Compliance with financial reporting requirements helps ensure that each insurance company adequately prepares for the eventual payment of contractual benefits. In addition, to make informed decisions, policyowners, investors, and other interested parties must be able to rely on the information presented in an insurer’s financial statements.

The following sections discuss agencies and organizations that have a significant impact on accounting and financial reporting for life insurance companies in the United States. Note, however, that other countries have a variety of agencies and organizations that provide similar regulatory and professional oversight of the insurance industry.

 

Securities and Exchange Commission

The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is a federal government agency that regulates the investment industry in the United States. Its main purpose is to protect investors. The SEC has jurisdiction over all publicly traded companies in the United States. It also holds the legal authority to prescribe the accounting principles—in this case, GAAP—that public companies use. Many insurers are subject to SEC regulations. The following tests determine whether SEC regulations apply to an insurer operating in the United States:

  • Is the insurer a stock company? All publicly traded companies, including stock insurers, are subject to SEC regulation.

  • Does the insurer sell variable products, such as variable life insurance and variable annuities? Variable products are investment products as well as insurance products; therefore, an insurer that sells variable products is subject to SEC regulation. Under this test, mutual insurers and fraternal insurers that sell variable products are subject to SEC regulation, even though they are not publicly traded stock companies.

Insurers that are subject to SEC regulation must generally submit U.S. GAAP financial statements to the SEC. However, the SEC now accepts a non-U.S. company’s financial statements that were prepared according to IFRS without requiring the company to restate its financial statements according to U.S. GAAP. Currently, U.S. mutual insurers and fraternal insurers that sell variable products can submit statutory financial statements to the SEC.

EXAMPLE

Example. The Stanza Mutual Life Insurance Company sells term life and whole life insurance products and variable annuity products. The Lyrical Life Insurance Company sells fixed and variable life and annuity products. Stanza is a U.S. company, and Lyrical is a non-U.S. company that prepares its financial statements according to IFRS.

Analysis. Because Stanza sells variable products, it is required to submit financial statements to the SEC; however, because Stanza is a mutual insurer, these statements can be statutory financial statements rather than GAAP financial statements. Although it is a non-U.S. company, Lyrical can submit its financial statements to the SEC without restating them according to U.S. GAAP because it prepares its financial statements according to IFRS.

Figure 1.7 illustrates how to determine whether an insurance company is subject to SEC regulation.

 

Financial Accounting Standards Board

The SEC has delegated its responsibility for establishing U.S. GAAP to the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB), a private organization. The primary role of the FASB (pronounced FAZ-bee) is to establish and promote the use of U.S. GAAP. Historically, the FASB issued authoritative publications, most of which are known as Statements of Financial Accounting Standards. FASB publications apply to insurance companies that conduct business in the United States.

EXAMPLE

Example. In 1982, the FASB issued Statement 60, which was intended to explain the accounting requirements for all types of life insurance contracts. However, in practice, it dealt primarily with accounting for traditional whole life insurance policies. Therefore, in 1987, the FASB issued Statement 97, which presented the accounting requirements for nontraditional life insurance contracts, such as universal life insurance policies.

In 2009, the FASB completed the Accounting Standards Codification (ASC), which codified all U.S. GAAP into a single source. This compilation includes all the FASB’s previous publications, as well as other authoritative guidance. With the ASC, new FASB publications take the form of Accounting Standards Updates (ASUs).

EXAMPLE

Example. In 2018, the FASB issued an Accounting Standards Update (ASU) titled Targeted Improvements to the Accounting for Long-Duration Contracts. Long-duration contracts are contracts, such as whole life insurance policies or annuity contracts, that are expected to remain in force for an extended period. Among other matters, this ASU provides a simplified method of amortizing deferred acquisition costs (DAC). 1 We discuss DAC in a later chapter.

A company must disclose in its financial reports all significant departures from FASB guidance. The FASB has representation on the IASB.

 

American Institute of Certified Public Accountants

The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants (AICPA) is a professional association of CPAs in the United States. Although the AICPA has no regulatory powers, its influence is widespread. Through its Auditing Standards Board, the AICPA develops generally accepted auditing standards (GAAS), which public accountants use when conducting audits of an insurer’s financial statements.

EXAMPLE

Example. In January 2010, the AICPA finalized a new auditing standard for insurance companies and other financial services organizations: The Statement on Standards for Attestation Engagements (SSAE) No. 16 (SSAE 16).

The AICPA also influences accounting practices through its technical advisory committees, its publications, and its code of professional conduct for accounting professionals.

EXAMPLE

Example. The AICPA’s Audit & Accounting Guide: Life and Health Insurance Entities is a useful text for individuals who work in the accounting and financial reporting areas of life and health insurance companies. This technical guide is designed to help insurance companies (1) prepare their GAAP and statutory financial statements and (2) perform and report on their auditing activities. 2

 

Public Company Auditing Oversight Board

As a result of several high-profile accounting scandals in the early 2000s, Congress passed the U.S. federal law known as the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 (SOX) requires public companies to take specific precautions to prevent fraudulent behavior on the part of management and the company’s external auditors. SOX established the Public Company Auditing Oversight Board (PCAOB), which is a private-sector, nonprofit corporation that sets the auditing standards for external auditors of public companies. The purpose of the PCAOB is to protect the interests of investors by ensuring that audit reports are informative, fair, and independent.

 

National Association of Insurance Commissioners

The National Association of Insurance Commissioners (NAIC) is a private, nonprofit association of the commissioners of all 50 states, the District of Columbia, and the U.S. territories that promotes uniformity of state regulation by developing model laws and regulations that serve as guidelines for the states. Although the NAIC has no legislative power, its recommendations and actions strongly influence the individual state insurance commissioners, the state legislatures, and the insurance industry. Each state insurance department or commission determines which NAIC recommendations it approves or modifies, and then incorporates these recommendations into its state reporting requirements for insurers.

The NAIC’s influence on insurance accounting is strongest with respect to the U.S. Annual Statement, which we discussed earlier. The NAIC specifies the format and content of the Annual Statement. The NAIC also uses information in the Annual Statement to evaluate an insurer’s financial condition, as well as its compliance with insurance laws and regulatory requirements.

 

Internal Revenue Service

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS), a part of the U.S. Department of the Treasury, is the governmental agency responsible for enforcing the provisions of laws and regulations concerning income taxes. Insurers in the United States must adhere to the tax code of the IRS. The IRS significantly influences the way in which insurance companies conduct business. A complete discussion of tax accounting, the tax code, and specific tax effects on an insurer’s products is beyond the scope of this textbook.

pages.title: Financial Tools and Insurer Solvency
pages.contents:
Financial Tools and Insurer Solvency

Insurance company financial statements come under intense scrutiny from government regulators, including state insurance departments. This scrutiny is intended to identify potential solvency problems so that regulators can initiate preventive measures to avert insurer insolvency—the inability to meet financial obligations on time. Specific tools used to measure and monitor solvency differ among nations. In the following sections, we describe several tools commonly used in the United States.

 

Insurance Regulatory Information System

In the United States, the NAIC has established a solvency framework designed to enhance state regulatory efforts. 3 One important component of this framework, known as the Insurance Regulatory Information System (IRIS), is a collection of financial tools and databases designed to help state insurance regulators evaluate the financial condition of insurers that operate in their states. The goal of IRIS is to enable regulators to allocate resources to those insurers in greatest need of regulatory attention.

IRIS consists of two phases: the statistical phase, which features a tool known as the IRIS ratio application, and the analytical phase, in which a group of financial examiners and analysts works together on an analyst team:

  1. During the statistical phase, the IRIS ratio application extracts data from each insurer’s electronically filed Annual Statement and automatically calculates the results of 12 financial ratios for each insurer. The first eight ratios are tests of an insurer’s solvency and profitability. The remaining four ratios assess the insurer’s operations by measuring changes in premiums, product mix, asset mix, and reserving. The ratio results are then compiled in a report that presents an alphabetical listing of all the insurers in the state by type of insurer, along with their ratio results, the usual ranges for results, and the identification of values outside the ranges.
  2. In the analytical phase, the analyst team evaluates the IRIS ratio results of specified insurance companies. (An NAIC working group determines the criteria to be used in targeting specific insurers for the analyst team review.) After reviewing the results, the analyst team designates certain insurers as “Level A,” “Level B,” or “Reviewed, no level”:

  • “Level A” means that state regulators should give this insurer the highest priority in the review process. A “Level A” insurer is not necessarily facing insolvency; rather, this designation means that the insurer’s financial condition bears greater scrutiny.

  • “Level B” means that, although the insurer has some adverse results, it is a lower priority for state regulators than a “Level A” insurer.

  • “Reviewed, no level” refers to an insurer whose results have the lowest priority for state regulators.

Note that IRIS ratio results are only useful to regulators if the information in an insurer’s Annual Statement is accurate and complete. If an insurer’s financial information is missing or incorrect, its ratio results will be flawed. In this event, regulators generally ask the insurer to correct the mistakes in its Annual Statement and resubmit it, a process known as an amended filing. Then the IRIS ratio application generates a new set of results for the insurer.

 

Risk-Based Capital Requirements

Each country sets minimum capital requirements for domestic and international insurance companies. Capital is the amount of money invested in a company by its owners, usually through the purchase of the company’s stock. In the United States, one serious shortcoming of the minimum capital requirements is that they ignore the different risks to which insurers may be exposed.

To address this situation, the NAIC has established risk-based capital (RBC) requirements, which evaluate the adequacy of an insurer’s capital based on the insurer’s size and risk profile. 4 The RBC requirements are determined using a ratio known as the risk-based capital (RBC) ratio, which is calculated by applying various risk factors to specific asset, premium, claim, expense, and reserve items found in the insurer’s Annual Statement. Each insurer calculates its own RBC ratio results and includes them in a detailed report that must be electronically filed with the NAIC.

In evaluating a given insurer, an insurance regulator compares the results of the RBC ratios with specified trigger points to determine whether regulatory intervention is necessary and, if so, to what degree. Because risk-based capital is the minimum threshold of capital required, insurance companies aim for a significantly higher amount of capital and surplus—in effect, a safety cushion—than is necessary to satisfy regulatory requirements.

Financial Condition Examinations

IRIS ratios and RBC requirements are both examples of offsite investigations of insurer solvency. State regulators also conduct onsite investigations of insurers, including financial condition examinations. A financial condition examination is an onsite regulatory examination of an insurer that is carried out by one or more state insurance departments and is designed to identify and monitor any threats to the insurer’s solvency. In most U.S. states, each insurer domiciled in the state must undergo a financial condition examination once every three to five years by the state insurance department. More frequent examinations are conducted if the state insurance commissioner believes they are warranted. The insurer usually bears the cost of a financial condition examination.

In conducting a financial condition examination, state examiners

  • Verify the operating results reported in the insurer’s U.S. Annual Statement.

  • Examine the insurer’s accounting records to determine whether the insurer is operating on a sound and lawful basis. Inaccurate financial records may conceal financial problems or unlawful activities.

  • Investigate the insurer’s financial and business activities to ensure that they do not contribute to the insurer’s insolvency.

State examiners also review other factors that help them evaluate whether the insurer is in compliance with the law. For example, examiners might perform a broad-based analysis of the insurer’s financial accounts and lines of business, or they might focus their analysis on specified problem areas, as identified from the insurer’s Annual Statement, IRIS ratio results, RBC ratio results, previous examinations, or any other source.

One increasingly important source of information for examiners is an insurer’s ORSA. In an Own Risk and Solvency Assessment (ORSA), an insurer conducts an internal assessment of the risks associated with its current business plan and the adequacy of its capital resources to support those risks. The ORSA includes a high-level summary of an insurer’s risk management framework, as well as details on the insurer’s process for assessing risks in both normal and stressed environments. The NAIC typically requires insurers to undergo an ORSA on at least an annual basis.

Working through the NAIC, the states have developed a zone system to oversee the examinations of multistate insurers. According to this system, each insurance company is domiciled within one of four geographic zones in the United States. For any insurer that operates in more than one zone or in more than three states, the NAIC recommends that the insurer undergo an association examination. In an association examination, also known as a coordinated exam, examiners representing various states in the geographic zones in which the insurer is licensed participate in examining the insurer. Most financial condition examinations are association examinations.

Figure 1.9 presents the NAIC zone system.

The results of a financial condition examination are summarized in a document called an examination report, which is submitted to state regulators and the insurance company’s officers. The examination report

  • Emphasizes any adverse conditions the examiners discover and any significant changes in the insurer’s operations or financial condition since the last report

  • Identifies and reports any problems uncovered during the most recent examination

  • May explain the causes of problems and suggestions for how the insurer might correct the problems

pages.title: Account Classification
pages.contents:
Account Classification

An account is the basic tool that a company uses to record, group, and summarize similar types of business transactions. An insurance company’s business transactions, like those of other companies, typically involve five major account classifications: (1) assets, (2) liabilities, (3) owners’ equity, (4) revenues, and (5) expenses. A company’s account classifications make up its chart of accounts, which is a numbered or alphabetical list of all the company’s account names. Developing and maintaining the chart of accounts is typically under the controller’s span of control. Account titles and numbering schemes vary from insurer to insurer, but a simple chart of accounts appears below:

1000 Assets
  1001 Bonds
  1002 Common Stocks
  1003 Mortgages
2000 Liabilities
  2001 Contractual Reserves
  2002 Other Liabilities
3000 Owners' Equity
  3001 Capital
  3002 Surplus
4000 Revenues
  4001 Premium Income
  4002 Investment Income
  4003 Fee Income
5000 Expenses
  5001 Contractual Benefits
  5002 Operating Expenses

In this chapter, we present an overview of the five major account classifications. These accounts appear on a company’s balance sheet and income statement. Watch Video 2.1 to learn about these two statements.

Video 2.1 The Balance Sheet and the Income Statement

The Balance Sheet and the Income Statement

Balance Sheet Accounts

The first three account classifications we discuss—assets, liabilities, and owners’ equity—are found on a company’s balance sheet. A balance sheet, also called a statement of financial position or statement of financial condition, is a financial statement that shows a company’s financial condition or position by summarizing the company’s assets, liabilities, and owners’ equity as of a specified date. Let’s take a look at each of these three accounts now.

 

Assets: What Does the Company Own?

Assets are the items of value owned by a company. Assets may be

  • Tangible (physical), such as real estate, office supplies, and computer equipment, or

  • Intangible (not physical), such as securities (including stocks and bonds), trademarks, and goodwill

Insurers use their assets as a resource to generate cash, which they can use to fulfill their financial obligations.

EXAMPLE

Example. Insurance companies typically invest in bonds, which are assets. Whenever the bonds pay interest, mature, or are sold by an insurer, the insurer receives cash, which it can use to settle policyowner claims or other financial commitments.

One important characteristic of an asset is its liquidity, which is the ease with which the asset can be converted to cash for an approximation of its underlying value. In the context of liquidity, insurers may categorize their assets as either short-term or long-term:

  • Short-term assets, also called current assets, are assets that a company expects to readily convert into cash or consume within the current accounting period, typically one year. Short-term assets generally have high liquidity.

  • Long-term assets, also called noncurrent assets, are assets that a company plans to hold indefinitely or for a long time—generally longer than one year—to generate income. Compared to short-term assets, long-term assets usually take longer to convert to cash and are generally illiquid (the opposite of liquid).

Watch Video 2.2 on asset liquidity to see some examples of short-term and long-term assets.

Video 2.2 Asset Liquidity

Asset Liquidity

Liabilities: What Does the Company Owe?

Liabilities represent the monetary value of a company’s current and future obligations. Liabilities result from a monetary commitment that the company’s management has made on behalf of the company. As such, liabilities represent demands against the company’s assets. A payable—an amount the company has promised to pay to another party—is a liability.

To remain in business, an insurer must have a higher monetary value for its assets than for its liabilities:

Insurer assets ˃ Insurer liabilities

An insurer’s liabilities consist primarily of contractual reserves for future obligations, which are the amounts it expects to pay its policyowners, annuity contract owners, and beneficiaries.

As with assets, insurers may categorize their liabilities as either short-term or long-term:

  • Short-term liabilities, also called current liabilities, are financial obligations that the company must pay in one year or less. Agent commissions payable is one example of a short-term liability for insurers.

  • Long-term liabilities, also called noncurrent liabilities, are liabilities that the company does not have to pay in full during the current accounting period—usually one year. Bonds that an insurer issues—rather than purchases—are an example of a long-term liability for an insurer.

 

Owners’ Equity: What Has the Company Retained?

Owners’ equity represents all owner investments in the company. These investments represent a residual claim against a company’s assets. In other words, if a company goes out of business, its owners—that is, the stockholders of a stock insurer or the policyowners of a mutual insurer or fraternal insurer—are entitled to whatever remains of the company’s assets after all creditor claims and policyowner claims have been paid. In this sense, owners’ equity is the difference between a company’s assets and its liabilities:

Owners’ Equity = Assets – Liabilities

Sometimes, insurance companies replace the term owners’ equity with capital and surplus:

Capital + Surplus = Assets – Liabilities

Recall from Chapter 1 that, in the context of accounting, capital represents the amount of money invested in a company by its owners, usually through the purchase of the company’s stock.

One important example of a capital account is Retained Earnings. Retained earnings represents the net income that an insurance company holds to reinvest in the company instead of paying the money out in dividends to its stockholders. Stock insurers use the Retained Earnings account when preparing GAAP financial reports. To comply with statutory financial reporting requirements, insurance companies use Surplus instead of Retained Earnings. Surplus is the cumulative amount of money—calculated as an insurance company’s assets minus its liabilities and capital—that remains in the company over time. Because mutual insurers and fraternal insurers do not have stockholders, they have no capital accounts. Thus, for mutual and fraternal insurers, we can say that

Surplus = Assets – Liabilities

 

Income Statement Accounts

The remaining two account classifications—revenues and expenses—are found on a company’s income statement. An income statement, also called a statement of operations, is a financial statement that reports an insurer’s revenues and expenses during a specified period and indicates whether the insurer experienced net income or a net loss during the accounting period. We explain all of these terms below.

 

Revenues: What Has the Company Earned?

Revenues represent the amount of earnings from a company’s core business operations. For insurance companies, core business operations include selling insurance and annuity products and services to customers, collecting investment income from investments that they own, and collecting fee income from providing administrative or management services to customers.

In general, an increase in a company’s revenues ultimately results in an increase in the company’s assets. For example, when a policyowner pays a policy premium, this transaction ultimately increases not only an insurer’s revenues but also its cash, which is an asset.

 

Expenses: What Has the Company Spent?

Expenses, also known as costs, are the amounts that a company spends in the course of conducting business. Expenses are a necessary part of doing business, because a company cannot generate revenues without incurring expenses. Typical expenses for an insurer include investment expenses, contractual benefit expenses, and operating expenses. Employee salaries usually are a large percentage of an insurer’s expenses.

Unlike revenues, which ultimately increase a company’s assets, expenses ultimately decrease the company’s assets. For example, the act of paying a policy claim (an expense) decreases cash (an asset).

The relationship between an insurer’s revenues and expenses determines the insurer’s net income or net loss. Net income, or net profit, is any money that results from an excess of total revenues over total expenses during a specified period.

Total revenues > Total expenses = Net income

Likewise, a net loss is the amount of a company’s total expenses that exceeds its total revenues during a specified period. A company usually reports a net loss, which is a negative amount, in parentheses or in a different color, such as red, on its financial statements.

Total expenses > Total revenues = (Net loss)

OR

Total expenses > Total revenues = Net loss

The Basic Accounting Equation

To understand the relationship between the five major account classifications, we need to look at a fundamental part of the accounting function known as the basic accounting equation. The basic accounting equation, sometimes called the balance sheet equation, is the formula that expresses the relationship among the three key account classifications that a company reports on its balance sheet: Assets, Liabilities, and Owners’ Equity. We can express the basic accounting equation as follows:

Assets = Liabilities + Owners’ Equity

Like all companies, insurance companies must keep both sides of this equation in balance—hence, the “balance” in “balance sheet.” Therefore, every business transaction that changes one side of the equation must be offset by at least one change to the other side of the equation.

For stock insurance companies, we can substitute the term Capital and Surplus for Owners’ Equity, as follows:

Assets = Liabilities + Capital + Surplus

EXAMPLE

Example. To illustrate how the basic accounting equation stays in balance, let’s look at a simple transaction for a stock insurer.

A stock insurer issues additional stock to investors. This transaction increases Cash (part of Assets) on the left side of the equation, and this change is exactly offset by an equal increase to Capital on the right side of the equation.

Recall that mutual insurers and fraternal insurers have no capital accounts, so we can simplify the basic accounting equation for these types of insurers as follows:

Assets = Liabilities + Surplus

EXAMPLE

Example. Let’s look at another simple transaction, this time for a mutual insurer.

A mutual insurer pays out policy dividends in cash to owners of its participating life insurance policies. This transaction decreases Cash (part of Assets) on the left side of the equation, and this change is exactly offset by an equal decrease in the insurer’s Liabilities on the right side of the equation. (We discuss policy dividends as a liability for insurers in a later chapter.)

The basic accounting equation can be expanded to include an insurer’s revenues and expenses. At the end of an accounting period, the insurer closes out all its revenue and expense accounts on the income statement and transfers the net income or net loss—that is, total revenues minus total expenses—for the period to the Owners’ Equity account on the balance sheet.

Therefore, we can expand the basic accounting equation to include all five major account classifications:

Assets = Liabilities + Owners’ Equity + (Revenues – Expenses)

pages.title: The Operating Cycle
pages.contents:
The Operating Cycle

Tracking the flow of funds through a company is a primary focus of the accounting function. We call the way in which funds flow through a company as it conducts its day-to-day business activities the operating cycle. In accounting terminology, funds flowing into a company are a source of funds and funds flowing out of a company are a use of funds.

 

Sources of Funds

Typical sources of an insurer’s funds are the revenues—typically income—generated from the insurer’s core business activities. Because they are revenues, an insurer’s sources of funds answer the question: what has the insurer earned?

Insurers have three main types of income that serve as sources of funds:

  • Premium income. An insurer earns premium income when it agrees to accept financial risk and issues an insurance policy or annuity contract.

  • Investment income. As the insurer receives premium income, it invests a portion of that income, thereby earning additional income—known as investment income—in the form of interest, dividends, or rental income.

  • Fee income. Insurers typically obtain fee income by providing brokerage services, management services for separate accounts, third-party administration (TPA) services for other insurers, and retirement administration services. Fee income is a growing source of funds for some life insurance companies.

 

Uses of Funds

A life insurance company’s primary uses of funds include paying

  • Contractual benefits

  • Policy dividends

  • Various operating expenses, such as agent commissions and salaries, taxes, licenses, and fees

 

Contractual Benefit Payments

Insurance companies exist to provide promised benefits to owners of their insurance products, so one of an insurer’s main uses of funds is to pay contractual benefits. Contractual benefits are amounts that an insurer is legally required to pay under the terms of an insurance contract when a covered loss occurs.

 

Policy Dividends

Insurers also use funds to pay policy dividends on participating policies. A policy dividend is a portion of an insurer’s surplus that the insurer pays to the owner of a participating policy. An insurer typically pays policy dividends when its actual mortality experience is more favorable than expected. In essence, a policy dividend is a return of excess premium to the policyowner. Do not confuse policy dividends with stockholder dividends, which are another use of an insurer’s funds. Stockholder dividends are payments to the owners of stock in a stock insurance company.

 

Operating Expenses

All companies pay various operating expenses, which a company incurs in conducting its normal business operations. An insurer’s operating expenses are similar to those of many noninsurance companies and include such items as employee salaries, rent, maintenance, advertising, travel, and legal expenses.

Among the most significant operating expenses for insurers are agent commissions and salaries, which also represent a large use of an insurer’s funds. Most individual life insurance policies are sold on a commission basis. However, insurers typically compensate agents who sell group life insurance products on a salary basis.

In addition, life insurers pay taxes that many noninsurance companies pay, including property taxes and unemployment taxes. Life insurers also pay some insurance-specific taxes and fees, such as premium taxes and licensing fees.

pages.contents:
Double-Entry Accounting

All companies, including insurance companies, use double-entry accounting to record business transactions in their accounting systems. With double-entry accounting, every accounting entry must (1) have at least one debit and one credit, (2) have an equal monetary amount of debits and credits, and (3) maintain the balance of the basic accounting equation.

The cornerstone of double-entry accounting is the dual concept, which states that every business transaction has two aspects—debits and credits—that always equal each other in their monetary amounts:

  • A debit is a change made to the monetary value of an account that (1) increases the value of asset accounts and expense accounts, and (2) decreases the value of liability accounts, owners’ equity accounts, and revenue accounts.

  • A credit is a change made to the monetary value of an account that (1) increases the value of liability accounts, owners’ equity accounts, and revenue accounts, and (2) decreases the value of asset accounts and expense accounts.

When recording an accounting entry, you usually list debits first, followed by credits.

 

Accounting Entries

An accounting entry, also called a journal entry, is a record of a business transaction that includes at least one debit and one credit and shows the monetary value of the transaction in balance. For an activity to qualify as a business transaction, the activity must have a financial impact on the company—that is, the company must be able to assign an objective monetary value to the transaction.

A company determines the monetary value of a business transaction from source documents. Source documents are the various business papers and electronic forms that contain original information about a company’s business transactions. Source documents verify that a business transaction occurred, as well as the details of the transaction, such as the date, monetary amount, and who approved the transaction. Many insurance companies now track source documents by scanning them and storing them in an electronic document database. Examples of typical source documents for insurance companies are approved policy applications, premium notices, policy surrender forms, claim forms, invoices, and confirmations of investment purchases and sales.

 

Simple Accounting Entries

A simple accounting entry is a record of a business transaction that affects only two accounts, and thus has only one debit and one credit. The accounting entry for the receipt of an annual premium is an example of a transaction that affects only two accounts. Suppose the Steadfast Life Insurance Company receives a $2,000 annual premium payment on a life insurance policy. This business transaction affects only two accounts—Cash and Premium Income—as shown below:

Cash.........................2,000

Premium Income………….2,000

To record the receipt of a $2,000 annual premium.

The example above shows a debit to Cash and a credit to Premium Income. The effect of this business transaction is to increase both Cash and Premium Income by $2,000, the amount of the premium payment. Note that journal entries list debits first and to the left and then list credits offset, or indented, to the right. In reality, most insurers have automated, electronic accounting entries; in these entries, debits might be listed in one column and credits in another column.

The accounting entry above also includes a brief verbal description underneath it. The purpose of including verbal descriptions in accounting entries is to help anyone reviewing the company’s accounts to understand the details of a given transaction. Most automated systems contain clickable phrases that describe common transactions and that include links to each affected account.

 

Compound Accounting Entries

Many business transactions affect more than two accounts. A compound accounting entry is an accounting record of a business transaction that affects more than two accounts. Suppose Steadfast paid a claim of $10,000 plus interest of $100 to the beneficiary of a life insurance policy. This business transaction affects three accounts—Death Claims Paid, Interest Payable, and Cash—as shown below:

Death Claims Paid............ 10,000

Interest Payable.......................... 100

Cash......................................... 10,100

To record the payment of a $10,000 death claim plus $100 interest. 

The debit to Death Claims Paid, an expense account, increases the balance of this account, whereas the debit to Interest Payable, a liability account, and the credit to Cash, an asset account, decrease the balance in these accounts.

Permanent Accounts and Temporary Accounts

Accounts are either permanent or temporary. In accounting, a permanent account is a balance sheet account that has a balance at the beginning of each accounting period. Permanent accounts include asset, liability, and owners’ equity accounts. In contrast, a temporary account, also called a nominal account, is an account that is closed out to a permanent account at the end of each accounting period. In other words, at the beginning of each accounting period, all temporary accounts have a zero balance. Temporary accounts comprise the account classifications included on the income statement: revenue accounts and expense accounts. Most temporary accounts are closed out to an owners’ equity account, such as Retained Earnings or Surplus.

 

Closing Entries

Companies use closing entries to move the balances in their temporary accounts to permanent accounts at the end of the accounting period. A closing entry is an accounting entry that a company makes at the end of each accounting period to start the next accounting period with a zero balance in its temporary accounts. Because a revenue earned or an expense incurred in one period pertains only to that period, revenues and expenses must be closed out at the end of each accounting period. Adjusting Entries

An adjusting entry is an accounting entry that a company makes to record accruals for revenues and expenses, unearned revenues, and prepaid expenses. Accruals allow an insurer to record expenses incurred but not yet paid and to record revenues earned but not yet received. Other adjusting entries include depreciation, changes made to reserve accounts, and corrections to previous accounting periods. After making the appropriate adjusting entries at the end of each accounting period, a company prepares its financial statements; it then records the applicable closing entries to ready its accounting records for the start of the next accounting period.

Adjusting entries typically apply to transactions of which a company has knowledge but lacks the appropriate source documents. Regardless, the company is still required to provide some type of documentation to support these entries. For example, salaries that an insurance company’s employees have earned during this year, but that the company will not pay until next year, may not yet have a time sheet or the equivalent source document available. Nonetheless, at the end of the accounting period, the company will prepare documentation that shows the amount of the adjusting entry, along with supporting details about how the monetary amounts were calculated. Using the general format of debiting an expense account—Salaries Expense, in this case—and crediting a payable account—Salaries Payable—the company prepares an adjusting entry as follows:

Salaries Expense........................ xxx

Salaries Payable........................ xxx

To adjust for salaries that have been earned but not yet paid.

Next year, upon paying the accrued salaries, the company would debit Salaries Payable and credit Cash to record this transaction, as follows:

Salaries  Payable.................. xxx

Cash......................................... xxx

To pay accrued salaries from the previous year.

In describing double-entry accounting and the different types of accounting entries, we generally state that the “company” makes various entries in its accounting system. In reality, most insurance companies use sophisticated accounting software, which performs many accounting tasks with minimal human intervention.

The insight below describes a relatively new technology that has the potential to transform the accounting function: robotic process automation (RPA).

INSIGHT

Robotic Process Automation

Robotic process automation (RPA) refers to the use of sophisticated computer software that is configured to automate manual and repetitive rules-based tasks without the need for constant human supervision. The word “robotic” in RPA conjures up the steel-encased robots from science fiction lore. In this context, though, the word refers to the computer software, which has been programmed to perform various tasks in an automatic, “robotic” way. In insurance accounting, companies can use RPA to record and process transactions, manipulate data, and communicate with other company systems when necessary.

What can a typical company expect using RPA?

  • A reduction in data entry costs of up to 70%
  • A double-digit reduction in error rates
  • Automated solutions that can work 24 hours a day, 7 days a week
  • An increase in efficiency of up to 50%
  • A 40% reduction in the workforce
  • A 100% reduction in human error, along with a 100% recorded audit trail

As noted above, a company using RPA typically sees a reduction in its workforce. However, with “robots” (or “bots”) performing the tedious, repetitive tasks associated with many business transactions, financial professionals can potentially spend more of their time on high-value activities, such as analyzing and interpreting data.

Although RPA is relatively new, its potential to increase operating efficiencies has gained the attention of insurers—as well as companies in other industries—around the world.

Source

 

Normal Balances

An account’s balance is the monetary amount in the account as of a specified date. To obtain the balance in an account, you calculate the difference between the account’s debits and its credits:

  • If an account’s debits typically exceed its credits, the account is said to have a normal debit balance.

  • If an account’s credits typically exceed its debits, the account is said to have a normal credit balance.

In accounting, an account’s normal balance is the side of the account, either debit or credit, to which increases to the account are recorded. Accounts that are increased by

  • Debits typically have a normal debit balance at the end of the accounting period

  • Credits usually have a normal credit balance at the end of the accounting period

Normal balances are an important tool that managers (and others) can use to evaluate accounts and look for problems. For example, sometimes an account that has a normal debit balance shows a credit balance; alternatively, an account that has a normal credit balance shows a debit balance. In such cases, the manager who is responsible for that specific account balance must review it. For example, Cash has a normal debit balance. A credit balance in Cash means that the cash balance is below zero and must be investigated.

pages.title: Financial Statement Concepts
pages.contents:
Financial Statement Concepts

Two important accounting concepts are the entity concept and the going-concern concept. In a sense, they define what the company is: which pieces make up the company, and how those pieces interact today and will continue to interact in the future.

 

Entity Concept

An entity is the basic business unit for which a company keeps separate accounting records and prepares reports. An entity may be a person, a partnership, a corporation, an organization, a business, or a portion of a business, such as a corporate subsidiary. A company can define its own accounting entities. The entity concept states that a company must account separately for the business activities of each business unit. When the company has identified its accounting entities, only the transactions that relate to these entities will typically appear on the company’s financial statements. A very basic expression of the entity concept is the understanding that an individual is a separate entity from the company she works for: she cannot attribute her personal expenses to her company’s accounts, and, in turn, she cannot attribute the company’s expenses to her personal accounts.

In general, when a company controls one or more companies—usually referred to as subsidiaries—these subsidiaries maintain detailed records of their own financial transactions. Under U.S. GAAP, a company with a controlling financial interest—usually more than 50 percent ownership—in a business is required to consolidate its financial reporting. The company therefore summarizes and consolidates the records maintained by its subsidiaries into the financial statements it prepares. Usually, the financial statements are labeled with the name of the entity being represented.

Consolidated financial reporting records the business activities or transactions of a company and each of its majority-owned subsidiaries as a single entity. However, under statutory reporting, the company reports its investment in each majority-owned subsidiary in the Annual Statement as the company would report other investments of a similar type (such as common stock or preferred stock). Statutory reporting considers subsidiaries to be investments because shares of ownership are a marketable asset that the company could sell to meet its obligations to policyowners, even when the cash flow generated by a subsidiary might not be available.

Figure 3.1 shows an example of the entity concept under GAAP and statutory accounting.

 

Going-Concern Concept

The going-concern concept in accounting states that a company should maintain its accounting records to reflect the assumption that the company will continue to operate indefinitely. In other words, accounting records must reflect that the company is not facing liquidation. Liquidation is the process of selling all company assets for cash and using that cash to pay the company’s debts; any funds remaining are distributed to the owners of the business. The going-concern concept is an underlying premise of GAAP. It is not, however, entirely presumed under statutory accounting principles, which follow a modified going-concern concept. The primary objective under statutory accounting is solvency—to ensure that an insurer can meet its current and future obligations.

The going-concern concept affects a company’s financial reporting because this concept

  • Allows the company to defer the reporting of specified costs to a future accounting period if the costs are related to future income

  • Assumes that the company will pay off its liabilities over time as scheduled, instead of paying them in full immediately or during the current accounting period

EXAMPLE

Example. As a going concern, the Regalia Insurance Company does not liquidate its assets and distribute the proceeds to all policyowners in the current accounting period, regardless of whether the insured is living. Instead, Regalia pays contractual benefits upon receipt of death claims on in-force policies. Thus, Regalia intends to remain a going concern and plans to pay contractual benefits in the future. Also, as a going concern, Regalia decides to prepay its office rent in December to rent offices for January, but can defer the reporting of the Rental Expense account to the January accounting period.

pages.title: Qualitative Characteristics of Accounting Information
pages.contents:
Qualitative Characteristics of Accounting Information

Because insurance companies enter into long-term contracts with their customers, insurers must be able to anticipate future revenues and expenses as accurately as possible. The predictive quality of a company’s accounting information is vital to this purpose. Strong predictive quality relies in part on specified qualitative characteristics. These qualitative characteristics help ensure that a sophisticated analysis of a company’s financial statements will provide an accurate and useful understanding of the company’s financial condition. Here we discuss the impact of these characteristics on a company’s financial statements.

 

GAAP Characteristics

Qualitative characteristics that are particularly important under GAAP include

  • Understandability

  • Relevance

  • Reliability

  • Comparability and consistency

Materiality and cost-effectiveness also contribute to predictive quality. Figure 3.2 illustrates these characteristics.

 

Understandability

Under GAAP, a company’s financial statements must be understandable. The quality of understandability requires that a company’s financial statements disclose relevant financial information in such a way that interested parties can comprehend the information and make decisions based on it. Such decisions may include buying, holding, or selling the company’s stock; purchasing the company’s products or services; or applying for a job at the company. Of the GAAP characteristics, understandability is often considered the highest-level concept, because relevance, reliability, comparability, and consistency are all necessary for a company’s financial statements to be understandable.

 

Relevance

In accounting terminology, the characteristic of relevance requires accounting information to be useful, timely, and likely to affect an interested user’s decisions about a company. Relevant accounting information explains how a company has performed during the past accounting period, helps interested users project how the company is likely to perform in the future, and appears on a timely basis so that users can act on the information. A company generally reports only relevant information in its financial statements. Irrelevant information might cloud or distort the picture of a company’s financial performance or condition.

 

Reliability

Accounting information has the characteristic of reliability if it is accurate, objective, and free from bias and misrepresentation. The IASB has referred to this characteristic as “faithful representation.” Reliable accounting information fairly represents a company’s financial strength or profitability. In most situations, preparers compile objective information using a standardized measurement method. Further, the company must record and report accounting information in such a manner that outside experts, such as external auditors and regulators, can verify that the information is truthful and based on objective measurements. Objective measurements are based on source documents and explicitly forbid bias or personal opinion.

Sometimes, relevant information is not reliable. For example, information about a company’s plan to market a new product is relevant because the likelihood of the new product’s success could affect an investor’s decision to purchase the company’s stock. However, information about the financial impact the new product may have on the company is a reflection of management’s expectations for the product, not the product’s actual performance. Thus, the new product information is not reliable because it is not objective and verifiable.

When a conflict arises between relevance and reliability, the information in question is usually left out of financial statements. Generally, the information reported on an insurer’s financial statements is both relevant and reliable. Subjective but relevant information is reported in an accompanying narrative (notes) section of the insurer’s financial statements. Figure 3.3 summarizes this process.

Let’s look at a simple example of such a conflict, which does not always lead to a simple solution.

EXAMPLE

Example. The Malabar Life Insurance Company recently lost a court case but is currently appealing the decision. In this situation, the court case is relevant, but the financial impact may be difficult to measure reliably in the current accounting period. In this case, Malabar summarized the potential financial impact of either outcome of this case in a note that accompanied its financial statements.

 

Comparability and Consistency

The characteristic of comparability requires a company’s financial statements to be presented in such a way that interested users can identify similarities and differences in financial information across accounting periods and among different companies. In other words, a company’s financial statements must be comparable both to the company’s statements from earlier accounting periods and to the financial statements of other companies for those same accounting periods.

EXAMPLE

Example. In a note to its financial statements, the Gardenia Life Insurance Company explained that it is now reporting certain assets at their current market value rather than their original purchase price. This change improves the comparability of Gardenia’s financial statements over time, as a user can compare these assets’ values with their values in previous years. It also makes Gardenia’s balance sheet more readily comparable with the balance sheets of other life insurance companies that report these assets according to current market value.

Consistency is both an important qualitative characteristic under statutory accounting principles and a key component of comparability under GAAP. In accounting terminology, consistency means that a company applies the same accounting policies and procedures to the accounting information in its financial statements from one accounting period to the next, unless there is a sound reason for changing a specified policy or procedure.

Comparability and consistency are interrelated because they both require a company to use the same accounting policies and procedures from one accounting period to the next, unless a valid reason to make a change exists. As with comparability, consistency requires a company to disclose the nature and impact of any changes to its accounting policies and procedures. Consistency enables interested parties to compare a company’s financial performance over time. Consistency has two aspects: a company must record

  • Similar transactions the same way from transaction to transaction

  • Financial information the same way from one accounting period to the next

In some situations, accounting offers more than one acceptable method for assigning a monetary value to an account’s balance. For example, the valuation method used for an insurer’s bond holdings does not have to be the same valuation method used for an insurer’s real estate. However, the method chosen for valuing the insurer’s bond holdings or real estate must be applied consistently across all accounting periods.

A company can also change the accounting methods it uses from one accounting period to the next if the company describes the financial effects of the change. The change, and the reason for the change, should be disclosed in notes attached to the financial statements. An insurer typically changes accounting methods because of changes in

  • Accounting principles or insurance regulations

  • The insurer’s structure, goals, or procedures

  • The insurer’s business environment

EXAMPLE

Example. For decades, Gardenia reported the value of specific assets on its balance sheet at their original purchase price. Recently, Gardenia began reporting these assets at their current market value because it more accurately reflects the value of these assets. In a note to its financial statements, Gardenia describes the effects of this change on its financial condition and performance over time.

 

Materiality and Cost-Effectiveness

GAAP qualitative characteristics also must work within the constraints of materiality and cost-effectiveness. Materiality means that companies must report all significant information in their financial statements. Generally, an item of information is significant or material if its reporting, the lack of its reporting, or its misrepresentation could affect decisions made by interested users.

Whether information is material or not relies heavily on the judgment of a company’s accountants and management. The materiality of specific items or entries can also vary from company to company. For example, $20,000 of office supplies probably is not a material asset to a $50 billion company, yet this same asset probably is material to a $1 million company. Insurers usually consider several factors about a transaction, as well as the types of accounts the transaction affects, in evaluating whether accounting information about the transaction is material.

Although insurers should report all material information, they should capture this information in a cost-effective manner. The quality of cost-effectiveness means that a company considers the money spent to achieve the desired goals. A company should not incur huge expenses to record and report material accounting information. A given transaction’s materiality can be a judgment call. Let’s look at an example of how materiality and cost-effectiveness affect an insurer’s accounting information.

EXAMPLE

Example. Last year, the Alder Insurance Company purchased new computers for one of its divisions. The new computers significantly improved turnaround time for processing the division’s customer transactions. The costs incurred for the computers were relatively small amounts, when compared with the division’s budget, and Alder was able to capture the costs inexpensively in its automated accounting system. Alder’s management team determined that the cost of the computers was material and cost-effective to obtain and report. As a result, Alder included the costs incurred for purchasing the computers in its financial statements.

SAP Characteristics

The NAIC develops statutory accounting principles in accordance with the three concepts of

  • Conservatism

  • Consistency

  • Recognition

 

Conservatism

In contrast to GAAP-based accounting, under SAP, a life insurance company must report its accounting information in a conservative manner. In this context, conservatism is a prudent reaction for dealing with uncertainty in accounting records and reports. In practice, the use of conservatism typically understates the values of a company’s assets and revenues and overstates the values of the company’s liabilities and expenses. Insurers apply conservative accounting methods only if such conservatism does not violate other accounting qualities, such as relevance or reliability.

According to the quality of conservatism of accounting information, a company

  • Records revenues only when they are certain

  • Records expenses when they are incurred

  • Reports losses immediately

  • Reports gains only when they actually occur

Figure 3.4 illustrates these conservative principles.

Under conservatism, as compared with other financial reporting approaches, insurers typically report account values based on

  • Higher mortality rates for life insurance policies

  • Lower mortality rates for annuity contracts

  • Higher expense rates for each block of policies

  • Lower interest rates for investment earnings on assets that support life insurance policy reserves and annuity reserves

Regulators require conservative accounting methods to ensure that an insurer’s contractual reserves and surplus are more than adequate to protect policyowners and beneficiaries from adverse financial conditions. The following example shows how an insurer would incorporate conservatism into its financial reporting.

EXAMPLE

Example. The Watership Life Insurance Company is evaluating the first-year revenues and expenses for a new variable annuity product. Watership is uncertain that it will receive product revenues from a particular client, although the client has signed a contract to pay an amount that represents 2% of Watership’s revenues. In addition, Watership has incurred, but has not yet paid, product expenses that represent 3% of its total expenses. To comply with the conservatism requirement under statutory accounting principles, Watership reports the product’s expenses, but does not report the uncertain revenue from the client. Therefore, Watership is potentially overstating product expenses by 3% and understating product revenues by 2% in its statutory financial statements.

Because U.S. GAAP does not encourage conservatism, in preparing its GAAP financial statements, Watership will report both the unearned revenues and the expenses payable for the variable annuity product.

Under U.S. GAAP, the use of conservatism is considered biased and inconsistent with qualitative characteristics such as reliability and comparability.

 

Consistency

The qualitative characteristic of consistency is much the same when applied to statutory accounting as it is when applied to GAAP-based accounting. Regulators require meaningful, comparable financial information when determining an insurer’s financial condition. Therefore, a company’s accounting policies and procedures should remain consistent.

 

Recognition

In accounting terminology, recognition refers to the process of classifying an item in a financial statement as an asset, a liability, owners’ equity, a revenue, or an expense. Generally, a company recognizes revenue when a product is sold, when a service is completed, when cash changes hands, or when the legal ownership of a product passes from the company to a customer as part of a business transaction.
