pages.title: Account Maintenance Concepts and Principles
pages.contents:
Account Maintenance Concepts and Principles

In preparing accounting records and financial reports, all companies should follow certain concepts and principles. The following sections discuss these accounting concepts and principles.

 

Cost Concept

The cost concept, also called the historical-cost concept, the cost principle, the initial-recording concept, and the acquisition-cost concept, states that companies should include items on the balance sheet and income statement according to their actual cost at the time of purchase. For example, according to the cost concept, a company reports the historical cost, which is the original purchase price of an asset, on its balance sheet. An asset’s historical cost is derived from its book value on the date of purchase. An asset’s book value is the value at which the asset is recorded in a company’s accounting records.

Unlike an asset’s historical cost, an asset’s book value may change over time due to a variety of factors, including the recording of depreciation on the asset. (We discuss depreciation later in this chapter.) The reasoning behind the cost concept is that an asset’s historical cost provides a reliable measure of the asset’s value, because the historical cost is a verifiable figure that will not change. However, an asset’s historical cost may lack relevance because the asset may have significantly increased or decreased in value over time. Although the cost concept is useful in recording the values of certain assets, such as operations that depreciate equipment, companies often use other valuation methods to report the value of assets. We discuss these other methods in Chapter 5.

 

Money Measurement Concept

The money measurement concept, also called the measuring-unit concept, states that a company should record its accounting information in monetary terms, such as dollars, yen, or euros. The money measurement concept relies on the assumptions that

  • Only business transactions that have an objective monetary value can be reported in a company’s financial statements

  • The measuring unit’s value is stable over time

With regard to the first assumption, a company may possess resources critical to its success, such as employee education, that do not have an objective value. Therefore, the company cannot report these resources as assets in its financial statements. With regard to the second assumption, a company typically does not need to include notes to the financial statements to explain the loss of money’s value to rote inflation. In times of hyperinflation, however, a company may need to include notes to its financial statements, or even restate its financial statements, to show the true impact of the measuring unit’s loss of value. Note also that a company’s statements should consistently use the same monetary unit, rather than mixing currencies such as dollars and yen.

 

Full-Disclosure Concept

The full-disclosure concept states that a financial statement must contain all material information about a company and that the company must disclose any additional information or fact that, by its omission, could mislead an interested user of the company’s financial information. The full-disclosure concept implies the inclusion of every item that is material, relevant, reliable, comparable, and understandable, to provide a fair representation of a company’s financial condition and performance.

The full-disclosure concept also points to the critical role of notes and other supplementary materials that accompany an insurer’s financial statements. Examples of information that would be added to notes and other supplementary materials to provide full disclosure include pending mergers and acquisitions, or ongoing lawsuits. However, the full-disclosure concept does not require the inclusion of excessive details. For example, you are not necessarily better informed about the financial strength of a life insurance company if the company clutters its balance sheet with detailed descriptions of every government security that it owns. In such cases, you’ll find summary information more useful.

 

Time-Period Concept

The time-period concept states that a company’s financial statements should report the company’s business operations during a specified fiscal period, usually referred to as an accounting period. An accounting period is a specified length of time during which a company records, summarizes, and reports its financial transactions. Typical accounting periods are one month, one quarter, and one year. An accounting period is in itself arbitrary, given the assumed indefinite life associated with the going-concern concept. But without artificially imposed accounting periods, a company would have to postpone creating financial statements until the end of the company’s life, when all debts are paid and all investor claims are settled. Because a company’s financial information is needed during the company’s life, the time-period concept has evolved.

The time-period concept assumes that a company can identify an accounting period, reach a suitable cut-off date, and provide summary financial information as of that date or for that period. All companies must file specified financial statements at the end of each one-year period. Most companies also produce financial statements more frequently. These financial statements are usually called interim financial statements to distinguish them from annual financial statements.

Most insurance companies use a fiscal year that follows the calendar year—from January through December—as their annual accounting period. A fiscal year is a 12-month accounting period chosen by a company for financial reporting purposes. A company may select for financial reporting purposes a fiscal year other than the calendar year—such as September through August. However, insurance regulators typically require that insurers use the calendar year—January 1 through December 31—as the fiscal year for financial statements and reports submitted for regulatory purposes.

The drawback to adhering to the time-period concept is that a company does not complete all its transactions within one accounting period. A single accounting period might not be sufficient to complete even a simple transaction. For example, an insurer may incur agent commission expenses at the end of one period that will be paid at the beginning of the next period. Because transactions can take place over multiple accounting periods, a company’s management must ask the question: When should we record each revenue and each expense? To help companies answer this question, the accounting profession has developed two principles: (1) the realization principle for revenue recognition and (2) the matching principle for expense recognition.

 

Revenue Recognition: The Realization Principle

As you recall, recognition is the process of classifying the items in a financial statement properly, such as deciding whether an item is a liability or an expense. An insurer does not necessarily receive all its revenues in the same accounting period in which it earns them, such as when a customer chooses to pay for a service in advance. For this reason, the insurer follows certain guidelines to match the revenue with its correct accounting period, which is the period during which the insurer has earned the revenue.

Under U.S. GAAP, the realization principle states that a company should recognize revenue when it is earned, regardless of when the company receives the actual payment, so long as a legal and reasonable expectation exists that the customer will remit payment in full. For life insurance companies, revenue recognition applies primarily to the receipt of life insurance or annuity premiums. Insurers recognize premiums as they are earned over the lifetime of the insurance policy or annuity contract.

 

Expense Recognition: The Matching Principle

The matching principle governs the recognition of expenses. Under GAAP, the matching principle states that a company should recognize expenses as the company earns the revenues related to those expenses, regardless of when the company receives payment for the revenues earned and regardless of when the company actually paid the expenses. The realization principle and the matching principle work in tandem. A company reports earned revenue under the realization principle. The company also identifies the expenses it incurred to earn that specified revenue and records these expenses under the matching principle. Watch Video 3.1 for an example of these reporting principles in action.

Generally, U.S. GAAP permits three approaches to expense recognition: (1) associating cause and effect, (2) systematic and rational allocation, and (3) immediate recognition.

 

Associating Cause and Effect

Under GAAP, some expenses may be deferred and recognized over time. According to the approach of associating cause and effect, expenses that have a direct relationship to specified future revenues are charged to future accounting periods instead of being charged to the current accounting period.

One example of an expense that has a direct relationship to premium income is agent commissions. For specified types of insurance products, a life insurance company recognizes agent commissions in the same accounting period in which it receives the premium income generated by this expense. However, the expenses associated with products such as investment contracts and participating policies are usually spread across accounting periods as profits emerge from these products.

EXAMPLE

Example. Emphatic Life Insurance Company incurred agent commissions of $550,000 this year for its participating products. Under statutory accounting principles, Emphatic would report the entire $550,000 expense for agent commissions this year. Under GAAP, however, Emphatic would have to report only the portion of the $550,000 expense that applied directly to premium income earned this year. Emphatic calculates the amount to recognize as an expense each year according to the relationship of the current year’s earned premium income to its estimated future years’ premium income for its participating products. Emphatic would record the remainder of the expense as Deferred Acquisition Costs.

 

Systematic and Rational Allocation

Sometimes a direct association of cause and effect between revenues and expenses is not clearly recognizable. In such cases, a company uses another approach to recognize expenses according to GAAP. Under systematic and rational allocation, a company expenses an asset’s cost over its estimated useful life, regardless of when the company receives revenues from the asset. A common example of systematic and rational allocation is depreciation. Depreciation is the process of allocating (spreading) the cost of an asset over the asset’s estimated useful life. Salvage value is the residual value or selling price of an asset at the end of its useful life. Figure 3.5 shows an example of depreciation.

 

Immediate Recognition

Sometimes a company cannot match expenses during an accounting period with revenues earned for that period, nor can it match the expenses with revenues it expects to generate in the future. Other incurred expenses may provide no objectively recognizable future benefits to the company. In such cases, the company uses the immediate recognition approach to report expenses according to GAAP. Under immediate recognition, a company recognizes all costs as expenses during the current accounting period. Under statutory accounting principles, life insurers generally must use immediate recognition to recognize all incurred expenses—not just expenses for which the insurer cannot match revenues—in the current accounting period, rather than spread these expenses over the accounting periods in which premium income was earned.

EXAMPLE

Example. Suppose Emphatic incurs $42,000 in expenses for general legal services and $16,000 in employee training costs that cannot be attributed to revenues earned. Emphatic reports both the entire $42,000 legal service expense and the entire $16,000 employee training expense during the current accounting period.

pages.title: Accounting Bases
pages.contents:
Accounting Bases

The application of both the realization principle and the matching principle depends in part on the accounting basis that a company uses. The following sections discuss two major accounting bases: (1) accrual-basis accounting and (2) cash-basis accounting.

 

Accrual-Basis Accounting

Accrual-basis accounting is an accounting system under which a company records revenues when they are earned and expenses when they are incurred, even if the company has not yet received the revenues or paid the expenses. So, accrual-basis accounting

  • Records revenues according to the realization principle and expenses according to the matching principle

  • Helps match specific expenses with specific revenues, a process that typically enables companies to develop relevant, reliable, and comparable financial statements

The purpose of accrual-basis accounting is to record a business transaction when a company incurs a financial obligation or expects to receive a payment. Thus, accrual-basis accounting enables interested users of a company’s financial information to view the consequences of a company’s activities, including the company’s earning potential and financial performance. For this reason, accrual-basis accounting is generally regarded as more relevant, compared to cash-basis accounting. Accounting regulations generally mandate the use of accrual-basis accounting for financial reporting purposes.

Often, two separate accounting entries are needed to record a business transaction under accrual-basis accounting:

  1. The first accounting entry records the revenue earned or the expense incurred.
  2. The second accounting entry records the revenue received or the expense disbursed.

Companies that use accrual-basis accounting generally must also make adjusting entries to their accounting records at the end of each accounting period to match revenues and expenses in their financial statements for that accounting period.

 

Cash-Basis Accounting

Cash-basis accounting is an accounting system in which a company recognizes revenues or expenses only when it receives or disburses cash. In contrast, under accrual-basis accounting, a company’s financial statements must report the results of both cash and noncash transactions—for example, purchases on account—that occur during the accounting period. Neither the realization principle nor the matching principle applies under cash-basis accounting.

Cash receipts and cash disbursements are the most important components under cash-basis accounting. A cash receipt is a check, money order, electronic funds transfer (EFT), or other cash transaction that is remitted to a company as a form of payment for services rendered. A cash disbursement is the payment of cash by a company.

Under cash-basis accounting, a company records a

  • Cash receipt in the same accounting period in which it receives the cash

  • Cash disbursement in the same accounting period in which it remits payment

In a pure cash-basis system, a company makes no accounting entries to record pending revenues or expenses. Instead, the company calculates its net income by subtracting paid expenses from received revenues. Cash-basis accounting provides an accurate summary of a company’s current cash flows, but does not provide as accurate a picture of that company’s obligations or income in the immediate future, which may be significant.

EXAMPLE

Example. On December 31, 2018, the last day of its annual accounting period, the Samarkand Life Insurance Company purchased $50,000 of office equipment on account from the Maxis Office Equipment Company. Maxis delivered the equipment to Samarkand on the same day. Samarkand remitted payment in full on January 10, 2019. Below are the accounting entries for this transaction under cash-basis accounting and accrual-basis accounting.

Under cash-basis accounting, Samarkand would record the following transaction on January 10, 2019.

Office Equipment…………………………..……..….$50,000

Cash………………………………………………….…..$50,000

Under accrual-basis accounting, Samarkand would record the following transactions on December 31, 2018, and January 10, 2019, respectively:

Office Equipment………………………….……..….$50,000

Accounts Payable…………………………………..$50,000

Accounts Payable…………………………………..$50,000

Cash……………………………………………………..$50,000

Because cash-basis accounting does not apply the realization principle or the matching principle, the resulting financial statements can be misleading. For example, under cash-basis accounting, Samarkand’s balance sheet of December 31, 2018, would not show that the balance in Samarkand’s Office Equipment account has increased by $50,000, nor would it show that Samarkand owes Maxis $50,000 for the new office equipment. However, this transaction may be material to Samarkand’s potential policyowners or investors. In contrast, under accrual-basis accounting, Samarkand’s balance sheet would show the financial effect of this pending business transaction.

Historically, life insurance companies in the United States accounted for their financial transactions by making adjusting entries from cash-basis accounting to accrual-basis accounting for some accounts on the financial statements. Today, accounting software makes it much easier for insurers to maintain their accounting records simultaneously on both a cash basis and an accrual basis.

Predictive quality has five primary characteristics:

pages.title: Financial Statements
pages.contents:
Financial Statements

Recall that financial statements are summary reports of a company’s financial condition on a specified date or of its performance over a specified period. The preparation of financial statements is the end product of financial accounting, which we discussed in Chapter 1.

An insurer’s financial statements must contain enough information for users—both internal and external—to gain a general understanding of the insurer’s financial condition, activities, and prospects for growth. Figure 4.1 presents examples of users of an insurance company’s financial statements.

Financial statements follow a general protocol to make them easy to read, interpret, and compare. The heading of each financial statement generally contains the (1) name of the company, (2) name of the financial statement, (3) specified date or accounting (reporting) period covered by the financial statement, and (4) denomination used in reporting the financial information. Companies usually round off the reported monetary amounts to the nearest thousand or million. In addition to these general conventions, each type of financial statement has a specific format that is best suited to the kinds of financial information contained in that statement.

The following sections discuss a company’s key financial statements: the balance sheet, the income statement, the cash flow statement, and the statement of owners’ equity. Our focus is on the GAAP financial statements that an insurer includes in its Annual Report.

 

Balance Sheet

Recall that a balance sheet is a financial statement that shows a company’s financial condition or position by summarizing the company’s assets, liabilities, and owners’ equity as of a specified date. Typically that date is the last day of the accounting period, such as March 31, June 30, September 30, or December 31. A company’s balance sheet is considered to be a static report because it provides a snapshot of the company’s financial position as of a specified date.

On their GAAP balance sheets, most U.S. insurers present their assets in accordance with SEC regulations, which state that investments are listed first, followed by cash and other assets. The financial report below is an example of an insurer’s GAAP balance sheet.

Note that, because Steadfast is a stock insurer, its owners’ equity is referred to as stockholders’ equity.

Recall that, according to the basic accounting equation, the monetary amount of an insurer’s total assets must equal the combined monetary amounts of its total liabilities and owners’ equity. In other words, the two amounts must balance, giving this financial statement its name. Looking back at Steadfast’s balance sheet, we see that its total assets do equal its total liabilities and stockholders’ equity: both amounts are $251,846,000.

The balance sheet shows a user what a life insurer owns (its assets), what it owes (its liabilities), and what it has retained (its owners’ equity). A user can also determine whether an insurer is solvent by examining its balance sheet. Remember that, to be considered solvent, a life insurer must have an amount of assets that exceeds the amount of its liabilities. Steadfast is solvent, because its total assets of $251,846,000 exceed its total liabilities of $238,229,000.

 

Income Statement

As we’ve discussed, an income statement is a financial statement that reports an insurer’s revenues and expenses during a specified accounting period and indicates whether the insurer experienced net income or a net loss during the accounting period. The income statement is considered to be a dynamic report because it presents the flow of a company’s financial transactions during a specified accounting period, rather than as of a specified date.

The income statement shows a user whether a life insurer is profitable: Is it earning net income or incurring a net loss? Remember that, for a specific accounting period, an insurer experiences (1) net income when its revenues exceed its expenses, and (2) a net loss when its expenses exceed its revenues. Users also examine this statement to identify how an insurer is earning funds (its revenues), as well as how it is spending them (its expenses).

Statement of Comprehensive Income

Investments play a critical role in the operations of life insurers, and life insurers can have substantial capital gains and losses on those investments. These capital gains and losses can be categorized as either realized or unrealized:

  • A realized capital gain (loss) generally results from the actual sale of an asset.

  • An unrealized capital gain (loss) generally occurs while the insurer is still holding the asset; in other words, an unrealized capital gain or loss does not result from the sale of an asset.

Realized capital gains and losses on invested assets must be reported on an insurer’s GAAP income statement. According to the FASB, a life insurer has two options for reporting unrealized capital gains and losses on its invested assets: (1) in its income statement or (2) in a separate statement of comprehensive income, which immediately follows the insurer’s income statement.

The statement of comprehensive income presents a company’s comprehensive income for a given reporting period. Comprehensive income (CI) is the total change in equity for a reporting period, excluding changes resulting from investments by owners and distributions to owners. In other words, CI measures the changes in equity that result from non-owner transactions. Comprehensive income is the sum of net income and other items—known as other comprehensive income (OCI)—that are not reported on the income statement because they have not been realized.

In equation format, we have:

CI = Net income + OCI

Examples of OCI include

  • Unrealized capital gains and losses on certain investments, which we discuss in detail in the next chapter

  • Gains and losses resulting from translating the financial statements of foreign subsidiaries

  • Actuarial gains and losses related to pensions and other postretirement benefits

Because OCI is not reported on an insurer’s income statement, it is not included in the calculation of the insurer’s net income. Why is OCI excluded from an insurer’s net income? The components of OCI generally come from noncore business operations and onetime or unusual transactions. If these components were added to net income, the resulting figure could present an inaccurate view of the company’s operating performance.

To prevent this result, OCI accumulates on the statement of owners’ equity in a section called “accumulated other comprehensive income” or “AOCI.” We discuss the statement of owners’ equity later in this chapter. The balance of AOCI is also presented in the owners’ equity section of the balance sheet.

Our fictional company, Steadfast, includes the following statement of comprehensive income after its income statement:

Steadfast Life Insurance Company

Statement of Comprehensive Income

for the year ended December 31, 2018

As you can see, the statement first includes Steadfast’s net income; then it lists the various components of OCI, which are added to net income to arrive at CI. The calculation is as follows:

CI = Net income + OCI

CI = $1,154,000 + $(2,251,000)

CI = $(1,097,000)

 

Cash Flow Statement

A cash flow statement, also called a statement of cash flows, is a financial statement that shows a company’s cash receipts, cash disbursements, and the net change in cash during a specified accounting period. It provides information about a company’s change in cash between the company’s current balance sheet and previous balance sheet. Like the income statement, the cash flow statement is a dynamic report.

The primary purpose of a cash flow statement is to demonstrate how a company manages its cash over time. Like all companies, insurance companies need to ensure that they have enough cash available to pay expenses. An insurer’s balance sheet may reveal billions in assets, but a portion of those assets need to be in cash. Otherwise, an insurer could be forced to sell assets for less than they are worth to pay its expenses. On the other hand, an insurer that holds too much idle cash could be missing out on investment opportunities. Therefore, managing cash effectively is one of an insurer’s most important tasks.

Cash Inflows and Cash Outflows

A cash flow is any movement of cash into or out of an organization; cash flows may either be sources of funds or uses of funds for the organization. In the context of accounting,

  • A cash inflow is a movement of cash into an organization; cash inflows are sources of funds. Cash inflows include cash receipts, or money received by an insurer—from premium income, investment income, and fee income, for example.

  • A cash outflow is a movement of cash out of an organization; cash outflows are uses of funds. Cash outflows include cash disbursements, or money that the insurer has paid for policy benefits, expenses associated with investment purchases, ongoing business expenses, and so on.

Changes in an insurer’s cash flows occur as a result of three activities, as presented in the chart below.

Type of Activity

Transactions Resulting in Cash Inflows

Transactions Resulting in Cash Outflows

Operating activities

 

Transactions that involve a company’s core business operations and that directly determine the company’s net income

 

  • Premiums paid by customers

  • Receipt of interest and dividends

  • Fee income and other revenue

  • Receipts from reinsurance claims

 

  • Contractual benefit payments to policyowners and beneficiaries

  • Payments to employees and suppliers

  • Payment of taxes

Investing activities

 

Transactions that involve a company’s purchase or sale of long-term assets and the lending of funds to other companies

 

  • Sales of bonds, mortgages, stocks, property, buildings, and other long-term assets

  • Receipt of principal on loan repayments

 

  • Purchases of bonds, mortgages, stocks, property, buildings, and other long-term assets

  • Disbursements of loans to borrowers

Financing activities

 

Transactions that involve borrowed funds and cash payments to or from a company’s owners*

 

*Note that a company’s investing activities involve the securities of other companies, whereas financing activities involve the company’s own securities.

 

  • Common stock issue and sale

  • Bond (or note) issue and sale

  • Receipt of loan proceeds from creditor

 

  • Payments of cash dividends to stockholders

  • Payment of principal on debt securities such as bonds, loans, and notes

If the cash inflows exceed the cash outflows for an activity, then the result for that activity is a net cash inflow. Conversely, if the cash outflows exceed the cash inflows, then the result is a net cash outflow. For an accounting period, the net cash inflow (outflow), which is the difference between cash inflows and cash outflows, represents the net change in cash—that is, the increase or decrease in cash.

Theoretically, a company’s net change in cash equals the difference between the amount of cash and cash equivalents as shown on any two consecutive balance sheets, such as the company’s current and previous balance sheet. You can calculate a company’s net cash flow during a specified period by subtracting the company’s cash outflows from its cash inflows. You can also determine net cash flow by subtracting the company’s uses of funds from its sources of funds.

Net cash inflow (Net cash outflow) = Cash inflows – Cash outflows

OR

Net cash inflow (Net cash outflow) = Sources of funds – Uses of funds

On a typical cash flow statement for a life insurer, you won’t see the terms cash inflow (from cash receipts), cash outflow (from cash disbursements), or net cash inflow/outflow. Instead,

  • Cash inflow is represented by a positive amount

  • Cash outflow is represented by an amount in parentheses—that is, a negative amount

For example, looking back at Steadfast’s cash flow statement, under Cash Flows from Operating Activities, Steadfast had a “Change in premiums and fees receivable” of 97, representing a cash inflow of $97,000. In contrast, Steadfast had a “Change in accrued investment income” of (21), representing a cash outflow of $21,000. In addition, for the three types of activities—operating, investing, and financing—the summary line for each generally uses the phrase “net cash” rather than “net cash inflow” or “net cash outflow.” Again, whether the amount is an inflow or outflow is indicated by a positive number (no parentheses) or a negative number (in parentheses).

Statement of Owners’ Equity

The statement of owners’ equity, also known as the statement of changes in owners’ equity, is a financial statement that provides information about changes in owners’ equity accounts between two sequential balance sheets. Stock insurers typically refer to the statement of owners’ equity as either the statement of stockholders’ equity or the statement of changes in stockholders’ equity. Like the income statement and cash flow statement, the statement of owners’ equity is considered to be a dynamic report.

For a stock insurer, events that cause its stockholders’ equity accounts to change include

  • Issuing stock

  • Purchasing treasury stock

  • Retaining net income

  • Paying cash dividends on stock

  • Accumulating other comprehensive income

Mutual insurers and fraternal insurers often prepare a statement of policyowners’ equity or statement of policyholders’ equity for their customers. Because these companies do not issue common stock, mutual insurers and fraternal insurers typically experience changes in owners’ equity only as a result of changes in net income and surplus. Financial Statement Integration

In the context of financial statements, one phrase you might read or hear is financial statement integration. This phrase simply means that a company’s financial statements are interrelated.

First of all, for a given accounting period, the income statement is linked to the balance sheet, because changes in the accounts on an insurer’s income statement ultimately affect accounts on the insurer’s balance sheet. For example, in general, an increase in an insurer’s revenues (income statement) ultimately results in an increase in the insurer’s assets (balance sheet).

EXAMPLE

Example. When an insurer receives investment income or a premium from a policyowner, these transactions ultimately increase not only the insurer’s revenues (income statement), but also its cash (balance sheet).

Conversely, in general, an increase in an insurer’s expenses (income statement) ultimately results in a decrease in the insurer’s assets (balance sheet).

EXAMPLE

Example. When an insurer pays contractual benefits or agent commissions, these transactions ultimately increase the insurer’s expenses (income statement) but decrease its cash (balance sheet).

pages.title: Financial Reports
pages.contents:
Financial Reports

A U.S. insurance company includes its financial statements in a variety of reports, the most important of which are its Annual Report and its Annual Statement. Recall that the Annual Report is a GAAP financial report, whereas the Annual Statement is a statutory financial report. The following sections discuss these two key financial reports, along with related reports.

 

Annual Report

As we’ve discussed, an Annual Report is a document that a company’s management sends to interested parties to explain the company’s financial performance during the past year. Think of a company’s Annual Report as a report card; investors, regulators, potential customers, and others use the information in this report to judge the company’s performance. For insurers, the Annual Report is an opportunity to advertise its products and services to customers, and, if the company is a stock insurer, promote its stock to investors.

In the United States, all publicly traded companies, including stock insurers, must publish an Annual Report for their stockholders. In addition, mutual insurers and fraternal insurers that offer variable products are required to publish an Annual Report for their policyowners. These days, most Annual Reports are electronic documents that individuals can access through a company’s website.

A stock insurer’s Annual Report usually includes the following information:

  • A letter to stockholders. Generally, the letter comes from the company’s president or chief executive officer (CEO) and describes the company’s performance over the past year, emphasizing particular successes and examining possible areas in need of improvement.

  • A description of financial highlights for the year. The letter is typically followed by a table of financial highlights that summarizes the company’s financial achievements during the previous five to 10 years. This section usually includes graphs or charts designed to illustrate trends, such as growth in the company’s net income or product revenues.

  • An independent auditor’s report. This report is a statement by an independent public accountant who has audited the financial information contained in the Annual Report. In this report, the auditor attests that the information fairly represents the operations of the company in accordance with GAAP. An auditor does not, however, issue an opinion on the accuracy of the information in the company’s financial statements.

  • The audited financial statements—the balance sheet, income statement, cash flow statement, and statement of owners’ equity. The balance sheet must show data covering the past two years, whereas the other financial statements must show data for the past three years.

  • Notes to the financial statements and supplementary information. Accompanying or immediately following the financial statements are the notes to the financial statements, which are factual in nature and disclose the details behind some of the amounts presented in the financial statements. For example, one typical note explains the accounting policies that the company followed in preparing its financial statements.

  • Management discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations (MD&A). The MD&A is in narrative form and presents an analysis and interpretation of the company’s financial statements and company performance from management’s point of view. For example, during a period of low interest rates, management might explain why the company’s interest-sensitive products and investments did not perform as well as expected.

In the United States, insurers that are required to publish an Annual Report must also file the following reports with the SEC:

  • The Form 10-K is an SEC-required version of the Annual Report. To eliminate the need to create two separate reports, many insurers include in their Annual Reports all the information that the SEC requires for the Form 10-K.

  • The Form 10-Q is a quarterly report designed to keep the SEC and investors apprised of the company’s performance and condition during the year. The Form 10-Q differs from the Form 10-K in several ways. For example, the financial statements in the Form 10-K must be audited, whereas those in the Form 10-Q do not have to be audited. In addition, whereas the Form 10-K must include complete financial statements, the Form 10-Q can contain condensed versions of the financial statements.

  • The Form 8-K discloses any material event not previously reported that is important to investors. Examples of material events reported in the Form 8-K include mergers, acquisitions, and a change in auditors.

Figure 4.2 compares the Form 10-K and the Form 10-Q.

 

Annual Statement

As described earlier, the Annual Statement is a financial report that every insurer in the United States must file annually with the NAIC and the insurance regulatory organization in each state in which the insurer conducts business. The Annual Statement contains data that authorities need to evaluate a company’s solvency and compliance with insurance regulations. The Annual Statement filing for life insurance companies—which can contain more than 200 pages of financial statements, supporting schedules, and exhibits—is sometimes called the blank or the blue book.

The NAIC and most state insurance departments require insurers to file the Annual Statement electronically. Although regulators are the primary audience for the Annual Statement, other users include rating agencies, investment analysts, and a company’s managers. For example, managers frequently use Annual Statement data to compare their company’s performance to that of other companies.

In addition to the Annual Statement, life insurers must file a Quarterly Statement with the NAIC and the insurance regulatory organization in each state in which they conduct business. Although the Quarterly Statement contains a company’s complete financial statements, overall it is a much shorter report, containing fewer exhibits and schedules than the Annual Statement.

In this discussion, we focus primarily on the financial statements included in the Annual Statement. Note, however, that the Annual Statement contains many other sections, some of which are comparable to those found in the Annual Report, such as a Five-Year Historical Data exhibit, Notes to the Financial Statements, and an MD&A.

The beginning of the Annual Statement features separate pages titled

  • Assets

  • Liabilities, Surplus and Other Funds

  • Summary of Operations

  • Cash Flow

The first two pages on this list—Assets and Liabilities, Surplus and Other Funds—comprise the insurer’s statutory balance sheet. The Summary of Operations page, which shows an insurer’s net income, is the statutory version of the GAAP income statement. The Summary of Operations page also includes a section highlighting the changes in the company’s capital and surplus accounts; this section functions as the statutory counterpart to the GAAP statement of owners’ equity. Finally, Cash Flow is the statutory version of the GAAP cash flow statement. Each of these statutory financial statements contains data for the current year and the previous year.

Figure 4.3 compares the financial statements included in a life insurer’s Annual Report (GAAP) and its Annual Statement (SAP).

In upcoming chapters, we present more detail on how insurance accounting differs depending on whether the reporting basis is GAAP or SAP.

Beginning with this chapter, we discuss financial accounting, which focuses primarily on the external uses of an insurer’s financial information. We use the five major account classifications—assets, liabilities, owners’ equity, revenues, and expenses—to show key concepts and practices related to financial accounting and reporting in life insurance companies. pages.title: Asset Valuation
pages.contents:
Asset Valuation

For financial reporting purposes, life insurers must be able to assign a value to everything they own, everything they owe, and everything they have retained. Valuation is the process of calculating the monetary value of an insurer’s assets, liabilities, and owners’ equity for accounting and financial reporting purposes. Here our focus is on the valuation of an insurer’s assets.

Insurers use several methods of valuing assets. The asset valuation method used depends on a number of factors, including regulatory requirements, the type of asset, and the purpose for holding the asset.

Insurance regulators typically specify the valuation methods insurers must use for different types of assets. To comply with statutory reporting requirements, life insurers that conduct business in the United States value their assets under the guidance of the NAIC Accounting Practices & Procedures Manual and the Purposes and Procedures Manual of the NAIC Investment Analysis Office. The following sections discuss common valuation methods based on cost and those based on fair value.

 

Valuation Methods Based on Cost

Recall that an asset’s historical cost is the price originally paid for the asset. Historical cost is a simple asset valuation method because nearly all assets have a readily determinable historical cost. On the date of purchase, an asset’s historical cost equals its book value. As we’ve discussed, the book value of an asset is the value at which a company records the asset in its accounting records and reports the asset on its balance sheet.

Here, we are concerned with the effects of amortization and depreciation on an asset’s book value after the date of purchase. Amortization, which typically applies to certain long-term assets such as bonds and mortgages, is the periodic and systematic increase or decrease of the original cost of an investment to its ultimate value at maturity. An asset’s amortized cost is the asset’s book value after its cost has been adjusted for applicable amortization. We earlier defined depreciation, which typically applies to long-term fixed assets such as buildings and other real estate, as the allocation (spreading) of the cost of an asset over the asset’s estimated useful life. An asset’s depreciated cost is the asset’s book value after applicable depreciation has been deducted from its cost. The total amount of depreciation allocated to an asset as of a specified date is called accumulated depreciation.

EXAMPLE

Example. The Flotilla Life Insurance Company purchased a building five years ago for $500,000. Depreciation expense on the building is $10,000 per year.

Analysis. The building’s historical cost is $500,000. The accumulated depreciation on the building is $50,000, calculated as 5 years × $10,000 of depreciation expense per year. The building’s depreciated cost, which is now its book value, is $450,000, calculated as $500,000 – (5 × $10,000).

 

Valuation Methods Based on Fair Value

Although valuation methods based on cost are relatively easy to understand and to uncover, an asset’s cost may have little relevance to the asset’s value today or in the future. For example, an insurer that purchased the common stock of a successful company 10 years ago would be unlikely to buy, hold, or sell that stock today based on the original cost of the stock. In this case, the fair value of the stock would be more relevant.

Fair value is the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants on the valuation date. Quoted market prices in active markets are usually the best evidence of fair value. The fair value of most assets fluctuates over time and may vary considerably from both the historical cost and amortized cost.

A fair market for the purchase and sale of assets is critical to the concept of fair value accounting and to the value associated with each asset. Fair value accountingis the process of valuing a company’s balance sheet accounts, including assets, on the price that the asset would bring in an active, organized market in which (1) the asset sale is not the result of liquidation, and (2) neither the buyer nor the seller is forced to enter the transaction. The purpose of fair value accounting is to provide transparent, validated information about the values for a company’s balance sheet accounts.

Insurers sometimes have difficulty assigning an objective value to assets that are not actively traded. Instead, such assets might be assigned a value based on internal management projections or other subjective valuation methods. In valuing assets that are not actively traded, U.S. life insurers also consult various resources provided by the NAIC. For example, the NAIC has a department—the Securities Valuation Office (SVO)—that is responsible for the ongoing credit quality assessment and valuation of securities owned by state-regulated insurance companies. The NAIC also offers an Automated Valuation Service (AVS), which provides access to the Valuation of Securities (VOS) database, from which an insurer can quickly price its securities for the Annual Statement.

 

Realized and Unrealized Capital Gains and Losses

Recall from Chapter 4 that realized and unrealized capital gains and losses on an insurer’s invested assets can have a significant impact on its financial condition. Calculations of these capital gains and losses generally differ, depending on whether the invested asset is a debt security or an equity security and whether the accounting basis is SAP or GAAP.

According to SAP, for debt securities in general,

  • A realized capital gain (loss) on a debt security is the difference between the debt security’s net sales proceeds and its book value. For an asset, the net sales proceeds equal the gross sales proceeds, or selling price, minus any sales commissions and other costs associated with the sale of the asset. If the net sales proceeds from the debt security are greater than its book value, then the result is a realized capital gain; if the net sales proceeds are less than the debt security’s book value, then the result is a realized capital loss.

Net sales proceeds ˃ Book value = Realized capital gain on debt security
Net sales proceeds ˂ Book value = Realized capital loss on debt security

  • An unrealized capital gain (loss) on a debt security is the difference between the debt security’s fair value and its book value. If the fair value of the debt security is greater than its book value, then the result is an unrealized capital gain; if the fair value is less than the debt security’s book value, then the result is an unrealized capital loss.

Fair value ˃ Book value = Unrealized capital gain on debt security
Fair value < Book value = Unrealized capital loss on debt security

EXAMPLE

Example. The Stardust Life Insurance Company owns a bond that has an amortized cost, or book value, of $50,000. The fair value of this bond is $46,000.

Analysis. Under SAP, the fair value of this bond is less than its book value, resulting in an unrealized capital loss of $4,000, calculated as $46,000 – $50,000.

According to GAAP, for debt securities in general,

  • A realized capital gain (loss) on a debt security is the difference between the debt security’s net sales proceeds and its amortized cost. If the net sales proceeds from the debt security are greater than its amortized cost, then the result is a realized capital gain; if the net sales proceeds are less than the debt security’s amortized cost, then the result is a realized capital loss.

Net sales proceeds ˃ Amortized cost = Realized capital gain on debt security
Net sales proceeds ˂ Amortized cost = Realized capital loss on debt security

  • An unrealized capital gain (loss) on a debt security is the difference between the fair value of the debt security and its amortized cost. If the fair value of a debt security is greater than its amortized cost, then the result is an unrealized capital gain; if the fair value is less than the debt security’s amortized cost, then the result is an unrealized capital loss.

Fair value ˃ Amortized cost = Unrealized capital gain on debt security
Fair value < Amortized cost = Unrealized capital loss on debt security

EXAMPLE

Example. Note that our previous example results in the same values under GAAP, because Stardust’s bond has an amortized cost of $50,000, whereas its fair value is $46,000.

Analysis. Under GAAP, the fair value of this bond is less than its amortized cost, resulting in an unrealized capital loss of $4,000, calculated as $46,000 – $50,000.

Under GAAP and SAP, realized and unrealized capital gains on equity securities are generally calculated the same way:

  • A realized capital gain (loss) on an equity security is the difference between the equity security’s net sales proceeds and its historical cost. If the net sales proceeds from the equity security are greater than its historical cost, then the result is a realized capital gain; if the net sales proceeds are less than the equity security’s historical cost, then the result is a realized capital loss.

Net sales proceeds ˃ Historical cost = Realized capital gain on equity security
Net sales proceeds < Historical cost = Realized capital loss on equity security

EXAMPLE

Example. Stardust decided to sell 50 shares of stock that it owned in the Wavelength Corporation. The historical cost of the stock was $10 per share. When Stardust sold the stock, the net sales proceeds were $30 per share.

Analysis. Under SAP and GAAP, the realized capital gain on the Wavelength stock was equal to $1,000, calculated as (50 × $30) – (50 × $10).

  • An unrealized capital gain (loss) on an equity security is the difference between the equity security’s fair value and its historical cost. If the fair value of the equity security is greater than its historical cost, then the result is an unrealized capital gain; if the fair value is less than the equity security’s historical cost, then the result is an unrealized capital loss.

Fair value ˃ Historical cost = Unrealized capital gain on equity security
Fair value < Historical cost = Unrealized capital loss on equity security

EXAMPLE

Example. Stardust owns 100 shares of stock in the Briar Corporation. The historical cost of the stock is $50 per share. At the current time, the stock’s fair value is $20 per share.

Analysis. Under SAP and GAAP, the unrealized capital loss on the Briar stock is equal to $3,000, calculated as (100 × $20) – (100 × $50).

Impaired Assets

Insurers must continually assess the fair market value of each asset purchased relative to its cost. When the fair market value of an asset is less than its cost, the insurer must determine whether this decline is temporary. When the decline in the fair market value is not temporary, the insurer typically classifies the asset as other-than-temporarily impaired (OTTI), and writes down the value of the asset to its fair market value. A write-down is a permanent adjustment in the book value of an asset whose fair market value is deemed to be OTTI.

The loss on an OTTI asset that an insurer still owns is considered a realized capital loss rather than an unrealized capital loss because the asset’s book value has been permanently adjusted. Once an asset has been written down as a realized capital loss, it cannot be written back up, even if the asset recovers its market value.

pages.contents:
Admitted Assets and Nonadmitted Assets

As we described earlier in the text, assets can be assigned to various classifications—such as tangible versus intangible and short-term versus long-term. To comply with statutory reporting requirements, U.S. life insurers also must classify their assets as either admitted assets or nonadmitted assets on the Annual Statement, usually based on their liquidity:

  • Admitted assets are assets whose full value is reported on the Assets page of the Annual Statement. Examples of admitted assets are cash, cash equivalents, and most invested assets.

  • Nonadmitted assets are assets that are reported on the Assets page of the Annual Statement but are accorded no value. Most nonadmitted assets are used in the normal process of doing business, such as office furniture and equipment. Some assets are partially nonadmitted, which means that only a portion of their value is reported on the Assets page of the Annual Statement. One example of a partially nonadmitted asset is deferred tax assets.

The purpose of these classifications is to enable regulators to identify which of an insurer’s assets possess adequate liquidity. Recall that a liquid asset is one that can be readily converted to cash at an approximation of its underlying value. Liquid assets are crucial in enabling an insurer to satisfy its contractual obligations. In other words, admitted assets are assets whose values are “admitted” on the Annual Statement because they can easily be converted to cash—without a loss in value—to pay for an insurer’s obligations, whereas nonadmitted assets are assets whose value is “not admitted” because they do not possess this quality. By not allowing an insurer to report a value (or a full value) for a nonliquid asset, statutory regulators enforce the concept of conservatism, as discussed earlier in this text.

The excerpt below illustrates the treatment of admitted and nonadmitted assets on the Assets page of the Annual Statement:

Note that an insurer’s net admitted assets are found by subtracting nonadmitted assets from assets:

Net admitted assets = Assets – Nonadmitted assets

  • Cash is an admitted asset, so the full amount—$168,314,225—is shown as a net admitted asset. (Technically, the calculation is $168,314,225 – $0 = $168,314,225.)

  • Furniture and equipment is a nonadmitted asset, so its full value is “netted out,” as in $3,988,142 – $3,988,142 = $0, leaving no value in the net admitted assets column.

Figure 5.1 lists some typical admitted and nonadmitted assets for life insurers.We discuss many of these assets in this and the next chapter.

Note that the admitted and nonadmitted asset classifications are only relevant for statutory reporting purposes; under GAAP accounting, an insurer includes values for all of its assets in its financial statements. Because of this difference, the asset amounts in an insurer’s Annual Report rarely equal those shown on the Assets page of the insurer’s Annual Statement.

pages.title: Accounting for Asset Transactions
pages.contents:
Accounting for Asset Transactions

Now we are ready to look at how insurance companies account for asset transactions. A company records the purchase of an asset by debiting an asset account and crediting another asset account, a liability account, an owners' equity account, or a combination, based on how the company pays for the asset. In most cases, the purchase of an asset affects another asset account, such as Cash, or a liability account, such as Accounts Payable, Notes Payable, or Mortgages Payable.

Similarly, the company records the sale of an asset by crediting the asset account and debiting another asset account, liability account, owners’ equity account, or a combination, according to how the company receives payment for the asset. Most asset sales affect another asset account—such as Accounts Receivable, Notes Receivable, or Mortgages Receivable—rather than an owners’ equity account.

The insight below presents several sample accounting entries to record the purchase and sale of an asset. Keep these general transactions in mind as we discuss how the terms of asset purchases and sales affect an insurer’s various accounts and, ultimately, the insurer’s financial condition.

INSIGHT

Accounting Entries for the Purchase and Sale of an Asset

In the following examples, we ignore the effects of transaction costs, such as brokerage commissions.

ASSET PURCHASES

 

When an insurer records the purchase of an asset, the accounting entry used depends on whether the purchase was for cash, on account, or on account with a cash down payment.

Assume that the insurer purchases Asset A for cash.

The appropriate accounting entry would be

Asset A……………..$$$

Cash…………………..$$$

To record the purchase of Asset A for cash.

The purchase of Asset A increased the value of the insurer’s Asset A account by the value of the purchased asset, and decreased the insurer’s Cash—another asset account—by the same amount. Note that this transaction does not change the insurer’s total assets, nor does it affect any of the insurer’s liability accounts or owners’ equity accounts.

Now assume that the insurer purchases Asset A on account.

The appropriate accounting entry would be

Asset A…………………………...…..$$$

Accounts Payable—Asset A……………..$$$

To record the purchase of Asset A on account.

In this transaction, the insurer incurs a liability—the Accounts Payable—that the insurer promises to pay the seller in the future. Recall that a liability account has a normal credit balance, so a credit is used to record an increase in the value of this liability. Here, the insurer’s total assets increased by the value of the purchased asset and the insurer’s total liabilities increased by the same amount because of the increase in Accounts Payable—Asset A.

Now assume that the insurer purchases Asset A by making a cash down payment and incurring the remaining amount as a liability to be paid in the future.

The appropriate accounting entry would be

Asset A………………………..$$$

Cash………………………………….......$

Accounts Payable—Asset A……..$$

To record the purchase of Asset A on account with a cash down payment.

Recall that each accounting entry must have an equal monetary value for its debits and credits. So, in this transaction, the sum of the debits—the monetary amount assigned to the Asset A account—must equal the sum of the credits—Cash plus Accounts Payable—Asset A.

ASSET SALES

 

When an insurer records the sale of an asset, the accounting entry used depends on whether the sale was for cash, on account, or on account with a cash down payment.

Assume that the insurer sells Asset A for cash.

The appropriate accounting entry would be

Cash..……………..$$$

Asset A……………..$$$

To record the sale of Asset A for cash.

Note that the accounting entry used to record the sale of an asset for cash is the opposite of the entry made when purchasing the asset for cash, assuming there is no gain or loss.

Now assume that the insurer sells Asset A on account.

The appropriate accounting entry would be

Accounts Receivable—Asset A……………………..$$$

Asset A……………..…………….…………………………..$$$

To record the sale of Asset A on account.

In this transaction, the insurer sold Asset A and, instead of cash, received an asset referred to as Accounts Receivable—Asset A. This account receivable is a contractual promise made by the purchaser of Asset A to the insurer, the seller of Asset A, to pay for the asset in the future. Accounts receivable are considered to be assets for the insurer, provided the purchaser pays the insurer for Asset A in the agreed-upon time.

Now assume that the insurer sells Asset A on account, with a cash down payment.

The appropriate accounting entry would be

Cash……………………………….……….....$

Accounts Receivable—Asset A……..$$

Asset A………………………..$$$

To record the sale of Asset A on account, with a cash down payment.

In this transaction, the insurer is the holder, or owner, of the receivable. As in the previous example, the receivable is considered an asset, provided the purchaser pays the insurer for Asset A in the agreed-upon time.

Accounts Receivable—Asset A……………………..$100,000

Asset A……………..…………….……………………..$100,000

pages.title: Investment Accounting
pages.contents:
Investment Accounting

When life insurance companies sell their products, they receive premiums from customers in return for promising to provide future benefits in specified circumstances. To ensure their ability to meet these benefit obligations as they come due, life insurers take part of these premium payments and invest them. Investing refers to employing a principal sum of money to generate earnings. In a financial sense, investing usually involves using a sum of money to (1) purchase assets or (2) deposit funds into a financial institution. Typical examples of an insurer’s investments, or invested assets, are bonds, mortgages, and stock.

Investment accounting is the area of accounting that is responsible for recording all accounting entries related to the invested assets held in an insurer’s investment portfolios. In this context, an investment portfolio is a collection of various investments owned by the same organization, usually assembled to meet a defined set of financial goals.

The invested assets in a portfolio can be further classified as securities. For insurance companies, important examples of securities are debt securities, equity securities, hybrid securities, and derivative securities.

  • A debt security is an obligation of indebtedness owed by a business, a government, or an agency. Important examples of debt securities for life insurers are bonds and mortgages issued by other companies or entities. Debt securities represent loans made by the purchaser of the security to the issuer of the security.

  • An equity security is an ownership interest in a business. The most important equity security for life insurers is common stock. By purchasing the common stock of another company, the insurer hopes to receive (1) income in the form of cash dividends and (2) growth in the value of that stock upon its eventual sale.

  • A hybrid security has characteristics of debt and equity securities. Hybrid securities are becoming more common in insurance company portfolios because they often combine the best features of debt securities and equity securities. Preferred stock is an example of a hybrid security.

  • A derivative security derives its value from other securities. Types of derivatives that are important to insurers are options, forward contracts, futures contracts, and swaps.

Life insurance companies hold a much greater monetary share of their assets in debt securities than in equity securities. Insurers prefer debt securities in part because their investment risk is generally lower than that of equity securities. Equally important to insurers, however, are the characteristics of debt securities—their fixed maturity dates and fixed interest-payment schedules. These characteristics ensure that adequate funds are available to insurers when needed to pay contractual obligations. Of the debt securities held by life insurance companies, bonds are the clear industry favorite, as illustrated in Figure 5.2.

 

Bonds

A bond is a debt security that a bond issuer, typically a corporation or government entity, sells to raise money. The purchaser of a bond, or owner of a bond, is known as the bondholder. In return for the purchase price of the bond, the bondholder typically receives from the bond issuer

  • Periodic interest payments, known as coupon payments, usually on a semiannual basis—every six months—in the United States. The interest rate specified on a bond is called the coupon rate, also known as the stated rate. A bond’s coupon rate is a percentage of its par value, which we discuss below.

  • Payment of the bond’s par value by a specified maturity date. Typical maturities for bonds fall in the five-year to 30-year range. The par value of a bond is the designated legal monetary value assigned to the bond. Other terms used for par value are principal and face amount. When a bond issuer first sells a bond, the selling price is usually the bond’s par value, typically $1,000. Thereafter, the value of the bond fluctuates according to competitive market forces.

EXAMPLE

Example. The Kona Corporation recently issued bonds with a par value of $1,000, a maturity date of 10 years, and semiannual coupon payments at a 5% annual coupon rate. The Peaberry Insurance Company purchased 100 Kona bonds at a par value of $1,000 per bond. Peaberry plans to hold the Kona bonds until maturity.

Analysis. In this situation, the bond issuer is Kona, and the bondholder is Peaberry. Over the 10-year period of holding the Kona bonds, Peaberry will receive a coupon payment of $50 in interest per year, or $25 in interest twice per year, on each bond. On the maturity date of these bonds, Peaberry will receive the par value of $1,000 on each bond.

Figure 5.3 presents a simplified example of a bond certificate.

Bonds issued by corporations are called corporate bonds, whereas those issued by governments—including federal, state, provincial, county, city, and other local governments—are called government bonds. Although the largest proportion of an insurer’s bond investments are corporate bonds, insurers also invest a considerable amount of money in government bonds.

Insurers typically maintain detailed accounting records—including the purchase price, par value, coupon rate, coupon payment dates, name of the bond issuer, issue date, and maturity date—for each bond that they own. They also report summary information about their bond investments within their financial statements.

 

Bond Purchases, Sales, and Valuation

When an insurer purchases a bond, it typically records the bond’s value at the price that it paid for the bond, whether or not that amount matches the bond’s par value. An insurer may purchase a bond at a price that differs from the bond’s par value. An insurer may also sell a bond that it owns at a price that differs from the bond’s par value.

EXAMPLE

Example. The Lentyl Insurance Company purchased for $950 a $1,000 par value bond issued by the Yuletide Corporation.

Analysis. A typical entry that Lentyl would make to record this purchase is a debit of $950 to an asset account, such as Yuletide Bonds, and a credit of $950 to Cash. If, instead, Lentyl purchased the bond for $1,200, it would most likely record a debit to Yuletide Bonds for $1,200 and a credit of $1,200 to Cash.

For U.S. statutory reporting purposes, a bond’s statement value generally depends on its NAIC rating. The NAIC has six ratings for bonds. Bonds rated NAIC 1 to NAIC 5 are reported at amortized cost. For bonds that are rated NAIC 6—the designation for bonds “in or near default”—life insurers typically use a valuation method known as the lower-of-cost-or-market (LCM) rule. According to this rule, the statement value of a bond rated NAIC 6 is the lower of its amortized cost or fair value. The difference between the bond’s amortized cost and its fair value is generally an unrealized loss.

The following chart lists the NAIC ratings for bonds:

Balance Sheet Valuation of Bonds for Life and Fraternal Companies

Maintaining an Asset Valuation Reserve (AVR)

NAIC Designation

Statement Carrying Value

1: Highest quality

Amortized cost

2: High quality

Amortized cost

3: Medium quality

Amortized cost

4: Low quality

Amortized cost

5: Lowest quality

Amortized cost

6: In or near default

Lower of amortized cost or fair value

EXAMPLE

Example. The Azalea Life Insurance Company owns a bond that has an amortized cost, or book value, of $1 million. The fair value of this bond is $300,000. This bond has a rating of NAIC 6.

Analysis. For U.S. statutory reporting purposes, Azalea would record an unrealized loss of $700,000 and reduce the book value of this bond to $300,000.

 

Bond Interest

Recall that bond interest is typically paid on a semiannual basis. Let’s look at a simple example.

EXAMPLE

Example. An insurer is the bondholder of 5,000 bonds issued by the Triangle Corporation. Each bond has a $1,000 par value. The bonds pay an annual coupon rate of interest of 6%. In this situation, the insurer will receive $150,000 in interest income twice each year, calculated as follows: 5,000 bonds × $1,000 par value × (6% coupon rate ÷ 2 payments per year). In this case, the insurer would record its interest income as follows:

Cash……………………………150,000

Interest Income—Triangle Bonds…………..150,000

To record the receipt of semiannual bond interest income.

If an insurer buys a bond between coupon payment dates, accrued interest income for this bond was actually earned by the seller of the bond prior to the date of purchase. In the context of bond interest income, accrued income is the amount of interest that has been earned on a bond, but is not yet payable to the bondholder as of the financial reporting date. Typical financial reporting dates are month-end, quarter-end, and year-end. To compensate the seller for this lost interest, the bond’s purchase price must include an amount equal to the accrued interest income as of the date of purchase.

EXAMPLE

Example. An insurer purchases a $1,000 bond at par with a 7% coupon rate and semiannual payments—that is, two coupon payments per year of $35 each—with $20 accrued interest income as of the purchase date. The bond was issued by the Triangle Corporation.

The insurer’s purchase price is $1,020, calculated as follows:

$1,000 purchase price + $20 accrued income = $1,020

The insurer records the accrued interest as an asset—Investment Income Due and Accrued—as shown in the following accounting entry:

Triangle Bonds…………………………………………..…….…………1,000

Investment Income Due and Accrued—Bonds………………......20

Cash………………………………….………….…..…………….1,020

To record the purchase of Triangle bonds with accrued bond interest income.

The insurer expects to receive the full amount of the bond interest, $35 in our example, when the next semiannual interest payment is made. Upon receipt of the regularly scheduled semiannual interest payment, the insurer would record the following accounting entry:

Cash………………………………………..………..35

Investment Income Due and Accrued—Bonds…….20

Interest Income—Triangle Bonds…………………..…..15

To record accrued and received bond interest income.

Note that the insurer’s income statement would include only $15 of bond interest income because the bond seller earned the remaining $20 in interest income.

Keep in mind that Investment Income Due and Accrued is an asset account, whereas Bond Interest Income is a revenue account.

 

Bond Discounts and Bond Premiums

Changes in an existing bond’s price are generally inversely related to changes in market interest rates. This relationship can be illustrated as follows:

If market interest rates then the prices of existing bonds

If market interest rates then the prices of existing bonds

Because of the inverse relationship between market interest rates and bond prices, a bond’s purchase price often differs from its par value. Thus, a bond’s fair value—usually its current market value—does not necessarily equal the bond’s par value. In general, a bond will sell at a discount—that is, less than the par value—if market interest rates are higher than the bond’s coupon rate and will sell at a premium—that is, greater than the par value—if market interest rates are lower than the bond’s coupon rate. Video 5.2 reviews bond discounts and premiums.

Video 5.2 Bond Discounts and Premiums

Bond Discounts and Premiums
