Note that the annual amount of interest paid on a bond is based on the bond’s coupon rate and the par value of the bond, regardless of the actual price paid for the bond.

EXAMPLE

Example. The Cardamom Life Insurance Company purchased a $1,000 par value bond for $1,200. The bond has an annual coupon rate of 4%.

Analysis. The bond’s purchase price of $1,200 is not relevant in calculating the bond’s semiannual coupon payments. The semiannual coupon payments on this bond are calculated as the bond’s par value of $1,000, multiplied by 4% divided by 2: $1,000 × (0.04 ÷ 2) = $20.

If the purchase price differs from the bond’s par value, then the actual rate of return—known as the effective rate of return or effective yield—on the amount paid for the bond will differ from the coupon rate. To obtain the effective rate of return, divide the annual bond interest by the purchase price paid for the bond.

Bond effective rate of return = Annual bond interest
Purchase price

A bond purchased at par value will have an effective rate of return equal to the bond’s coupon rate. In general, the effective rate of return on a bond is higher than the coupon rate for a bond purchased at a discount and lower than the coupon rate for a bond purchased at a premium.

EXAMPLE

Example. Suppose an insurer purchases a 2%, $1,000 bond that matures in one year. The following calculations show the bond’s effective rate of return if the insurer purchases the bond at par value, at a premium, and at a discount:

$20 annual bond interest = 0.0200 = 2.0% (par value)
$1,000 bond purchase price
$20 annual bond interest = 0.0180 = 1.8% (premium above par)
$1,100 bond purchase price
$20 annual bond interest = 0.0250 = 2.5% (discount below par)
$800 bond purchase price

Let’s look at a more detailed example of a bond sale at a premium and at a discount.

EXAMPLE

Example. The Willow Corporation issued a $1,000 par value bond with a coupon rate of 5%. Suppose that the Castle Life Insurance Company purchased these 5% bonds at their $1,000 par value.

Now assume that market interest rates fall to 3%. Willow, as the bond issuer, is still obligated to pay interest at a rate of 5% to its bondholders, including Castle. In the current market, the Willow bonds earn Castle $50 per year; new bonds issued at par value would have a coupon rate of 3% and, therefore, would earn bondholders only $30 per year.

If Castle chose to sell these bonds in the current market, it could demand a bond price higher than $1,000—that is, a premium—because the Willow bond’s coupon rate is higher than the current market interest rate of 3%. A new purchaser of the Willow bonds would be willing to pay more than the par value to lock in the higher coupon rate.

The accounting entry to record Castle’s sale of the Willow bonds at a premium would most likely be

Cash…………………$$$

Willow Bonds……………………………..………….$$

Gain on Sale of Willow Bonds…………………..$

To record the sale of Willow bonds at a premium.

The amount of cash received equals the amount credited to the bonds sold plus the amount of the realized gain on the sale of the bonds. Note that, if Castle were to keep the bonds, rather than sell them, Castle would have an unrealized gain on these bonds.

Now assume that market interest rates rise to 8%. Castle, as the bondholder, faces a current market price on the Willow bonds that is lower than their par value. The 8% bonds would earn $80 a year in interest income, whereas the Willow bonds would earn Castle only $50 a year in interest income. A new purchaser of the Willow bonds would be unwilling to pay the par value of the bond because it could purchase new bonds that have a higher coupon rate.

In order to persuade a purchaser to buy the Willow bonds, Castle would need to sell the bonds at a price below par value—that is, at a discount. In this case, Castle would receive less than the $1,000 par value per bond sold.

If Castle were to sell the Willow bonds in this situation, Castle would have a realized loss on the bonds. Upon the sale of the bonds at a discount, Castle would most likely record the following accounting entry:

Cash……………................……………….$$

Loss on Sale of Willow Bonds…….....$

Willow Bonds………………………………$$$

To record the sale of Willow bonds at a discount.

The amount of cash received equals the amount credited to the bonds sold minus the amount debited to the realized loss on the sale of the bonds. Castle would have an unrealized loss on these bonds if it chose to retain the bonds instead of selling them.

 

Mortgages

A mortgage is a long-term loan secured by a pledge of specified real property. In this context, the insurer is usually the purchaser, not the issuer (seller), of the mortgage. Under GAAP and SAP, mortgages are generally reported at their outstanding principal balance or amortized cost (if acquired at a discount or a premium).

Insurers also invest in mortgages through mortgage-backed securities, in which holders of mortgages form a pool of mortgages and sell shares in the pool to investors. Mortgage-backed securities can be classified as either residential or commercial mortgage-backed securities:

  • A residential mortgage-backed security (RMBS) is a type of mortgage-backed security that is secured by a pool of residential mortgages.

  • A commercial mortgage-backed security (CMBS) is a type of mortgage-backed security that is secured by a pool of commercial mortgages.

For U.S. statutory accounting purposes, mortgage-backed securities are classified as bonds.

EXAMPLE

Example: The Trellis Life Insurance Company purchased $2.5 million of Syllable RMBSs. A typical accounting entry that Trellis most likely would make to record this transaction is

RMBSs—Syllable…………….2,500,000

Cash………………………………………..2,500,000

To record the purchase of Syllable RMBSs.

Mortgages and mortgage-backed securities appeal to insurers because these investments generally return a predictable stream of cash flows by providing (1) monthly debt repayment schedules and (2) a minimum, often fixed, rate of return.

Sometimes an insurer is the mortgage lender rather than the purchaser of a pool of mortgages. Typically, insurers own the mortgages of large, commercial developments.

EXAMPLE

Example: The Roundel Life Insurance Company is the mortgage lender on the $20 million Origami Mall. In this case, the basic accounting entry to record this mortgage is

Mortgage Loan—Origami Mall……20,000,000

Cash………………………………………………………..…..20,000,000

To record the issue of a mortgage on Origami Mall.

As part of each mortgage payment, most mortgage lenders, including insurers like the one in the above example, also require borrowers to make deposits to an escrow account. An escrow account, a liability account for the lender, is a trust account used to pay property maintenance expenses, property taxes, and other expenses related to a mortgaged property. Many lenders establish escrow accounts to ensure that (1) the property is maintained at some minimum level and (2) property taxes and other routine costs are paid.

When the insurer pays property taxes or other property expenses related to the mortgaged property, the insurer debits the property’s escrow account and credits Cash. The amount deposited in escrow by the borrower remains the same each month until a change in taxes, property insurance premiums, or other expenses necessitates a change in the escrow deposit. Because the lender accounts for escrow deposits separately from the principal and interest payments on the mortgage loan, escrow account transactions do not affect the outstanding principal and interest payments on the mortgage.

 

Stocks

A stock is an asset that represents a stockholder’s ownership interest in a company. Stock is sold in shares, and anyone who owns shares of stock in a company is known as a stockholder or shareholder. The par value of a stock is the designated legal monetary value assigned to each outstanding share of stock. To the purchaser, the stock of other companies is considered an equity security. The two major classes of stock are common stock and preferred stock:

  • Common stock is a type of stock that usually entitles the owner to (1) vote on the selection of directors and on other important company matters and (2) receive dividends on the stock, if they are declared.

  • Preferred stock is a type of stock that typically does not carry the voting rights of common stock, but does carry a stated dividend rate that is paid before any payment of common stock dividends by the same company. In the event of the company’s liquidation, owners of preferred stock have a prior claim to assets over common stockholders. Preferred stock is considered a hybrid security: it resembles a debt security with its stated dividend rate, which functions like an interest payment; and it resembles an equity security with its potential for price appreciation.

Of these two classes, life insurers typically invest more heavily in common stock than preferred stock.

Typically, U.S. statutory accounting limits the percentage of stocks that insurers can hold in the general account. Insurers also hold stocks in their separate accounts. We discuss the general account and separate accounts in the next chapter. Although equity securities make up a much smaller portion of an insurer’s investment portfolio than do bonds and other debt securities, an insurer’s investments in equity securities can represent a large monetary amount. The following sections discuss accounting for stocks from the investor’s point of view, with the assumption that an insurance company is the investor. In a later chapter, we discuss accounting for stocks when the insurer issues its own stock.

 

Stock Purchases, Sales, and Valuation

Accounting for the purchase and sale of stock held for investment purposes is similar to that for the purchase and sale of bonds. In other words, Stock is debited and Cash is credited for the stock’s purchase price, net of fees, commissions, or other transaction costs.

In their GAAP financial statements, insurers report the fair value per share of each stock they own—whether the stock is common or preferred. Under U.S. statutory accounting, most common stock is reported at fair value as of the financial reporting date. In contrast, most preferred stock is reported in a manner similar to bonds. Preferred stock that has an NAIC designation of 1 to 3 is reported at its amortized cost. However, for preferred stock with an NAIC designation of 4 to 6, insurers use the lower-of-cost-or-market (LCM) rule to report the preferred stock’s value.

The insight below presents some transactions associated with owning stock.

INSIGHT

Stock Transactions

The Parapet Life Insurance Company purchased 100 shares of Dandelion common stock for $95 per share. Parapet records the transaction by debiting the cost of the common stock to the Dandelion Common Stock account and crediting Cash for the same amount. The accounting entry is as follows:

Dandelion Common Stock…9,500

Cash…………………………………..9,500

To record the purchase of Dandelion common stock.

Assume that Parapet decides to sell all 100 shares of the Dandelion common stock for $80 per share, the current market price. The cash proceeds for this sale can be found by multiplying the number of shares sold by the market price per share: 100 shares × $80 per share = $8,000. Because the net sales proceeds of $8,000 are less than the historical cost of $9,500, we know that this sale results in a realized capital loss.

We can compute the realized capital loss as follows:

Realized capital loss = Net sales proceeds – Asset’s historical cost

Plugging in the values from the sale gives us

$8,000 – $9,500 = –$1,500, or a realized capital loss of $1,500

The accounting entry to record this transaction is

Cash……………………………………………..…………..8,000

Loss on Sale of Dandelion Common Stock…...1,500

Dandelion Common Stock…………………………………………9,500

To record the sale of Dandelion common stock at a loss.

Suppose instead that Parapet sold the Dandelion common stock for $120 per share. Because the net sales proceeds of $12,000, or 100 × $120, are more than the historical cost of $9,500, we know that this sale results in a realized capital gain.

We can compute the realized capital gain as follows:

Realized capital gain = Net sales proceeds – Asset’s historical cost

Plugging in the values from the sale gives us

$12,000 – $9,500 = $2,500, or a realized capital gain of $2,500

The accounting entry to record this transaction is

Cash………………………………………………...12,000

Dandelion Common Stock……………………………………9,500

Gain on Sale of Dandelion Common Stock…….….….2,500

To record the sale of Dandelion common stock at a gain.

 

Cash Dividends

Owners of stock may receive two kinds of dividends:

  • A cash dividend is a cash payment that a company periodically distributes to the owners of its preferred stock and common stock.

  • A stock dividend is a type of dividend in which a company distributes additional shares of its stock to stockholders.

In this section, we discuss cash dividends. Cash dividends on common stock are usually expressed as an annual monetary amount per share. Cash dividends on preferred stock are typically expressed as a percentage of par value per share. Dividends are typically paid quarterly.

EXAMPLE

Examples.

Suppose a common stock has an annual cash dividend of $1. In this case, the quarterly dividend is $0.25 per share, found as $1 ÷ 4.

A preferred stock with a par value of $20 has a cash dividend expressed as 10% of its par value, resulting in an annual dividend of $2 per share, or a quarterly dividend of $0.50 per share, found as $2 ÷ 4.

A typical accounting entry to record the receipt of cash dividends is a debit to Cash, an asset account, and a credit to a revenue account, such as Dividend Income—Common Stock or Dividend Income—Preferred Stock. Like accrued interest and accrued investment income, cash dividends that have been earned but not yet received on stock that an insurer owns as of the insurer’s financial reporting date are reported under Investment Income Due and Accrued or a similar asset account. We discuss accrued investment income in a later chapter.

Cash dividends are payable to stockholders who own the stock on the ex-dividend date. The ex-dividend date, also called the ex-date, is the date following the declaration date that is used for determining whether a stockholder is eligible to receive a declared cash dividend. The ex-dividend date is typically two business days prior to the record date. The record date is the date on which parties who are listed on a company’s records as owning the company’s common stock are identified as being entitled to receive dividends on stock, which are declared by the issuing company’s board of directors. Derivatives

Recall that derivatives are securities whose value is based on other securities, such as stocks or bonds. Insurers employ different kinds of derivatives, each of which has its own terms and features. Insurers generally use derivatives to mitigate their exposure to various risks, such as interest-rate risk, currency risk, and market risk. A detailed discussion of the many types of derivatives is beyond the scope of this text. Instead, we focus on the regulatory requirements that insurers must satisfy for holding derivatives and the typical accounting treatment for derivatives.

Derivatives are highly complex instruments that in some cases come with high risks. Therefore, regulators require insurers to submit detailed information about the derivatives they hold. For both U.S. GAAP and statutory reporting, insurers typically include derivatives on the balance sheet or disclose them in notes that accompany their financial statements.

For statutory reporting purposes, insurers must also report their derivatives in Schedule DB of their Quarterly and Annual Statements. In this schedule, insurers must provide certain information about each derivative they hold, such as a description of the derivative, its face amount (also called notional amount), fair value, and maturity date. If the derivative is being held for a hedging purpose, the insurer must provide additional details about the hedge. Hedgingrefers to counterbalancing a given risk exposure against another. In other words, to protect itself from a given risk, an insurer takes an action—such as entering into a derivatives contract—that “hedges” or minimizes that risk.

U.S. GAAP requires insurers to recognize derivatives as either assets or liabilities on the balance sheet and measure them at fair value, regardless of the purpose for holding the derivative. Under SAP, the purpose for holding a derivative dictates the manner in which it is reported. For example, derivatives used for hedging purposes generally should be accounted for in a manner consistent with the item that is being hedged:

  • If the item being hedged is reported at amortized cost, then the derivative should be reported at amortized cost.

  • If the item being hedged is reported at fair value, then the derivative should be reported at fair value.

In contrast, derivatives held for purposes other than hedging—for example, to generate income—are typically reported at fair value, and any changes in the fair value of such a derivative are recognized in current operations.

The NAIC’s Derivative Instruments Model Regulation also establishes standards for the prudent use of derivatives by insurance companies. According to this Model Regulation, insurers must have written guidelines that govern their transactions in derivative instruments, and they also must have procedures in place for monitoring their derivatives. Insurers generally record these guidelines and procedures in a derivatives use plan (DUP). Many insurers conduct periodic audits of their DUPs to confirm that they are complying with the DUP.

pages.title: Accounting for Short-Term Assets
pages.contents:
Accounting for Short-Term Assets

Life insurers maintain detailed accounting records for short-term assets available for the payment of contractual benefits and business expenses. Recall that short-term assets are assets that a company expects to convert to cash or consume within the current accounting period, typically one year. Typical short-term assets held by insurers include cash and cash equivalents, investment income due and accrued, deferred premiums, uncollected premiums, and prepaid expenses.

 

Cash and Cash Equivalents

Cash is the amount of currency on hand or on deposit at an insurer’s bank. Cash equivalents are short-term assets that will mature in 90 days or less from the date of purchase. Cash equivalents are highly liquid investments—that is, they can be readily converted to cash with little or no loss in value. One example of a cash equivalent is a Treasury bill that will mature within 90 days or less of the date of purchase. Treasury bills, also called T-bills, are short-term assets issued and guaranteed by the U.S. government.

Cash accounting, sometimes called treasury operations or cash management, refers to the management and maintenance of records and reports for all of an insurer’s cash transactions, specifically money deposited in or withdrawn from an insurer’s accounts at a bank or other financial institution. The cash accounting function might also include the management of cash equivalents and short-term invested assets because these assets can usually be readily converted to cash.

Cash accounting typically involves the oversight of one or more transactions (checking) accounts with a bank or other financial institution. For example, an insurer might have separate checking accounts for premium collection, claim payments, and agent commissions. Because these accounts, even if interest-bearing, generally pay a lower rate of interest than is available on other short-term assets, the insurer tends to maintain in these accounts only the minimum cash balance required to pay its current obligations.

For financial reporting purposes, an insurer’s cash balance as of a specified date is the total amount of cash in its Cash account. In addition to cash and cash equivalents, insurers have other short-term assets, including (1) investment income due and accrued, (2) deferred premiums and uncollected premiums, and (3) prepaid expenses. Short-term assets, with the exception of prepaid expenses, are typically considered admitted assets for U.S. statutory accounting purposes.

 

Investment Income Due and Accrued

Investment income due and accrued is a short-term asset for insurers in the United States. Income due and accrued is income that was earned by the insurer before the financial reporting date but that has not yet been received. This income is classified as an asset because the insurer can expect to receive the income as a result of contractual arrangements. Investment Income Due and Accrued is the account used to report due and accrued investment income for U.S. statutory accounting purposes. An insurer indicates in a note to the financial statements the amount of investment income due and accrued that the insurer expects to receive after the financial reporting date.

Figure 6.1 presents an example of investment income due and accrued.

 

Deferred Premiums and Uncollected Premiums

Life insurers use short-term asset accounts—such as Deferred Premiums or Uncollected Premiums—to record and report life insurance policy premiums that (1) are due after the statutory reporting date but before the next policy anniversary date or (2) were due before the statutory reporting date but have not been received yet.

Deferred premiums are life insurance premiums due after the statutory reporting date but before the next policy anniversary date. The Deferred Premiums account is specific to life insurance companies that comply with U.S. statutory accounting principles. Moreover, this account applies only to life insurance premium payments that (1) are made more frequently than annually and (2) have a due date that falls between the statutory reporting date and the policy’s next anniversary date.

Figure 6.2 presents an example of a deferred premium.

Life insurance companies also report their uncollected premiums for statutory accounting purposes. Uncollected premiums are individual life insurance policy premiums that are due before the statutory reporting date but have not been received as of that date.

Figure 6.3 presents an example of an uncollected premium.

 

Prepaid Expenses

In accounting, prepaid expenses are those expenditures, paid in advance, that the insurer expects will provide a future value or benefit. Examples of prepaid expenses include rent, subscriptions, service contracts, and any other charges that the insurer has paid before receiving the goods and services associated with those charges. Because prepaid expenses are not readily available to satisfy policyowner obligations, SAP considers them to be nonadmitted assets. Under GAAP, however, prepaid expenses are classified as short-term assets, and they are charged to expense in the accounting period in which the benefits are received or used.

Figure 6.4 presents an example of prepaid expenses.

pages.title: Valuation and Reporting of Real Estate
pages.contents:
Valuation and Reporting of Real Estate

Property is an asset that can be owned or possessed. Property can be classified as real estate or personal property. Real estate, also called real property, is land or anything attached to the land. Examples of real estate are a parcel of land, a home, or a commercial building. Most insurers own three types of real estate:

  1. Properties occupied by the insurer, such as home office and regional office buildings

  2. Properties held for sale, which are not as common as insurer-occupied properties

  3. Properties held for the production of rental income

Personal property is any property that is not real estate. Some examples of personal property are automobiles, computer equipment, and furniture.

Insurers generally report real estate at book value in their financial statements. For U.S. statutory purposes, real estate is typically considered an admitted asset, and insurers describe each real estate asset in a separate schedule in the Annual Statement. In contrast, personal property is typically considered a nonadmitted asset.

 

Recording Purchases and Sales of Real Estate

Life insurance companies in the United States depreciate the cost of real estate—except for land—over the useful economic life of the property. Land is not depreciated under U.S. accounting standards. Instead, the insurer values land at its historical cost until the property is sold.

In addition to the purchase price, the cost for real estate may include any acquisition costs—such as sales commissions and legal fees—spent to acquire the property. On the date of purchase, the historical cost and the book value of an asset in general, and real estate in particular, are equal. Over time, however, depreciation will allocate the cost of the asset over the asset’s estimated useful life.

Accounting entries to record depreciation on real estate usually involve contra accounts. A contra account, which accompanies a specified “companion” account—typically an asset account—is an account that has a normal balance that is the opposite of the companion account. For example, asset accounts and expense accounts have a normal debit balance, so contra accounts for assets and expenses would have a normal credit balance. The purpose of a contra account is to provide additional information on the transactions that occur in the companion account. The amounts in a contra account usually decrease the balance in its companion account. However, the monetary amount in a contra account should not be larger than the amount in its companion account.

Contra accounts are generally used to amortize real estate depreciation. A typical accounting entry to record depreciation of an insurer’s real estate is a debit to Depreciation on Real Estate (a noncash expense account) and a credit to a contra account, such as Accumulated Depreciation on Real Estate. By using contra accounts for real estate, an insurer records Accumulated Depreciation—a contra account—separately from Real Estate, the companion asset account.

Figure 6.5 summarizes the characteristics of contra accounts.

Property Taxes

Life insurance companies usually record property taxes as an investment expense. Property taxes are generally payable in advance at specified times during the year. Property taxes accumulate between tax payment dates. Sometimes an insurer purchases real estate for which the taxes have not been paid in advance. In this case, the seller of the real estate either (1) pays to the insurer the amount of any accrued and unpaid taxes or (2) reduces the purchase price by that amount. If an insurer purchases property after the seller has paid the taxes for the current tax period, the insurer must return to the seller the amount of tax applicable to the remainder of the tax period. This concept is similar to the example described in the previous chapter, where the bond seller and the bond purchaser each earn bond interest income during the same interest period.

 

Foreclosure

Foreclosure is a legal proceeding by which a lender can take possession of and sell a mortgaged property to recover the unpaid loan balance if the borrower fails to make timely contractual principal and interest payments on the loan. An insurer has two options when it obtains property through foreclosure: (1) put the property up for resale or (2) rent the property to generate rental income.

When real estate obtained through foreclosure is offered for resale, an insurer usually capitalizes the costs of foreclosure, including property taxes on the real estate acquired. In the context of accounting for these costs, to capitalize means to record the costs as an asset. In this case, this means adding the amount of property taxes to the cost of the property. On the other hand, when real estate is obtained through foreclosure and is rented to produce income, an insurer treats the property taxes as an expense.

 

Rental Income and Rental Expense

Earnings associated with real estate ownership generally take the forms of (1) rental income and (2) a gain upon the sale of the property at a price higher than the purchase price. When an insurer leases property to another entity, the insurer records income from this transaction by debiting Cash and crediting Rental Income. Expense transactions regarding an insurer’s rental properties are debited to Real Estate Expense and credited to Cash. Insurers record the amount of rental expense they pay on rented property in an expense account such as Rental Expense. We discuss accounting for expenses in a later chapter.

pages.title: Accounting for Other Assets
pages.contents:
Accounting for Other Assets

Insurance companies own and maintain many assets in addition to the ones we have discussed. This section briefly covers accounting for amounts recoverable from reinsurers, policy loans, deferred acquisition costs, and the insurer’s general account and separate accounts.

 

Amounts Recoverable from Reinsurers

Reinsurance is insurance that one insurance company, known as the direct writer or ceding company, purchases from another insurance company, known as the reinsurer or assuming company, to transfer all or part of the risk on insurance policies that the direct writer has issued. When an insurer obtains reinsurance on a policy, the insurer is usually responsible for paying benefits to any and all policy beneficiaries. However, because the reinsurer has assumed a portion or all of the risk associated with the policy, the reinsurer is typically obligated to pay its contracted share of the benefits to the direct writer—in this case, the insurer—to comply with the terms of the reinsurance agreement. The money that the reinsurer is obligated to pay the insurer is an asset to the insurer. Let’s look at a simple example of how an insurer would account for a death claim payment on a reinsured life insurance policy.

EXAMPLE

Example. The Sunflower Life Insurance Company issues an individual life insurance policy with a $250,000 death benefit. Sunflower reinsures $50,000 of the risk on this policy. While the policy is in force, the insured dies and Sunflower determines that the policy beneficiary is entitled to the $250,000 death benefit. To record the payment of the death benefit, Sunflower makes the following accounting entry:

Death Claims Paid…………………..……..….250,000

Cash…………………………………..………..…….………250,000

To record payment of the death benefit to a policy beneficiary.

Upon the death of the insured, the reinsurer owes Sunflower $50,000 under the terms of its reinsurance agreement. Sunflower records the amount recoverable from the reinsurer as follows:

Amount Recoverable from Reinsurer………50,000

Death Claims Paid………………………………………50,000

To record the amount recoverable from the reinsurer.

Upon receipt of the $50,000 from the reinsurer, Sunflower would record the following accounting entry:

Cash…………………………………………..………....50,000

Amount Recoverable from Reinsurer………………50,000

To record the receipt of payment for the claim recoverable from the reinsurer.

In the above example, Amount Recoverable from Reinsurer is a statutory account.

 

Policy Loans

Cash value life insurance policies include a savings element—known as the cash value—that a policyowner can use in a number of ways. One important use of the cash value is as a loan. A policy loan, called a certificate loan in fraternal benefit societies, is a loan made to a policyowner and secured by the policy’s cash value as collateral. Policy loans are unique to life insurance companies, and this asset account can have a substantial balance in it. The basic accounting entry to record a policy loan is a debit to an asset account, such as Policy Loans or Contract Loans, and a credit to Cash, another asset account.

Because insurers charge interest on policy loans, accounting for policy loans involves keeping detailed records of the principal and interest on each policy loan. Insurers typically calculate policy loan interest so that it is payable on the policy anniversary date. However, some insurers charge policy loan interest at the end of the policy year, and a few insurers charge interest in advance. Policyowners usually pay the accrued policy loan interest when repaying the principal on a policy loan. The typical accounting entry to record the receipt of principal and interest on a policy loan consists of a debit to Cash, a credit to Policy Loans or Contract Loans, and a credit to Investment Income for the interest portion of the loan.

For statutory reporting purposes, policy loans are typically considered admitted assets. They are reported at book value, which means the original loan amount, plus accrued interest, minus principal repayments. Contract Loans, an asset account, is reported separately from Investment Income, a revenue account. However, for financial reporting purposes, policy loan interest that is due and accrued is reported as part of Investment Income Due and Accrued, an asset account.

 

Deferred Acquisition Costs

The FASB defines deferred acquisition costs (DAC), also known as deferred policy acquisition costs (DPAC), as costs that are related directly to the successful acquisition of new or renewal insurance contracts. Under U.S. GAAP, insurers capitalize these costs and then amortize them over several years. Note that this definition includes the word successful. In the past, some companies were capitalizing all acquisition-related costs, even though some of these costs were related to unsuccessful attempts to acquire new or renewal business. This approach created problems, because when these costs were deferred and then amortized into earnings in future periods, the insurer had no corresponding revenue to which the expenses could be matched.

According to the FASB, typical examples of DAC are policy issue costs, underwriting costs, and agent commissions. Deferred Acquisition Costs is a long-term asset account that appears on a balance sheet prepared under U.S. GAAP, but not on the statutory balance sheet. Under statutory accounting in the United States, the insurer reports costs for new products during the accounting period in which they are incurred.

 

The General Account and Separate Accounts

In Chapter 1, you learned that U.S. life insurance companies that offer variable products—also known as nonguaranteed products—are subject to SEC regulation. Here we discuss another requirement for these companies: they must maintain one or more separate accounts to manage the funds associated with these variable products. So, what’s a separate account? And how is it related to an account that all life insurers have—the general account?

For a life insurer, the general account and any separate accounts contain assets that back the insurer’s products:

  • The general account is the account in which an insurer maintains assets that support its contractual obligations for guaranteed insurance products. Products typically backed by general account assets include individual permanent life insurance products—such as whole life insurance and universal life insurance—fixed-rate annuities, and guaranteed minimum benefit riders under variable products. General account assets typically are subject to the claims of an insurer’s general creditors in the event of the insurer’s insolvency. In addition, the insurer bears the investment risk associated with the assets in the general account.

  • A separate account, also called a segregated fund, is an account that the insurer maintains separately from its general account for managing the funds associated with nonguaranteed (variable) insurance products, such as variable universal life insurance and variable annuities. Although the vast majority of the products in separate accounts are nonguaranteed, some separate accounts contain guaranteed (nonvariable) products, such as modified guaranteed annuities. Unlike general account assets, separate account assets are generally insulated from the claims of an insurer’s general creditors in the event of the insurer’s insolvency. In general, the customer bears all or most of the investment risk associated with separate account products.

Just like general account assets, separate account assets belong to the insurer. The difference, however, is that the insurer generally establishes a liability to its customers who own separate account products. This liability reflects the customers’ direct financial interest in the separate account assets held by the insurer.

The chart below summarizes the differences between an insurer’s general account and its separate accounts.

General Account

Separate Accounts

Supports the contractual obligations for guaranteed insurance products

Manage the funds associated with nonguaranteed insurance products

The insurer bears the investment risk for funds in the general account

In general, the customer bears all or most of the risk of separate account products

Assets are subject to the claims of creditors in the event of insurer insolvency

Assets are generally insulated from the claims of creditors in the event of insurer insolvency

Assets belong to the insurer

Assets belong to the insurer, but the insurer generally establishes a liability to customers owning separate account products

The discussion that follows applies to life insurers that offer both guaranteed and nonguaranteed insurance products—in other words, life insurers that maintain a general account and one or more separate accounts. For these life insurers, statutory reporting includes two types of annual statements: (1) the Annual Statement and (2) the Annual Statement of the Separate Accounts, which we abbreviate as the Separate Accounts Annual Statement.

 

The Annual Statement

The Annual Statement is “the blank” or “blue book” that we discussed earlier in the text. The Annual Statement reports in detail on an insurer’s general account business; however, it also contains summary information on the insurer’s separate accounts business. For example, any net income reported on the Separate Accounts Annual Statement—excluding unrealized capital gains and losses—is included on the Annual Statement’s Summary of Operations. In addition, in the notes to the financial statements, a note is included describing the characteristics of the company’s separate accounts business.

 

The Separate Accounts Annual Statement

The Separate Accounts Annual Statement, sometimes called the “green book,” generally reports on the investment activities of all the insurer’s separate accounts. Like the Annual Statement, the Separate Accounts Annual Statement includes the pages that form the statutory balance sheet and income statement, along with information on reserves and an analysis of operations by lines of business. However, it includes no notes to the financial statements nor any types of noninvestment schedules. Because of these differences, the Separate Accounts Annual Statement is typically much shorter than the Annual Statement.

In addition, whereas the Annual Statement has a quarterly and annual version, the Separate Accounts Annual Statement has only an annual version. The Separate Accounts Annual Statement also includes a unique exhibit called “Guaranteed insurance and annuity products”—or “Exhibit 6”—that separates the liabilities for guaranteed products from those for nonguaranteed products. Regulators use this exhibit to differentiate between the separate account liabilities that represent risks for the company versus those that represent risks for customers.

See below for an example of this exhibit. The lines highlighted in gray show that, for this company, 24.7 percent of its separate account liabilities are for guaranteed products, whereas 75.3 percent are for nonguaranteed products.

All inflows to and outflows from the Separate Accounts Annual Statement—excluding investment returns and activity—enter or leave the Statement through the general account Annual Statement. Characteristics of Contra Accounts

How does a contra account appear in a company’s records?

It typically accompanies a companion account.

The companion account is typically what kind of account?

An asset account.

What is the normal balance of a contra account?

The opposite of the normal balance of the companion account.

For example, if the companion account is an asset account, it has a debit balance,which means the contra account has a credit balance.

What effect does a contra account typically have on its companion account?

The contra account usually decreases the balance of the companionaccount.

Can the amount in a contra account be larger than the amount in the companionaccount?

No.

What is the purpose of a contra account?

To provide additional information on the transactions that occur in thecompanion account.

What is a typical example of a contra account?

Accumulated Depreciation is a contra account; its companion assetaccount is Real Estate.

Reserves are significant liabilities for insurers. For a life insurer, reservesare estimates of the amounts of money that the insurer needs to pay future contract obligations. Because reserves are a critical component of an insurer’s solvency, insurance companies and regulators place great emphasis on establishing adequate reserves.

Why is it so important for an insurer to have adequate reserves? Let’s look at what happens when an insurer’s reserves are inadequate:

EXAMPLE

Example. Assume that an insurer’s reserves are underestimated; this means its surplus will be overstated, and the insurer may appear financially stronger than it really is. When contractual obligations come due, the insurer will have to use more of its assets than anticipated to pay these obligations, which will reduce its surplus. This unexpected reduction in surplus could impair the insurer’s future operations or, if the reduction is significant enough, threaten the insurer’s solvency.

On the other hand, overestimating reserves can cause problems for an insurer, too. The insurer’s surplus will initially be understated, making the company appear weaker than it really is. In such a situation, the insurer’s future operations could be impeded, or the insurer could miss out on important business opportunities.

pages.title: The Concept of Reserves
pages.contents:
The Concept of Reserves

Although establishing adequate reserves is crucial for insurance companies, the process is not always simple. For some insurance products, determining the amount of a reserve is a relatively straightforward process. However, for most insurance products, the amount of an insurer’s future contractual obligations is not known precisely in advance. Because of this uncertainty, the process of setting adequate reserve amounts starts with actuarial assumptions.

 

Actuarial Assumptions

The amounts that insurers record in their reserve accounts are, of necessity, estimates. When an insurer establishes reserves for a block of guaranteed insurance policies, it knows the total face value of the block of policies and, thus, its future obligation to its customers. However, the insurer can only estimate the amount of investment earnings on the portion of policy premiums it actually invests. In addition, the insurer does not know precisely when a customer or beneficiary will submit a claim on the policy or if a policy will lapse before benefit payments become due. Because of such uncertainties, insurers must estimate the amounts to report in their reserve accounts. These assumed values used in a life insurance or an annuity product design are called actuarial assumptions. In product design, insurers make assumptions with respect to many factors, such as future mortality rates, investment earnings, expenses, surrenders, and lapses.

To determine the amount of reserves to record in its accounting records, insurers rely on actuaries. An actuary is an expert in financial risk management and the mathematics and modeling of insurance, annuities, and financial instruments. In insurance companies, actuaries are responsible for ensuring that the company’s products are financially sound. Using mathematical probabilities, actuaries estimate the amounts needed to pay future benefits to the insurer’s customers. The insurer then records and reports these amounts as liabilities in its accounting records. Reserves for a block of insurance policies or contracts, a line of business, or an entire company are called aggregate reserves. When you see reserves on an insurer’s balance sheet, you are looking at aggregated reserves for each line of business.

 

Accounting Records and Reserves

Reserves can vary depending on the type of accounting records the insurer is using. We describe four important types of accounting records for life insurance companies below:

  • As you can guess from your knowledge of GAAP accounting, GAAP accounting records are designed for financial reporting to investors, noninsurance regulators (such as the SEC in the United States), and the general public. In the United States, all stock insurance companies and many mutual insurance companies maintain accounting records and prepare financial statements according to GAAP. Because GAAP accounting records focus on showing a company’s financial stability and its profitability, GAAP is a type of profitability-basis accounting. The reserves calculated for GAAP-based financial statements are called GAAP reserves or profitability-basis reserves.

  • Internal accounting records, also known as modified GAAP accounting records, are designed for financial reporting to a company’s management team, whose primary interest is in having appropriate data for making decisions. Internal accounting records are used in management accounting because they are designed to produce results that managers believe present a realistic picture of a company’s financial situation. Each insurer freely sets its own desired accounting standards, although most companies base their internal accounting records and reports on their own modified version of GAAP. Reserves calculated under modified GAAP are called internal reserves. Because internal accounting records contain proprietary information, such as a company’s product sales, investment returns, and profits, these records generally are not released to external parties.

  • As you can surmise from your knowledge of SAP, statutory accounting records, also called solvency-basis accounting records, are designed to comply with the financial reporting requirements established by state insurance regulators. Statutory accounting records are a type of solvency-basis accounting. Reserves calculated under statutory accounting are called statutory reserves, required reserves, and solvency-basis reserves.

  • Tax accounting records are designed for financial reporting to taxing authorities. Typically, the taxing authorities—for example, the IRS and the state revenue departments in the United States—develop the procedures for companies to comply with tax reporting requirements. Reserves calculated for tax accounting purposes are called tax reserves. Most tax accounting topics are outside the scope of this textbook.

 

Reserves for Products

Life insurance companies establish and monitor several types of reserves that are used in accounting for blocks of life insurance policies or annuity contracts. The various types of reserves enable an insurer to illustrate clearly in its financial statements the nature and extent of its liabilities for policy benefits.

 

Contractual Reserves and Noncontractual Reserves

Insurers have several types of contractual reserves and noncontractual reserves. A contractual reserve is a liability that identifies the amount that, together with future premiums and investment earnings, represents the expected amount of future benefits payable on an insurer’s in-force business. In other words, contractual reserves are the insurer’s estimates for the amounts it needs on hand today to pay contractual benefits on a product as they come due.

Contractual reserves

Reserves + Future premiums + Investment earnings =

Expected future benefits payable on in-force business

Other terms sometimes used for contractual reserves include policy reserves, legal reserves, and tabular reserves in the United States and similar terms in other countries.

In contrast to contractual reserves, a noncontractual reserve is a liability amount that an insurer estimates it will need to pay the insurer’s business obligations that are not directly attributable to benefits payable for a specified product. In other words, all reserves that are not contractual reserves are classified as noncontractual reserves. Two examples of noncontractual reserves for life insurers are the asset valuation reserve (AVR) and the interest maintenance reserve (IMR), which we discuss in the next chapter.

 

GAAP Reserves and Statutory Reserves

In recent years, regulatory authorities in the United States have implemented changes that affect how insurers estimate their GAAP reserves and statutory reserves.

GAAP Reserves

For many years, U.S. GAAP generally did not allow an insurer to modify the actuarial assumptions on which it calculated its GAAP reserves—even if the insurer’s assumptions at policy issue turned out to be wrong. Insurers referred to these assumptions as being “locked in” at issue. Estimates of future policy benefits, however, were allowed to include a provision for adverse deviation (PAD), a safety margin that allowed for unfavorable variations from actuarial assumptions.

In 2018, the FASB issued its ASU titled Targeted Improvements to the Accounting for Long-Duration Contracts. According to this ASU, the assumptions that an insurer uses to estimate its future policy benefits are no longer “locked in” at issue. Instead, insurers are allowed to update these assumptions—at least on an annual basis and more frequently if necessary. Because insurers can now update these assumptions, estimates of future policy benefits under GAAP will no longer need to include a PAD.

According to the FASB, large publicly traded life insurers must start following the rules in this ASU for fiscal years beginning after December 31, 2022. Smaller public insurers must start following these rules for fiscal years beginning after December 2024

Statutory Reserves

Traditionally, state regulations have mandated that life insurers establish statutory reserves for their products based on prescribed formulas and assumptions. Under this approach, typically known as rules-based reserving, all life insurance companies that sold a specific product were required to use the same formula for reserve valuation and the same estimates of future mortality and investment experience. This one-size-fits-all approach created situations in which some insurers were holding either too little or too much in statutory reserves for a given product.

To address this imbalance, state regulators have endorsed a new approach in recent years: principles-based reserving (PBR). PBR attempts to “right-size” an insurer’s reserves, so that the reserves an insurer holds for a specific product are based on the insurer’s own experience and risks.

As of the publication date of this text, life insurers are permitted to use PBR for most individual life insurance products. (The new approach applies to products issued on or after January 1, 2017.) Over time, PBR is expected to be developed for additional product lines. By enabling insurers to calculate and report more accurate estimates for their statutory reserves, PBR promises to enhance the reporting function and strengthen the financial position of the insurers that use it.

Additional detail on PBR and reserve calculation requirements can be found in the Valuation Manual established in the Standard Valuation Law for each state.

pages.title: Reserves, Net Income, and Surplus
pages.contents:
Reserves, Net Income, and Surplus

Now we’re ready to consider some specific insurance transactions related to reserves to see how they are handled by the accounting function.

At the end of each accounting period, an insurer’s actuaries provide updated reserve amounts for each block of policies. The accounting function then posts an adjusting entry to ensure that the balance sheet reports the updated reserve amounts.

Part of the aggregate reserve amount is released when a policy benefit is paid or a contract terminates. A released reserve is a contractual reserve that was originally established in connection with an in-force policy but is no longer required. Released reserves help cushion the impact of policy benefit payments on the insurer’s surplus, as shown in the following example.

EXAMPLE

Example. The Elegant Life Insurance Company established a reserve for a $1 million block of life insurance policies. At the time when $1 million in policy benefits was paid, the balance in the reserve account for this block of policies was $400,000.

Analysis. Upon the payment of the policy benefits, Elegant would release $400,000 of reserves. Despite the $1 million paid in policy benefits, neither Elegant’s net income nor its surplus is automatically reduced by $1 million.

Instead, Elegant’s net income decreases by only $600,000 ($1,000,000 – $400,000), which is the difference between the amount of the benefit payments and the amount of the released reserve for this block of policies, all other factors remaining equal. When it closes out the accounting period, Elegant adds net income to surplus, and assuming no policy dividends or cash dividends, the impact on surplus is also a decrease of $600,000 instead of $1 million, because of the released reserve.

Figure 7.1 presents a simplified flowchart of the accounting entries resulting from financial transactions associated with a block of insurance contracts.

 

Strengthening and Destrengthening Reserves

Under statutory accounting, an insurer is allowed to strengthen or destrengthen its statutory reserves for an existing product or a block of policies:

  • Reserve strengthening. If a reserve is too low, an insurer may consider strengthening it. Typically, this situation occurs if the insurer’s experience with a product reveals that the assumptions used to calculate contractual reserves were too optimistic. In such a situation, the insurer may decide to increase its reserves to protect or improve its solvency or its quality rating by an independent rating agency. The act of increasing a reserve amount, which results in a decrease in the insurer’s capital or surplus, is known as reserve strengthening. Insurers strengthen reserves by using actuarial assumptions that are less favorable to the company than those used in the original reserve valuation.

  • Reserve destrengthening. Conversely, an insurer may decide, based on its experience with a product, that the product’s reserves are too high, calling for reserve destrengthening. In this situation, the insurer may want to increase the amount of its capital or surplus to use its capital for other purposes, such as to support new business. By engaging in reserve destrengthening, the insurer decreases a reserve amount, which results in an increase in the insurer’s capital or surplus. Insurers destrengthen reserves by using actuarial assumptions that are more favorable to the company than those used in the original reserve valuation. For insurers that operate in the United States, reserve destrengthening requires regulatory permission from the insurance commissioner in the insurer’s state of domicile. In practice, insurers rarely destrengthen their contractual reserves.

 

Accounting for Reserve Strengthening/Destrengthening

In the case of reserve strengthening and destrengthening, both the monetary amount of the reserve and the insurer’s underlying actuarial assumptions change. Accounting for reserve strengthening or destrengthening directly changes either capital or surplus on the insurer’s balance sheet. Accounts with names such as Contractual Reserves—Life or Policy Reserves—Life are used to record and report changes in reserves that result from reserve strengthening or destrengthening. The insurer also reports reserves—such as Aggregate Reserve for Life Contracts—for each type of insurance product in the Annual Statement.

Keep in mind that the periodic accounting entries made to increase or decrease an insurer’s aggregate reserves as a result of routine contractual transactions, such as paying policy claims or accounting for lapsed policies, differ from reserve strengthening and destrengthening. Recording accounting entries for routine contractual activity changes only the monetary amount of the aggregate reserves; the insurer’s original underlying assumptions to calculate the reserves do not change.

Typical account names used to record such changes include Change in Reserves or Increases/Decreases in Provision for Future Policy Benefits. These accounts are income statement accounts, and they are used to report changes in reserve amounts as a result of routine financial transactions associated with a block of policies. Thus, an insurer reports changes in reserves that are a result of routine contractual activity on its income statement.

Typically, changes in contractual reserves are reported at the end of an accounting period for that period’s transactions.

 

Surplus Strain

An insurer’s first-year costs for many products are substantial. In addition, the insurer must establish reserves for a product in the product’s first year. The increase in a U.S. insurer’s assets resulting from a product’s first-year premium is often smaller than the increase in the insurer’s liabilities created by the reserve the insurer must establish for the product. In such situations, the insurer’s surplus must be reduced to provide for the increase in reserves.

For a new product, first-year costs of contract issue, sales commissions, and the creation of new reserves typically combine to produce a negative first-year surplus. This negative surplus is an aspect of surplus strain. Surplus strain, also known as issue strain or new business strain, is the decrease in an insurer’s surplus caused by the high first-year costs and the reserve requirements associated with new products. A decrease in potential surplus strain that strengthens an insurer’s financial position is referred to as surplus relief. Watch Video 7.2 for an explanation of surplus strain.

Under U.S. statutory and U.S. GAAP accounting, insurers use different approaches for spreading out the impact of surplus strain:

  • Under statutory accounting, life insurers can use modified reserve valuation, which is a method of calculating contractual reserves in which an insurer sets a lower-than-level first-year contractual reserve in recognition of a product’s high first-year expenses. Under modified reserve valuation, the first-year reserve adjustment affects contractual reserve values for all subsequent years of the product’s existence. Reserves developed using the modified reserve valuation method are called modified reserves.

  • U.S. GAAP does not allow an adjustment to reserves to minimize the impact of surplus strain. Instead, it uses an asset account you learned about in the previous chapter: deferred acquisition costs (DAC).

The following sections discuss the use of deferred acquisition costs and reinsurance to reduce surplus strain.

 

Deferred Acquisition Costs

Under U.S. GAAP, insurers can reduce surplus strain by using DAC to spread out, through amortization, the reporting of acquisition costs and issue costs over several years. The negative impact on surplus is then applied in subsequent years. Note that DAC is not a tool for increasing or decreasing the amount of a reserve. Because of the use of DAC, when analysts study U.S. GAAP financial statements to evaluate an insurer’s strength, they typically adjust GAAP reserves for DAC to produce a measure known as net GAAP reserves. Net GAAP reserves equal the insurer’s reported GAAP reserves minus DAC, as shown:

Net GAAP reserves = GAAP reserves – DAC

Net GAAP reserves are similar to modified statutory reserves in that both net GAAP reserves and modified statutory reserves represent the insurer’s contractual reserve liabilities modified by an allowance to reflect the high cost of first-year expenses. Remember, reserves and surplus are both on the right-hand side of the basic accounting equation. If assets cannot be increased to match the increase in reserves, then surplus must be decreased to create the balance, as shown in the following example.

EXAMPLE

Example. The Durable Life Insurance Company has

  • $6.0 million in assets
  • $4.0 million in liabilities
  • $1.0 million in capital
  • $1.0 million in surplus

Durable established $0.1 million in DAC (an asset) when it increased its reserves (a liability) by $0.1 million. As a result, Durable’s assets increase to $6.1 million ($6.0 million + $0.1 million), and its liabilities increase to $4.1 million ($4.0 million + $0.1 million).

Reinsurance and Reserve Credits

Recall that a direct writer uses reinsurance primarily to reduce the amount of risk it assumes when it sells an insurance policy. Under some types of reinsurance arrangements, the reinsurer assumes some of the direct writer’s liability for benefit payments and also agrees to establish reserves for the reinsured portion of the risk. Under these agreements, a direct writer is responsible for establishing a smaller amount of required reserves and has a reduced potential for surplus strain.

The reduction in surplus strain that is achieved by using reinsurance is a type of surplus relief. A reserve credit is the solvency-basis accounting entry the direct writer uses to record a reduction of reserves due to the use of reinsurance. Despite its name, a reserve credit is actually posted as a debit; this means that a reserve credit decreases the amount of reserves as a result of reinsurance.

On a reinsured policy, the direct writer first establishes a policy reserve in the usual manner. Then the direct writer in effect reduces that reserve amount by recording a reserve credit that offsets a portion of the reserve. Most states restrict the situations in which a direct writer in the United States is entitled to take reinsurance reserve credits by placing requirements on the reinsurer. Because taking reserve credits can improve an insurer’s financial condition, insurers seek to cede risks to reinsurers that meet the specified requirements for reserve credit.

pages.title: Asset Fluctuation Reserves
pages.contents:
Asset Fluctuation Reserves

The reserves we discussed in the previous chapter were those related to a life insurer’s obligations to its policyowners and beneficiaries—in other words, an insurer’s contractual reserves. In the United States, each life insurer also must establish two statutory reserves that are noncontractual in nature: the asset valuation reserve (AVR) and the interest maintenance reserve (IMR). The AVR and the IMR are designed to absorb gains and losses on the insurer’s invested assets.

You may recall from earlier chapters that the market values of an insurer’s invested assets can fluctuate widely. These two reserves are intended to minimize the effects of these fluctuations—thus earning them the name asset fluctuation reserves.

On an insurer’s statutory balance sheet, capital gains increase the insurer’s assets, whereas capital losses decrease them. The insurer must balance these changes in assets with a change in either liabilities or capital and surplus. If capital gains and losses were allowed to affect an insurer’s capital and surplus accounts, then the insurer’s capital and surplus would be subject to significant short-term fluctuations, resulting in an inaccurate picture of the insurer’s overall financial condition. Instead, these capital gains and losses are reflected in the AVR and the IMR. These two reserves act as a buffer for the insurer’s capital and surplus, causing capital and surplus to be affected only gradually by capital gains and losses. Thus, these reserves help to ensure the stability of an insurer’s capital and surplus accounts.

Note that the AVR and IMR are relevant only for statutory reporting purposes.

 

Asset Valuation Reserve

The asset valuation reserve (AVR) is a reserve that minimizes the effects of both realized and unrealized gains and losses on an insurer’s invested assets when those gains and losses are related to the credit quality of the assets—a risk known as credit risk—or fluctuations in the prices of equity securities—a risk known as equity risk. In this context, credit risk is the risk that a financial obligation will not be paid. Recall that a capital gain or loss generally is realized when an insurer sells an invested asset, whereas a capital gain or loss generally is unrealized as long as the insurer still holds the invested asset. Capital gains increase the AVR, whereas capital losses decrease the AVR.

Some common examples of credit risk for life insurers are as follows:

  • A bond issuer experiences financial difficulties and is unable to pay interest or principal on the bond.

  • A mortgage borrower stops making mortgage payments.

  • A stock issuer experiences unfavorable financial circumstances or files for bankruptcy.

Although these examples describe invested assets that have declined in value due to credit risk, the market value of invested assets can also increase due to credit risk.

At the end of the accounting year, an insurer may be required to increase its AVR by transferring an amount from its capital and surplus accounts. The amount that the insurer transfers depends on the risks associated with its invested assets: the riskier its invested assets, the larger the AVR the insurer must maintain. The ending balance of the AVR is reported on the statutory balance sheet as a liability.

 

Interest Maintenance Reserve

The interest maintenance reserve (IMR) is a reserve that helps absorb realized gains and losses on an insurer’s debt securities, such as bonds, mortgages, mortgage-backed securities, and preferred stock, when those gains or losses are caused by changes in market interest rates rather than changes in the credit quality of the assets. (Recall from Chapter 5 that we classified preferred stock as a hybrid security. For purposes of the IMR, however, preferred stock is considered to be a debt security.)

The IMR helps to protect an insurer’s net gain from operations and its capital and surplus from the effects of interest-rate risk. In this context, interest-rate riskis the risk that unpredictable movements in market interest rates will cause the value of a life insurer’s debt securities to change. The typical effects of changing market interest rates on an insurer’s debt securities are as follows:

  • When market interest rates increase, the value of an insurer’s debt securities generally decreases.

  • When market interest rates decrease, the value of an insurer’s debt securities generally increases.

Capital gains caused by changes in market interest rates increase the IMR, whereas capital losses caused by changes in market interest rates decrease the IMR.

After an insurer posts a realized gain or loss on an invested asset to the IMR, the insurer amortizes, or spreads out, the gain or loss into investment income for the remaining original term of that investment. As a result, the insurer reports only a portion of an invested asset’s gain or loss on the Statement of Operations in a given year. The insurer then transfers a portion of each capital gain or loss from the IMR to capital and surplus each year until, at the date the invested asset would have matured, the insurer has transferred the entire gain or loss to capital and surplus. Therefore, these capital gains and losses affect capital and surplus gradually, as if the insurer had held the asset until maturity. As with the AVR, the ending balance of the IMR is generally reported on the statutory balance sheet as a liability.

pages.title: Policyowner Dividends
pages.contents:
Policyowner Dividends

Policyowner dividends are another important liability for many life insurance companies. When an insurer’s actual experience on its products is more favorable than its expected experience, the insurer can refund money to participating policyowners. A policyowner dividend, also called a policy dividend, is the portion of an insurer’s surplus that is paid to participating policyowners and that is considered a partial refund of the policy premium that was not needed by the insurer for policy expenses.

Annual dividends on participating policies are generally payable on the policy anniversary date—the date on which coverage under an insurance policy became effective—after a policy has been in force for one or more years. Policyowner dividends are optional—that is, an insurer’s board of directors will declare these dividends only if the insurer’s financial results warrant them. In general, the board of directors declares policy dividends shortly before the end of the year.

The total amount of policyowner dividends payable on a particular product in each upcoming year is contingent upon several factors, including (1) the insurer’s financial performance with the product and (2) the number of policies still in force on their anniversary dates. Thus, the amount in Policyowner Dividends Payable, a liability account on the insurer’s balance sheet, is necessarily an estimate provided by the insurer’s actuaries. On U.S. GAAP-based financial statements, an insurer estimates the present value of all future policyowner dividends as a component of policy reserves for specific life insurance products. For U.S. statutory accounting purposes, the insurer estimates its policyowner dividend liabilities for only the next fiscal year.

 

Policyowner Dividend Liabilities

An insurer’s liabilities for policyowner dividends include (1) policyowner dividends due and unpaid, (2) policyowner dividends payable in the following calendar year, and (3) dividend accumulations.

 

Policyowner Dividends Due and Unpaid

Policyowner dividends due and unpaid represent those dividends payable to the policyowner in the current year that have not been disbursed or otherwise applied as of the financial reporting date for the current year. An insurer must establish a liability for policyowner dividends due and unpaid whenever the policyowner has earned the dividend but has not yet received it or applied it to a dividend payment option. Amounts recorded in the liability account Policyowner Dividends Due and Unpaid apply to the current year. These dividends have met all the criteria for payment, and the exact monetary amount of the dividends is known.

 

Policyowner Dividends Payable in the Following Calendar Year

Policyowner dividends payable in the following calendar year include two categories of dividends:

  • Dividends apportioned for payment are the estimated amount of all policyowner dividends declared by an insurance company’s board of directors prior to the end of the statement year that are not yet paid or due at the end of the year.

  • Dividends not yet apportioned for payment are all dividends payable in the following calendar year that have not been declared.

Amounts in the liability account Policyowner Dividends Payable in the Following Calendar Year are estimated on the basis of each policy’s anniversary date. Unlike the liability for policyowner dividends due and unpaid, the exact amount of the insurer’s liability for policyowner dividends payable in the following calendar year is unknown.

 

Dividend Accumulations

Dividend accumulations, also known as dividends left on deposit, result when a policyowner elects to leave policyowner dividends on deposit at interest with the insurer. The insurer establishes a liability for any dividend accumulations, as well as for the accrued interest on those accumulations.

 

Policyowner Dividend Payment Options

Owners of participating life insurance policies typically can select one of five policyowner dividend payment options, or dividend payment options, which enable participating policyowners to select the manner in which they want their policyowner dividends disbursed. The insurer pays the dividends to the policyowner according to the terms of the dividend payment option chosen.

The insight below summarizes the accounting treatment of common policyowner dividend payment options.

INSIGHT

Common Policyowner Dividend Payment Options

Policyowner Dividends Paid in Cash

When a policyowner elects to receive a dividend in cash, an insurer typically updates the dividend record—which is part of the policyowner master file—and records the appropriate accounting entries upon payment of the dividend.

A typical accounting entry to record the payment of a policyowner dividend is

Policyowner Dividends Paid in Cash………………………..xxx

Cash…………………………………………………………………….xxx

To record the payment of policyowner dividends.

Policyowner Dividends Applied to Pay Premiums

When a policyowner uses a dividend to reduce a policy premium, the insurer deducts the policyowner dividend from the premium due to determine the amount owed by the policyowner. The insurer records the accounting entry on the policy anniversary date. If the dividend is greater than the premium due, the policyowner can receive the excess in cash or apply it to another dividend payment option.

A typical accounting entry to record policyowner dividends applied to pay premiums due is

Policyowner Dividends Applied to Premiums………………………..xxx

Premium Income………………..……………………………………………….xxx

To record the application of a policyowner dividend to pay a current premium.

Policyowner Dividend Accumulations

For dividend accumulations, most insurers record the policyowner dividend and its accrued interest on the policy anniversary date—that is, the date on which the dividend becomes payable—provided the policy premiums have been paid to that date.

A typical accounting entry to record policyowner dividends applied to accumulate at interest with the insurer is

Policyowner Dividends Applied to Dividend Accumulations………..xxx

Dividend Accumulations..…………………………..…………………………….xxx

To record policyowner dividends applied to accumulate with the insurer at interest.

Note that this accounting entry records the initial deposit of the dividend. Separate accounting entries would record the interest earned on the dividend.

Policyowner Dividends Applied to Purchase Paid-Up Additions (PUAs)

When a policyowner uses a dividend to purchase paid-up additions (PUAs), the insurer determines the amount of the additional insurance purchased. The insurer then adds a rider to the basic policy to indicate the additional insurance coverage or treats the paid-up insurance as a separate policy.

A typical accounting entry to record policyowner dividends applied to buy PUAs is

Policyowner Dividends to Purchase PUAs………………………..xxx

Single Premiums for PUAs………………………………..…………….xxx

To record policyowner dividends applied to purchase paid-up additions.

Note that Single Premiums for PUAs is a type of premium income (revenue) account. We discuss revenue accounts in Chapter 10.

Policyowner Dividends Applied to Purchase One-Year Term Insurance

This policyowner dividend payment option is sometimes called the fifth dividend option. As with PUAs, the insurer adds a rider to the basic policy to indicate the additional insurance coverage or treats the paid-up insurance as a separate policy.

The entry to apply policyowner dividends to one-year term insurance is similar to that for PUAs, as shown below:

Policyowner Dividends to Purchase One-Year Term

Insurance..………………………..……………………………….……………..xxx

Single Premiums for One-Year Term Insurance ………………………….xxx

To record policyowner dividends applied to purchase one-year term insurance.

The insurer records accounting entries for the total monetary amount of all policyowner dividends being applied under each of the dividend payment options. After paying a dividend or applying it under a dividend payment option, the insurer updates its dividend record to provide a detailed history of each policy’s dividend transactions. The insurer uses this information to

  • Prepare summaries of dividend transactions for financial reporting purposes

  • Prepare lists by policy number for tracing dividend disbursements in case a policyowner should question whether she was sent a dividend or wants confirmation of how the dividend was applied

  • Facilitate audits by regulatory authorities

  • Report interest credited on policyowner dividends for income tax purposes
