pages.title: Nonforfeiture Values
pages.contents:
Nonforfeiture Values

When a life insurance policy lapses—that is, the policyowner stops paying premiums—the basic insurance contract terminates, except for those rights that the policyowner has under any nonforfeiture options. Nonforfeiture options are the various ways in which a policyowner can apply the cash value of a life insurance policy if the policy lapses. Nonforfeiture values are the benefits, such as cash or insurance, that the insurer guarantees to a policyowner if the insurance contract lapses. Nonforfeiture options can take the form of cash surrenders, reduced paid-up insurance, or extended term insurance.

 

Cash Surrender

When a policyowner has elected the cash surrender value option, insurance protection stops and the insurer calculates the cash surrender value owed to the policyowner. The insurer then remits this amount to the policyowner, and the company has no further obligation under the policy. A typical accounting entry to record the surrender of a life insurance policy is as follows:

Surrenders Paid—Life Insurance...........xxx

Cash......................…………………………....xxx

To record a life insurance policy cash surrender.

The debit to Surrenders Paid—Life Insurance typically decreases the insurer’s surplus because it immediately increases benefits paid, thereby reducing net income. However, a change in the liability for policy reserves occurs simultaneously.

The reserve for a policy must equal or exceed the policy’s cash surrender value. If the reserve equals the cash surrender value, the net effect of the surrender is an equal decrease in Cash, an asset account, and in Reserves, a liability account. The following example shows the net effect—an increase in surplus—of a cash surrender when the reserve is greater than the policy’s cash surrender value.

EXAMPLE

Example. Lydia is the policyowner of a life insurance policy with the Coral Life Insurance Company. Suppose Lydia surrenders her policy, which has a cash surrender value of $3,200. Coral’s released reserve for this policy totals $3,400.

In this case, there is a $200 increase in Coral’s Surplus account, all other factors remaining equal. Recall, however, that insurers do not usually make accounting entries each time transactions affect policy reserves. Therefore, the changes caused by the reserve released (shown in Coral’s very simplified balance sheet below) will not be recorded until Coral’s actuaries calculate actual reserves at the end of the accounting period.

Balance Sheet

Assets
-$3,200 Cash

Liabilities
-$3,400 Released Reserve

Capital and Surplus
+$200 Surplus


Reduced Paid-Up or Extended Term Insurance
 

Reduced Paid-Up or Extended Term Insurance

Because the accounting treatment of reduced paid-up and extended term insurance is similar, we discuss these two nonforfeiture options together. Under these options, the policy’s nonforfeiture value is applied as a premium to purchase paid-up term insurance, extended term insurance, or paid-up whole life insurance for the policyowner. When a policy continues under one of these options, with no dividend accumulations or policy loans outstanding, the insurer need not make an accounting entry. The transaction is simply a transfer of the policy’s reserve liability from a premium-paying classification to a paid-up insurance classification. The insurer makes accounting entries only if the policy had dividend accumulations or an outstanding policy loan at the time of surrender. The insurer also converts the policyowner master file from premium-paying status to paid-up status.

pages.title: Death Benefit Payments
pages.contents:
Death Benefit Payments

A death claim is a request for payment upon the death of the insured, under the terms and conditions of a life insurance policy. Supplementary contracts can also provide for payments. Typically, a supplementary contract, also known as a settlement contract, arises from the election of a settlement option by a life insurance beneficiary. Payments on supplementary contracts are typically called contractual payments. In this section, we discuss accounting and financial reporting for death benefit payments and contractual payments associated with life insurance policies. Typical accounts used to record and report death benefit payments include Death Benefit Payments, Death Claims Paid, or Claim Settlements.

To comply with statutory reporting requirements, insurers in the United States must list the total liability for unpaid life insurance claims—that is, any claims that are unpaid at the end of the accounting period—on the Liabilities, Surplus and Other Funds page of the Annual Statement. Examples of unpaid life insurance claims include claims that are in the course of settlement and claims that are in dispute. The amount of an insurer’s liabilities for claims reported in the financial statements usually equals the aggregate amount of all claims.

Most life insurance policies provide for payment of the policy’s face amount upon the insured’s death. However, in certain cases, the actual amount of the death benefit payable differs from the policy’s face amount. For example, universal life insurance policies may provide a benefit larger than the policy’s face amount. In these cases, the insurer makes adjustments to the amount payable to a policy beneficiary.

Figure 8.2 shows an overview of the death benefit payment process, including typical accounting entries that an insurer records at each step of the process.

 

Supplementary Contract Payments

As discussed earlier, a supplementary contract typically arises from the election of a settlement option by a life insurance beneficiary. In addition to the typical lump-sum settlement of policy proceeds, insurers provide settlement options, which are alternative methods that the beneficiary can elect for receiving payment of the policy proceeds. Typical settlement options for individual life insurance policies are the interest option, fixed period option, fixed amount option, and life income option.

The following example illustrates the accounting treatment for a supplementary contract.

EXAMPLE

Example. The Plume Life Insurance Company issued a $200,000 ordinary life insurance policy. Upon the death of the insured, the policy’s beneficiary decides to leave the policy proceeds on deposit with Plume under a supplementary contract that will provide the beneficiary with a monthly income for life. The accounting entry to establish this supplementary contract is as follows:

Death Claims Paid—Ordinary………….200,000

Consideration for Supplementary Contracts with
Life Contingencies…………..………………………..200,000

To record the establishment of a life insurance policy settlement option.

pages.title: Premium Liabilities
pages.contents:
Premium Liabilities

In certain situations, an insurer may need to record specified premium payments as liabilities. Some of these situations depend on the timing of the premium payments, whereas others depend on the type of product or contract to which the premiums apply.

 

Premium Suspense Accounts

The accounting entry to record an insurer’s receipt of a premium typically includes a debit to Cash. However, the insurer may not be able to determine immediately the credit entry to offset the debit to Cash. In such situations, many insurers use premium suspense accounts. In accounting terminology, a suspense account is an account that is used to record transactions that cannot be posted immediately to a specified account. Specifically, Premium Suspense is the liability account used to record transactions that are intended as premiums, but that the insurer cannot accept as income until a particular event occurs.

Theoretically, upon policy issue, there is little need for a premium suspense account. However, in practice, many insurers initially suspense all insurance premiums. Insurers typically use premium suspense accounts for premium payment amounts that are (1) renewal premiums, (2) different from the amounts in the insurer’s records, or (3) lacking critical information, such as a policy number. Another typical use of premium suspense accounts is in situations in which an insurer has received the initial premium for a policy but is still waiting for an underwriting decision on the policy.

A typical accounting entry to record such transactions is as follows:

Cash………………………..xxx

Premium Suspense…………………xxx

To record receipt of a premium payment that cannot be immediately recorded to a premium income account.

After the particular event occurs—for example, the insurer confirms the correct amount or policy number—the insurer can then debit the premium suspense account and credit a revenue account for the premium amount, as follows:

Premium Suspense………………….xxx

Premium Income……………………………xxx

To record a suspensed premium to a premium income account.

Note that the end result here is a debit to Cash and a credit to Premium Income.

 

Premiums Paid in Advance

When an insurer receives premiums before they are due, it reports a liability for premiums paid in advance on its U.S. GAAP and statutory financial statements. For life insurance contracts, premiums paid in advance, also called advance premiums, are premiums that an insurer has received but that are due on or after the next policy anniversary date.

Sometimes included in the category of premiums paid in advance are premium deposits, which, in this context, are amounts that an insurer’s policyowners leave on deposit with the insurer to pay for several years of premiums at one time. Because the insurer has the use of these policyowner funds before they are due, it typically discounts the premiums—in effect, receiving a smaller amount in cash. However, a more common approach with these premium deposits is to place them in a liability account known as a premium deposit fund. Under this approach, when an individual premium becomes due, the insurer pays it from the premium deposit fund and credits Premium Income.

 

Premiums for Deposit-Type and Investment Contracts

Under both SAP and GAAP, special rules apply to payments received for deposit-type contracts and investment contracts.

 

SAP Deposit-Type Contracts

Under SAP, deposit-type contracts are contracts that do not expose the insurer to mortality risk or morbidity risk. In this discussion, we focus on deposit-type contracts that lack a mortality risk component—in other words, contracts that provide benefit payments that do not depend upon the death or continued survival of an individual or group of individuals. Examples of deposit-type contracts are

  • Guaranteed interest contracts (GICs), also known as guaranteed investment contracts, in which the contract holder places one or more deposits with the insurer for a stated period in exchange for repayment of those deposits plus interest at a guaranteed rate. GICs are often used as funding vehicles for group retirement plans.

  • Annuities certain, which are contracts under which the insurer makes periodic payments to an individual over a specified period or in a specified amount.

  • Supplemental contracts without life contingencies, which are supplemental contracts under which the insurer holds the policy proceeds and makes payments to an individual—usually the policyowner or beneficiary—without regard to the life of the individual.

  • Dividend accumulations, which we discussed earlier in the chapter.

For deposit-type contracts, amounts received as payments are reported to the appropriate liability account on the insurer’s statutory balance sheet, known as Liability for deposit-type contracts. The rationale for this treatment is that these payments are accounted for as policyowner account balances, which means that policyowners have more discretion over deposits and withdrawals.

The Annual Statement provides detailed information about these contracts in Exhibit 7—Deposit-Type Contracts.

 

GAAP Investment Contracts

According to GAAP, long-duration contracts that do not expose the insurer to significant risks arising from policyowner or contract owner mortality are classified as investment contracts. Recall that a long-duration contract is one that is expected to remain in force for an extended period. Examples of investment contracts are

  • Guaranteed interest contracts

  • Most deferred annuity contracts during the accumulation phase

Under GAAP, accounting for investment contracts is similar to accounting for interest-bearing or other financial instruments where the balance accrues to the benefit of the policyowner or contract owner. According to this approach, premiums or deposits received for investment contracts are recorded as a deposit liability rather than as revenue. A typical GAAP account title for this liability is Funds held under deposit contracts.

 

Premiums for Universal Life Insurance

Unlike traditional whole life insurance policies, UL insurance policies have premiums, expenses, and interest credits that may not be fixed or guaranteed. While a UL policy is in force, the insurer credits premiums and interest to the policy’s account balance and subtracts various expenses from it. Technically, the policyowner owns this account balance. Therefore, according to the FASB, under GAAP, an insurer must treat premium payments for a UL policy as a liability, usually referred to as contract holder liabilities.

The chart below summarizes the situations in which an insurer may need to record premium payments as liabilities.

pages.title: Expenses Due or Accrued
pages.contents:
Expenses Due or Accrued

An insurer estimates its liability for expenses due or accrued for those goods and services it has received but for which the insurer has not yet paid as of the financial reporting date. Although incurred or paid expenses are expense accounts on the income statement, due or accrued expenses are liability accounts on the balance sheet. The following sections briefly discuss an insurer’s primary due or accrued expenses.

 

General Expenses

The liability account General Expenses Due or Accrued represents the monetary value of those goods or services an insurer has already received, but has not yet paid for as of the financial reporting date. Insurers must exercise a considerable amount of judgment to determine the amount of this liability. For the Annual Statement, insurers report as liabilities any expenses due and accrued from

  • Salaries and wages incurred but not yet paid

  • Contributions to employee benefit plans

  • Professional and service fees

  • Utility services used

  • Investment expenses

  • Claims incurred but not yet reported

Recall that, under U.S. GAAP, an insurer classifies certain policy-related costs as an asset account—Deferred Acquisition Costs (DAC)—and amortizes these costs over a specified period of time.

 

Agent (Producer) Commissions Due or Accrued

A commission is monetary compensation paid to an agent and is usually expressed as a percentage of the gross premiums paid by customers. Agent commissions that are due or accrued are a significant liability for most insurers. An agent’s commission is considered due or accrued when the insurer receives a premium too late in the accounting period to process the commission payment to the agent by the financial reporting date. Commissions are generally due or accrued only on premiums that have been received.

On an insurer’s balance sheet, commissions are classified as Agent Commissions Due or Accrued or Producer Commissions Due or Accrued. Most insurers maintain a separate file for each agent to track unpaid but owed commissions and report the cumulative amount to an aggregate liability account such as Agent Commissions Due or Accrued. Thus, Agent Commissions Due or Accrued or Producer Commissions Due or Accrued is the aggregate account that includes all such agent commissions that are due or accrued. Note that, when the insurer pays an agent due or accrued commissions, the aggregate liability account is decreased, as is the insurer’s cash.

Video 8.2 presents an example of how an insurance company uses the account known as Agent Commissions Due or Accrued.

The liability account Taxes, Licenses, and Fees Due or Accrued includes (1) items billed but not yet paid, such as business or agent licenses; (2) amounts payable but not yet billed, such as property taxes on real estate; and (3) estimates of amounts still owed for premium taxes, which are levied on premiums collected during the year. We discuss premium taxes as an expense in Chapter 10.

We have now covered two of the major account classifications on the balance sheet—assets and liabilities. That leaves us with the third and final one: owners’ equity, which includes two primary accounts: (1) capital and (2) surplus. Recall that

  • Capital represents the amount of money invested in a company by its owners, usually through the purchase of the company’s stock. As we discussed in Chapter 2, mutual insurers and fraternal insurers have no capital accounts because they do not issue stock.

  • Surplus—which is calculated as an insurer’s assets minus its liabilities and capital—is the cumulative amount of money that remains in a company over time. Recall from Chapter 2 that Surplus is an important account under SAP.

Capital and surplus accounts are classified as owners’ equity in the basic accounting equation, which follows:

Assets = Liabilities + Owners’ equity

For some purposes, the basic accounting equation is presented as follows:

Assets = Liabilities + Capital and Surplus

pages.title: Capital Accounts
pages.contents:
Capital Accounts

Stock insurers typically use capital accounts to record the issue or purchase of their own stock. The following sections describe an insurer’s typical capital accounts under GAAP, which include Common Stock, Preferred Stock, Additional Paid-in Capital, Retained Earnings, Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income, and Treasury Stock. This chapter also discusses various statutory accounts—such as Common Stock, Preferred Stock, and Treasury Stock—where appropriate.

 

Common Stock

Earlier, we discussed common stock as an invested asset from the point of view of an insurer that invests in the common stocks of other companies. Here, we discuss a stock insurer’s issue (sale) of its own common stock, which is recorded in the owners’ equity account called Common Stock. Stock insurers issue common stock to raise capital.

A typical accounting entry to record the issue and sale of an insurer’s common stock at par value is a debit to Cash and a credit to Common Stock. Recall that the par value of a stock is the designated legal value assigned to each outstanding share of stock.

Proceeds from the sale of an insurer’s common stock increase its cash and its owners’ equity. However, issuing (selling) common stock requires a stock insurer to pay transaction costs that reduce its net proceeds from the sale of the stock. In addition, some issuers of common stock pay regular cash dividends to owners of their stock. These companies must plan ahead to have funds available to make these dividend payments.

The following balance sheet illustrates the effects of issuing and selling the company’s own common stock:

Balance Sheet

Common Stock Issue and Sale

Assets

Increase

Liabilities

No change
 

Capital and Surplus

Increase

Preferred Stock

Recall that preferred stock usually carries a stated dividend rate that is paid before any payment of common stock dividends by the same company. Here, we discuss preferred stock from the perspective of those insurers that issue (sell) their own preferred stock. Thus, Preferred Stock is the owners’ equity account to which an insurer records the sales and repurchases of its own preferred stock. A typical accounting entry to record the issue and sale of the insurer’s preferred stock at par value is a debit to Cash and a credit to Preferred Stock.

The general characteristics of preferred stock as a source of financing are the same for stock insurance companies as they are for any other stock company and, in many ways, the same as the characteristics of common stock. Proceeds from the sale of an insurer’s preferred stock increase its owners’ equity just as do proceeds from the sale of common stock. In addition, a stock insurer that issues (sells) preferred stock must pay transaction costs that reduce its net proceeds from the sale of the stock.

In contrast to common stock dividends, preferred stock dividends are payable according to a schedule. The insurer’s board of directors may choose not to declare the payment of a scheduled dividend on preferred stock if the insurer’s circumstances—such as extreme financial distress—warrant such a choice.

Additional Paid-In Capital

If the selling price of the stock issue is greater than the stock’s par value, insurers in the United States also credit Additional Paid-In Capital (U.S. GAAP) or Gross Paid-In and Contributed Surplus (SAP) for the excess of the selling price over the par value. Retained Earnings

Recall that retained earnings represents the net income that an insurance company holds to reinvest in the company instead of paying the money out in dividends to its stockholders. Under U.S. GAAP, only specified transactions can directly increase or decrease the Retained Earnings account. These transactions include the amount of gains or losses from the company’s operations, dividends paid to stockholders, extraordinary items, and monetary adjustments that result from changes in accounting procedures. A detailed discussion of these transactions is beyond the scope of this textbook.

 

Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income

Recall from Chapter 4 that, under GAAP, other comprehensive income (OCI) consists of items that are not reported on the income statement because they have not been realized. At the end of each reporting period, the total of OCI is transferred to an owners’ equity account called Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income. This account appears on an insurer’s statement of owners’ equity, and its balance also appears on the owners’ equity section of the balance sheet.

 

Treasury Stock

In certain situations, a stock insurer may decide to repurchase or retire some of its outstanding stock. For example, a stock insurer that believes its stock is undervalued may decide to repurchase or retire some of the outstanding stock. After the purchase, the same equity interest is spread over fewer shares, which results in an increase in the price per share.

Treasury stock is stock that an insurer in the United States had previously issued (sold) and then later repurchased at its market price. Keep in mind that treasury stock refers to the insurer’s own stock—either common stock or preferred stock—not the stock of other companies that the insurer holds in one or more of its investment portfolios. The insurer can resell treasury stock on a stock exchange or through an employee compensation or retirement plan that enables employees to purchase shares of insurance company stock under specified conditions.

Under U.S. GAAP, the basic accounting entry to record the purchase of treasury stock, when the insurer intends to resell it at a later date, consists of a debit to Treasury Stock and a credit to Cash. The treasury stock’s par value is not a factor in the purchase transaction; however, it will be a factor if the insurer resells the treasury stock at a later date. The insurer establishes an additional paid-in capital account for treasury stock resale transactions to keep these transactions separate from issues (sales) of its common stock and preferred stock at greater than par value. Gains from the sale of treasury stock are reported on the statement of owners’ equity.

Treasury Stock is a contra account; specifically, it is a contra equity account, because its companion account—Common Stock—is an owners’ equity account. Recall that amounts in a contra account typically decrease the amount in the companion account. Therefore, increases in the amount in Treasury Stock decrease the amount in Common Stock, thus decreasing an insurer’s capital. For this reason, an insurer typically must obtain regulatory approval to purchase treasury stock.

If the insurer does not intend to reissue treasury stock, then the stock is called retired stock. Under U.S. GAAP, the basic accounting entry to record the purchase of treasury stock, when the insurer intends to retire the stock, is a debit to Treasury Stock, a debit to Additional Paid-In Capital—Treasury Stock, and a credit to Cash. In the case of retired stock, the insurer deducts the number of shares and their monetary value from the capital account.

Under statutory accounting, the purchase of treasury stock reduces an insurer’s total surplus. An insurer reports treasury stock at the bottom of the Liabilities, Surplus and Other Funds page, in the special section on capital and surplus.

pages.title: Surplus Accounts
pages.contents:
Surplus Accounts

Two important surplus accounts for insurers are Special Surplus and Unassigned Surplus.

 

Special Surplus

For insurers in the United States, special surplus, also called special surplus funds, assigned surplus, appropriated surplus, earmarked surplus, or contingency reserves, consists of the part of the insurer’s surplus that the insurer’s board of directors has set aside to (1) meet unforeseen contingencies or (2) pay for certain extraordinary expenses. Amounts in the Special Surplus account are not available for distribution to stockowners or policyowners, nor do they replace an insurer’s obligation to establish liabilities for expected occurrences.

The amount in an insurer’s Special Surplus can be voluntary or involuntary, depending on statutory requirements. In the case of voluntary special surplus funds, an insurer’s board of directors can designate the amount of special surplus. An insurer uses an involuntary special surplus account only for a specified purpose.

 

Unassigned Surplus

The Unassigned Surplus account under statutory accounting is similar to the Retained Earnings account under U.S. GAAP in that Unassigned Surplus represents the accumulation of income not paid out in dividends. For insurers in the United States, unassigned surplus, also called unassigned surplus funds, divisible surplus, or free surplus, is the total amount of undistributed and unapportioned surplus remaining in the insurance company since the company began operations.

Unassigned surplus is available to meet any contingency that arises, including new business, outstanding debt, or the purchase of treasury stock or retired stock. An insurer can also use unassigned surplus to satisfy a contingency that has since exhausted the special surplus fund the insurer originally established for that contingency or to pay operating expenses when a company experiences a net loss during a year.

When an insurer pays dividends to its owners, it withdraws them from unassigned surplus. However, the insurer’s ability to declare a dividend on its stock depends on the amount available in its Retained Earnings account (GAAP) or Unassigned Surplus account (SAP). Ultimately, the more dividends an insurer pays to its owners, the lower the amount of growth possible in Retained Earnings or Unassigned Surplus. States may require approval for an insurer to pay dividends to its owners. For example, state regulations could limit stockholder dividends to a proportion of the insurer’s Unassigned Surplus so that the insurer can maintain an adequate level of surplus.

Before declaring dividends to its owners, an insurance company’s board of directors uses Unassigned Surplus as one factor in determining the dividend amount. Two primary factors in determining the amount of Unassigned Surplus available for distribution to an insurer’s owners are (1) the amount of business that the insurer writes and (2) the contractual agreements that the insurer has, such as loan agreements that might affect its future financial situation. Once the board of directors has declared a stockholder dividend, it becomes a liability to the insurer.

pages.title: Sources and Uses of Funds for Capital and Surplus
pages.contents:
Sources and Uses of Funds for Capital and Surplus

Earlier in the text, we discussed the flow of funds in an insurance company. Recall that, in general, sources of funds result from cash inflows, or money coming into the company. In contrast, uses of funds generally result from cash outflows, or money going out of the company. These cash inflows (sources) and cash outflows (uses) affect an insurer’s asset accounts—especially its Cash account—as well as its owners’ equity accounts—in particular, Capital and Surplus.

An insurer may generate cash flows internally or externally. The following table presents the differences between internal sources and uses of funds and external sources and uses of funds.

Internal Sources and Uses of Funds

External Sources and Uses of Funds

Result from financial transactions originating in an insurer’s core business operations, including life insurance and annuity sales.

Result from financial transactions outside an insurer’s core business operations.

Sources of funds: Increase capital and surplus.

 

Uses of funds: Decrease capital and surplus.

Internal Sources and Uses of Funds for Capital and Surplus

Typical internal sources and uses of funds for life insurers include net income or a net loss, increases or decreases in admitted assets, and reserve strengthening and destrengthening.

Net Income or Net Loss

The primary source of surplus for most insurers is net income, which includes

  • Gains from core insurance operations. Insurers can increase capital and surplus when they earn profits from their operations—that is, their revenues are greater than their expenses.

  • Gains from the sale of invested assets. Insurers also increase net income and ultimately surplus by selling invested assets for a gain.

Similarly, a loss from core insurance operations or a loss on the sale of an invested asset would result in a decrease in an insurer’s capital and surplus.

Increases or Decreases in Admitted Assets

Recall that, under statutory accounting,

  • Admitted assets are assets whose full value is reported on the Assets page of the Annual Statement

  • Nonadmitted assets are assets that are reported on the Assets page of the Annual Statement but are accorded no value

Increases or decreases in an insurer’s admitted assets ultimately affect its capital and surplus accounts. Video 9.3 illustrates the effects that sales and purchases of nonadmitted assets have on an insurer’s capital and surplus.

Video 9.3 Effects of Nonadmitted Assets on Capital and Surplus

So far in this section, we have discussed single sales and purchases of nonadmitted assets. For a given reporting period, however, an insurer accounts for the total change in its nonadmitted assets as either a net increase or a net decrease:

  • A net increase in nonadmitted assets decreases the insurer’s capital and surplus.

  • A net decrease in nonadmitted assets increases the insurer’s capital and surplus.

 

Reserve Destrengthening and Reserve Strengthening

In general, an inverse relationship exists between changes in an insurer’s contractual reserves and changes in its surplus. Therefore, in general,

  • A decrease in an insurer’s contractual reserves increases the insurer’s surplus

  • An increase in the insurer’s contractual reserves decreases the insurer’s surplus

A detailed discussion of these effects is outside the scope of this textbook.

Figure 9.2 summarizes a life insurer’s typical internal sources and uses of funds for capital and surplus.

 

External Sources and Uses of Funds for Capital and Surplus

Some typical external sources and uses of funds for life insurers include ceding or assuming reinsurance, selling or purchasing in-force business, issuing and retiring stock, issuing and repaying surplus notes, and changing corporate form.

 

Ceding or Assuming Reinsurance

In certain situations, a direct writer that cedes insurance risk to a reinsurer is able to increase its capital and surplus. Recall that, under the terms of some types of reinsurance arrangements, the reinsurer assumes some of the direct writer’s liability for benefit payments and agrees to establish reserves for the reinsured portion of the risk. Because this use of reinsurance allows a direct writer to establish a lower amount of contractual reserves than it otherwise would, the direct writer’s surplus is higher than it would have been without the reinsurance.

In contrast, an insurer can serve as the reinsurer in a reinsurance transaction, assuming part or all of the risk from the direct writer. In this situation, the reinsurer’s surplus decreases because it has to increase its contractual reserves to cover the additional risk it has assumed. Simply put, if the insurer increases contractual reserves (a liability), all other factors remaining equal, then surplus (an owners’ equity account) must decrease to keep the basic accounting equation in balance.

 

Selling or Purchasing In-Force Business

Sometimes an insurer wishes to sell in-force business, perhaps to exit a current market or reduce its presence in a current market. An insurer that sells in-force business may be able to increase its capital and surplus. If the difference between the in-force business sold and the reserves released on that business produces a gain, then an insurer’s surplus increases.

Conversely, an insurer may decide to purchase in-force business from another insurer, perhaps to enter a new market or increase its presence in a current market. By purchasing in-force business from another insurer, an insurer typically experiences a decrease in its capital and surplus. The purchase decreases the insurer’s assets, or Cash account, and increases the insurer’s liabilities, because the insurer must establish reserves for the in-force business. To keep the basic accounting equation in balance, the insurer’s capital and surplus must decrease, as shown in the following balance sheet:

Balance Sheet: Insurer Purchases In-Force Business from Another Insurer

Assets

Decrease

Liabilities

Increase
 

Capital and Surplus

Decrease
 

Issuing and Retiring Stock

Recall that a stock insurer can increase its capital by issuing common stock or preferred stock; in this situation, the cash received from the sale of the stock is an external source of funds for the insurer. In contrast, a stock insurer decreases its capital and surplus by retiring its own stock; the cash the insurer pays to retire the stock is an external use of funds.

 

Issuing and Repaying Surplus Notes

In the United States, stock insurers have the option of raising capital by issuing stocks or bonds, but mutual insurers and fraternal insurers have neither of these options. Enter the surplus note—also known as a surplus debenture or a contribution certificate. A surplus noteis a special type of unsecured debt security issued only by insurance companies. All types of insurance companies in the United States can issue surplus notes. Although mutual insurers and fraternal insurers are the most common issuers of surplus notes, stock insurers sometimes issue them. For stock insurers, surplus notes represent a way of raising capital in addition to—or in lieu of—issuing common or preferred stock.

Insurers typically issue and sell surplus notes to raise money for normal business operations or for expansion purposes. The issuer of a surplus note (the insurer) agrees to make payments of principal and interest according to a fixed schedule. Issuing surplus notes is an external source of funds for an insurer.

One key advantage of issuing surplus notes is that, under statutory accounting, surplus notes are classified as Surplus; in other words, issuing surplus notes increases an insurer’s surplus, not its liabilities. In order to receive this treatment, though, an insurer’s surplus notes must receive approval from the insurance commissioner in the insurer’s state of domicile. As part of the approval process, the surplus notes must contain a provision stating that interest payments and principal repayments require prior approval of the commissioner of the state of domicile.

Under statutory accounting, an insurer records the proceeds from a sale of surplus notes using one accounting entry that shows an increase in the issuing company’s capital and surplus accounts, and another entry that shows an increase in Cash, with no changes in the insurer’s liabilities, as illustrated in the following statutory balance sheet:

Balance Sheet (under SAP)

Surplus Notes Issue and Sale

Admitted Assets

Increase in Cash

Liabilities

No change
 

Capital and Surplus

Increase in Surplus

For statutory accounting purposes, issuing surplus notes improves an insurer’s ability to pay claims on a timely basis, because the increases in both Cash and Surplus strengthen the insurer’s balance sheet. Note that this advantage does not exist under U.S. GAAP, which requires insurers to report surplus notes as liabilities, and not surplus.

As mentioned earlier, making interest payments or repaying principal on a surplus note requires regulatory approval. Once the insurer receives regulatory approval, it must expense all interest approved for payment in its Statement of Operations. In addition, as of the date of approval of a principal repayment, the insurer must reclassify the approved payments from surplus to liabilities.

The effect of repaying interest and principal on surplus notes is a decrease in assets (Cash) and a decrease in

  • Owners’ equity (Surplus Notes) under U.S. statutory accounting

  • Liabilities (Surplus Notes) under U.S. GAAP

Note that repaying surplus notes is an external use of an insurer’s funds.

An insurer that issues surplus notes is also required to disclose detailed information about them in the notes to its financial statements. Examples of this required information include

  • The date the surplus notes were issued

  • A description of the assets received for the notes

  • The holder of each note

  • The amount of each note

  • The rate at which interest accrues

  • Interest and/or principal paid in the current year

  • Total interest and/or principal paid on surplus notes

 

Changing Corporate Form

To grow and increase capital, insurers can restructure the corporate form in various ways, such as through

  • Mergers, acquisitions, takeovers, and divestitures. Mergers, acquisitions, and takeovers typically combine formerly independent entities. For example, after a merger, the combined company typically has greater owners’ equity than either company had prior to the merger. The combined company’s assets, liabilities, and owners’ equity are reported using valuations as of the date of the merger.

  • Demutualization. Mutual insurance companies have limited access to capital markets. Therefore, they must rely primarily on premium income and investment income (both classified as revenues) to generate enough net income to increase their owners’ equity. For this reason, some mutual insurers have chosen demutualization—the process of converting a mutual insurance company to a stock insurance company—to compete more effectively in the capital markets. By demutualizing, a mutual insurer gains access to capital sources—such as the issue of common stock—available to stock insurers.

  • Financial holding companies. The primary impact of the United States federal legislation known as the Gramm-Leach-Bliley (GLB) Act of 1999 is that the traditionally separate components of the financial services industry—banks, securities firms, and insurance companies—can now structurally converge under the umbrella of a federally chartered financial holding company. The financial holding company can engage in a statutorily provided list of financial activities that were formerly divided by regulation.

pages.title: Revenues
pages.contents:
Revenues

Recall from Chapter 2 that revenue, often referred to as income, represents the amount of earnings from a company’s core business operations. Insurers typically have two primary sources of revenue: premium income and investment income. Fee income is another source of revenue. Revenue accounts, also called income accounts, are the accounts used to record and report a company’s revenues. An insurance company complies with accounting and financial reporting requirements by classifying its premium income, investment income, and fee income by individual or group product line and by product type: life, accident and health, credit life, and annuities. Thus, insurers typically credit one of several revenue accounts according to the revenue source, product line, and product type.

For example, when a policyowner remits a renewal premium for a life insurance policy, the accounting entry might include a debit to Cash and a credit to an account such as Premium Renewals—Individual Life. This specific account enables the insurer to identify the source of revenue (premium income) and the product line and type (individual life insurance).

The actual account names can and do vary among insurance companies. However, most revenue accounts have self-explanatory names, such as Premium Income—Group Life Insurance, Annuity Income—Deferred, Investment Income—Bond Interest, and Dividend Income—Common Stock. Note that an insurer’s income statement also includes any secondary sources of revenue not classified as premium, investment, and fee income, such as considerations for structured settlements and premiums for reinsurance assumed. Discussion of additional sources of insurance company revenues is beyond the scope of this textbook.

For an income statement prepared according to U.S. GAAP, insurers report income that has been earned during the accounting period. Other types of income that have not yet been earned or received are reported as assets or liabilities on the balance sheet. Figure 10.1 lists and describes these types of income.

Watch Video 10.1 to see how several of these types of income might apply to a single policy.

Premium Accounting

Premium transactions usually comprise the largest number of an insurer’s accounting entries. Premium accounting, sometimes called policy accounting, is the maintenance of detailed accounting records and reports of insurance premium transactions, such as premium billing and collections. Premium income includes premiums that an insurer receives from the various product lines that it sells as well as any reinsurance premiums that the insurer receives from providing reinsurance coverage.

Insurers use many different types of premium accounting systems, which reflect differences in company organization, management preferences, and products. For example, some insurance companies centralize premium collections at the home office. Other companies have regional offices or several collection centers throughout their marketing areas. Nonetheless, the primary function of a premium accounting system is to apply premiums to the appropriate accounts as soon as the insurer receives the premiums.

The most important objectives of an insurer’s premium accounting system are to

  • Bill for premiums before their due date, with sufficient lead time between the billing and due dates

  • Record the receipt of premiums in the premium accounting system

  • Classify premium income by product type, jurisdiction, and other specified categories so that the insurer can use the data to calculate taxable income and prepare financial statements by line of business

  • Accept premium payments after the expiration of the grace period under circumstances acceptable to the insurer

  • Terminate a policy or change the policy from a premium-paying status to a specified nonforfeiture option, if the policyowner has not paid the premium

Figure 10.2 depicts the general process of premium accounting at policy issue and policy renewal, including the steps an insurer takes if it chooses to record the initial premium in a suspense account.

Generally, the receipt of policy premiums increases both an insurer’s revenues and its assets. Premiums are usually deposited in the insurer’s bank account upon receipt. This practice provides for good accounting and makes the funds available for investment. The accounting treatment of premium income directly affects an insurer’s financial statements, particularly the cash flow statement, which reports all changes in cash from normal business operations. By monitoring policy premium receipts, an insurer can generate automated premium notices and past-due warnings with precise timing, as well as change a policy’s status from premium paying to non–premium paying.

The basic accounting entry to record the receipt of premium income on most insurance products is a debit to Cash, an asset account, and a credit to a revenue account, such as Premium Income:

Cash……………………xxx

Premium Income………………….xxx

To record the receipt of premium income.

Recall that some insurers initially place premiums in a suspense account upon receipt by debiting Cash and crediting Premium Suspense in the first accounting entry. In such cases, a second accounting entry is made to debit Premium Suspense and to credit a premium income account once the insurer determines where the premium belongs. Note that the ultimate effect of these two accounting entries is a debit to Cash and a credit to Premium Income.

Premium accounting systems calculate premium income on an accrual basis. The purpose of this calculation is to determine the amount of premium income that the insurer earned during the fiscal year. This amount generally differs from the amount of premium income the insurer collected during the same period. This difference is due to various adjustments to income resulting from unearned premiums and premium income that is due but has not been received by the financial reporting date. Recall from Chapter 8 that premium income may in some cases be classified as a liability under U.S. SAP and GAAP.

 

Investment Income Accounting

A company’s investment income consists of the earnings the company receives on the invested assets it owns. Typical sources of investment income for insurers are

  • Interest income on policy loans, bonds, and mortgages

  • Rental income on real estate

  • Cash dividends on stock owned by the insurer

Income earned on an insurer’s invested assets is usually the insurer’s second largest source of revenues after premium income. In some insurance companies, the amount of investment income exceeds that of premium income. Note that investment income does not include gains or losses—whether realized or unrealized—associated with an insurer’s invested assets.

Account titles for investment income vary among insurers, although they are usually self-explanatory. For example, one insurer may have an account called Investment Income—Bonds. Another insurer may call this account Interest Income—Bonds. Regardless of the account title, an insurer records in its investment income accounts all income earned and received on the invested assets that it owns.

A typical accounting entry to record the receipt of investment income is a debit to Cash, an asset account, and a credit to one or more investment income accounts, which are revenue accounts, as shown in the following example:

Cash……….xxx

Interest Income—Willow Bonds……………xxx

To record interest income received on Willow bonds owned by the insurer.

Insurers recognize investment income on an accrual basis to comply with financial reporting requirements under SAP and GAAP. Gross investment income is the accrual-basis amount of investment income, representing the total amount of income an insurer earned during the reporting period, before deducting expenses and amortization. Net investment income is the accrual-basis amount of investment income that remains after deducting expenses and amortization from an insurer’s gross investment income. In notes to their financial statements or supplementary schedules that accompany the statements, insurers typically categorize net investment income by investment type—such as bonds or mortgages—and type of income—such as interest or dividends. Recall from Chapter 6 that, under U.S. statutory accounting principles, insurers report the amount of earned investment income that has not yet been received under Investment Income Due and Accrued, an asset account. When the insurer receives the earned income, it records the amount of the income as a debit to Cash and a credit to Investment Income Due and Accrued.

The basic accounting entry used to record premium income on most insurance products consists of a (debit / credit) to an asset account, such as Cash, and a (debit / credit) to a revenue account, such as Premium Income.

pages.title: Expenses
pages.contents:
Expenses

Insurers incur expenses while conducting normal business operations, especially in the course of generating revenues. Contractual benefit payments are typically the largest expense for insurers. Thus, life insurance companies allocate a large portion of each premium dollar for contractual benefits. The remaining portion of each premium dollar must cover the insurer’s operating expenses and allow for a contribution to surplus. This section focuses on an insurer’s typical operating expenses. We also briefly discuss several insurance-specific taxes. Figure 10.3 highlights an insurer’s major expenses.

Insurers record each type of expense in a specified expense account. When an insurer pays a particular expense, the insurer debits the appropriate expense account and credits Cash. Insurers summarize their expenses on the income statement at the end of each reporting period. Insurers typically maintain a separate expense account for each type of operating expense. Similar to revenue account names, account names for expenses are generally self-explanatory, such as Agent Renewal Commissions, Public Accounting Expense, and Death Benefits Paid.

 

Contractual Benefit Expenses

Recall that an insurer’s primary liabilities are its contractual reserves, which are the amounts the insurer expects to pay for current and future contractual benefits to policyowners and beneficiaries. Contractual benefits include death benefits, cash surrenders, and annuity benefit payments. When an insurer sells an insurance policy or annuity contract, the insurer becomes legally obligated to pay the benefit amount associated with that product if certain conditions are met.

Contractual benefit expenses are an example of an insurer’s (investment expenses / general and administrative expenses).

  1.

Operating Expenses

Insurers also incur operating expenses that are similar to those incurred by noninsurance companies. Operating expenses, such as acquisition, development, maintenance, and overhead expenses, arise in the normal course of conducting business. Although insurers can readily identify the amount of contractual benefit expenses and agent compensation expenses incurred by product type or line of business, it is more difficult to determine what portion of the insurer’s operating expenses applies to a particular product. One important aspect of accounting for expenses concerns the allocation of operating expenses. In accounting, to allocate an amount is to distribute the amount proportionally among several accounts. The U.S. Annual Statement requires insurers to allocate operating expenses by lines of business.

A common method of allocating expenses is based on the amount of premium income for each line of business. First, the insurer determines what percentage of total premium income each line of business earned for the reporting period. Next, the insurer multiplies total operating expenses by that percentage to calculate the amount of operating expenses to allocate to each line of business. Keep in mind that, for agent commissions and other expenses that can easily be directly attributed to a specified product, expense allocation is unnecessary. Watch Video 10.2 for an example of allocating operating expenses.

Under U.S. statutory accounting principles, expenses such as costs for new products are recognized during the reporting period in which they occur. However, recall that, under U.S. GAAP, certain types of new business costs may be classified as deferred acquisition costs, in which case insurers capitalize these costs and amortize them over several years. The following sections discuss agent commissions and salaries and reinsurance allowances. We also separately discuss an insurer’s typical operating expenses related to taxes.

 

Agent Commissions

Agent commissions are typically a large expense for insurers. Insurers that use agents to sell individual life insurance products typically pay the agents on a commission basis. Insurers must have an accounting system that can accurately record and report commissions and salaries incurred in summary form and by product type, regardless of the agent distribution system they use. An insurer’s income statement typically contains summary information that shows the total amount of commissions earned by and paid to all agents. An insurer’s internal accounting records contain detailed information about each agent’s commissions. The objectives of commission accounting are to

  • Calculate the amount of commissions payable to each agent

  • Record commissions payable to each agent

For financial reporting purposes, an insurance company establishes a control account for each incurred commission expense. A control account summarizes accounting entries and monitors the expenses that are reported in a company’s financial statements. A typical control account, called Agents Ledger Control or Producers Ledger Control, includes commissions an insurer owes to agents as well as amounts that agents owe to the insurer. The amount of money owed by an insurer to an agent is an account payable, which is a short-term liability because the insurer expects to pay the agent within the current accounting period.

The amount of money owed by an agent to an insurer, often called Agent Balances Due or Producer Balances Due, is a type of account receivable. This account is a short-term asset account, because the insurer expects to receive this amount within the current accounting period. An agent may owe an insurer money because she may have received some form of income during her first months with the insurer as an advance against future commissions. In addition, an agent may owe an insurer for commissions that were paid on policies that subsequently lapsed. Under statutory accounting principles, agent balances due more than a specified length of time are generally considered a nonadmitted asset.

Several types of accounting entries occur frequently in connection with agent commissions. Note, however, that insurers do not typically withhold taxes from commissions, although they do withhold taxes from payments to salaried employees, including salaried agents. The following is an example of how an insurer typically accounts for agent commissions.

EXAMPLE

Example. When a Wisdom Life Insurance Company agent earns a commission, Wisdom records an accounting entry to show that it has incurred the commission expense and has established a liability for the commission owed to the agent:

Commissions Expense………………………………..xxx

Agents Ledger Control………………………………………….xxx

To record incurred agent commissions expense.

Upon payment of the earned commission to the agent, Wisdom records the following accounting entry:

Agents Ledger Control………………....xxx

Cash………………………………..………….xxx

To record the payment of agent commissions.

The combined effect of the two transactions is an increase in an expense account—Commissions Expense—and a corresponding decrease in an asset account—Cash.

Some insurance companies also pay commission bonuses to agents for exceeding target production levels. These bonuses usually represent a commission expense for insurers. The accounting entries to record these commission bonuses are similar to the transactions to record commissions earned and paid.

 

Agent Salaries

Most life insurance companies have a distribution system that relies primarily on commissioned agents. However, some insurers, especially direct response companies and group life insurers, rely on salaried agents or producers. An insurer may provide a salary or similar financial assistance to an agent while the agent establishes a client base. An insurer may also utilize branch office or field office managers to whom the insurer provides both a salary and additional compensation for developing an agency office.

In the case of salaried agents, an insurer is required to withhold payroll taxes, just as the insurer does for other salaried employees. A detailed discussion of payroll accounting is beyond the scope of this textbook. You should know, however, that payroll taxes withheld by an insurer are recorded in liability accounts. These liability accounts represent amounts that the insurer has collected on behalf of a governmental body and thus is obligated to pay. When the insurer pays taxes, the insurer debits the appropriate liability account and credits Cash. The effect of paying taxes to a governmental body decreases both the tax liability account and Cash. The following example shows how an insurer accounts for payments to its salaried employees.

EXAMPLE

Example. Suppose a salaried agent at the Query Life Insurance Company, a U.S. company, earns a $1,200 monthly salary. From this salary, $120 must be withheld for federal income taxes, $90 must be withheld for Social Security and Medicare, and $25 must be withheld for state income taxes. Query’s accounting entry to establish liabilities for federal and state taxes and the amount payable to this agent is as follows:

Salaries Expense…………1,200

Federal Income Taxes Payable………………………..120

Social Security and Medicare Taxes Payable……..90

State Income Taxes Payable…………………………..…25

Salaries Payable………………………………………….….965

To record the establishment of a liability for an agent’s salary and the appropriate tax withholdings.

The accounting entry records Query’s liability for taxes withheld as $235 ($120 + $90 + $25) and records the salary payable to the agent as $965 ($1,200 – $235). Thus, the amount payable to the agent equals the salary expense minus any withholdings.

When Query pays the agent’s salary, it makes the following accounting entry:

Salaries Payable………………………………………….965

Cash…………………………………………………………….965

To record the payment of an agent’s salary.

When the company then pays the state income taxes withheld from the agent’s salary, the appropriate accounting entry is:

State Income Taxes Payable…………..25

Cash………………………………………………25

To record the payment of state income taxes withheld from an agent’s salary.

Some salaried agents receive a year-end bonus for generating new business and maintaining that business. The insurer treats a salaried agent’s bonus as part of his salary and withholds the appropriate amounts for tax purposes, as with salary payments. For financial reporting purposes, the insurer maintains separate accounting records for each salaried employee and for each agent who receives a combination of salary and commission payments.

 

Reinsurance Allowances and Premiums

Recall that, in reinsurance transactions, the company that purchases reinsurance is the direct writer or ceding company, and the insurer that assumes the reinsurance is the reinsurer or assuming company. If a direct writer cedes part of the insurance risk on a block of insurance policies to a reinsurer, then the direct writer pays periodic premiums to the reinsurer. Commissions that the reinsurer pays to the direct writer are called reinsurance allowances, also known as reinsurance commissions, which are payments intended to cover all or part of the direct writer’s acquisition costs and other costs related to the reinsured business. In effect, the reinsurer pays a commission on this new business, just as any insurer pays a commission to an agent for new business. In such situations, the reinsurer pays the commission to the direct writer, rather than to an agent.

An example of accounting for reinsurance premiums follows.

EXAMPLE

Example. Suppose the Lexicon Life Insurance Company cedes $300,000 of a block of ordinary life policies to Strawberry Re. If the reinsurance agreement specifies a reinsurance premium of $1,000 and a reinsurance allowance of $750, then to record payment of the reinsurance premium, Lexicon makes the following accounting entry:

Reinsurance Ceded—First-Year Premium Expense…….....1,000

Reinsurance Allowance—Ceded………..……………….…………..750

Cash…………………………………………………………..……...……..…250

To record the payment of the reinsurance premium.

Strawberry Re records the receipt of the reinsurance premium income as follows:

Reinsurance Allowance—Assumed……………............…...……..750

Cash………………………………………………………………………..…….250

Reinsurance Assumed—First-Year Premium Expense ……1,000

To record the receipt of reinsurance premium income, net of allowance.

 

Premium Taxes

Premium taxes are taxes on the paid premium income an insurer receives within a particular jurisdiction. The definition of what constitutes paid premium income for tax purposes varies among jurisdictions. For example, some U.S. states impose the tax on gross premiums. Most states allow insurers to deduct policyowner dividends from their gross premiums before calculating premium taxes. In addition, investment income and reinsurance premiums are typically excluded from the formula that determines the amount of premium taxes due from an insurer.

State governments impose premium taxes on life insurance policies issued in that state. Taxing authorities calculate these taxes as a percentage of the premium income. Some states require that the insurer pay the larger of the premium tax or the state income tax.

Fraternal benefit societies are typically exempt from premium taxes. In addition, many U.S. states do not impose premium taxes on annuity considerations, which are sometimes called annuity premiums. Annuity considerations are sometimes taxed at a lower rate than insurance premiums in those states that impose premium taxes on annuity considerations.

Accounting for premium taxes requires two basic sets of accounting entries: one to record taxes incurred and another to record the payment of the tax. Typically, when an insurer incurs premium taxes, the insurer makes the following accounting entry:

Premium Tax Expense……xxx

Premium Taxes Payable……xxx

To record incurred premium taxes.

Here, the insurer debits an expense account—Premium Tax Expense—and credits a liability account—Premium Taxes Payable—for the amount of premium taxes incurred. Upon payment of premium taxes, the insurer then makes a second accounting entry, as follows:

Premium Taxes Payable…….xxx

Cash…………………………………….xxx

To record the payment of premium taxes.

alt:
Investment expenses are the costs associatedwith investing the insurer’s assets.

General and administrative expenses are thecosts incurred as a result of undertaking normal business activities togenerate sales and to support products. General and administrative expensesinclude contractual benefit expenses and operating expenses.

Contractual benefit expenses are the costs ofpaying contractual obligations to policyowners and beneficiaries.

Operating expenses are the costs of businessoperations other than contractual benefit expenses. Operating expensesinclude acquisition expenses, maintenance expenses, development expenses,and overhead expenses.

Acquisition expenses are the costs for optainingand issuing new business. Examples of acquisition expenses include first-yearagent commissions, contract issue expenses, advertising expenses, and underwritingexpenses.

Maintenance expenses are product-related coststhat are incurred on in-force policies and contracts. Examples of maintenanceexpenses include renewal commissions, some agency or branch office expenses,and customer service operating expenses.

Development expenses are costs related to designing,testing, and implementing a new product. Examples of development expensesinclude new administrative software expenses and new business license fees.

Overhead expenses are the costs of normal businessoperations that are not directly connected with any product. Examples ofoverhead expenses include utility expenses, some agency or branch officeexpenses, and some information systems expenses.

Financial Ratio Analysis

A ratio is a comparison of two numeric values expressed in the form of a fraction or a percentage. Here’s a simple example.

EXAMPLE

Example. When Charles went to work today, he had four major tasks to do by the end of the day. By 3:00, he had completed three of the tasks.

Analysis. In fraction form, Charles has completed ¾ of his tasks. To turn this fraction into a percentage, you would calculate 3 ÷ 4, which equals 0.75, and then multiply this by 100, to get 75%. So, by 3:00, Charles had completed 75% of his tasks for the day.

In general, financial ratio results of less than 1 are expressed as a percentage—for example, a result of 0.05 is presented as 5 percent. On the other hand, ratio results of 100 percent or more are typically expressed as a number—for example, a result of 500 percent would be presented as 5.

When a ratio is expressed in fraction form, the number in the top part of the fraction is the numerator and the number in the bottom part of the fraction is the denominator:

Ratio = Numerator
Denominator

Figure 11.1 summarizes the rules for interpreting changes in ratios when the ratios are expressed as fractions. We apply these rules later when we discuss specific types of ratios.

Financial ratio analysis, also called ratio analysis, consists of calculating the relationships between various pairs of financial statement values. The purpose of financial ratio analysis is to assess a company’s financial condition or performance. For example, financial ratio analysis can

  • Indicate changes or trends in a company’s operating performance

  • Help to identify a company’s strengths and weaknesses

  • Answer yes/no questions, such as whether the company’s short-term obligations can be paid on time and whether the company is collecting enough in premiums to cover its claims

An insurance company’s management uses financial ratios to measure performance at all levels of the company. In this case, the managers are engaged in internal analysis, which is financial ratio analysis undertaken by employees of the company being analyzed.

In contrast, external analysis is financial ratio analysis performed by someone outside of the company being analyzed. The regulatory ratios that we discussed in Chapter 1—IRIS ratios and the risk-based capital (RBC) ratio—are both examples of external analysis, in this case used to evaluate insurer solvency. Other stakeholders that perform external analysis include

  • Rating agencies, which need to determine the rating to assign to a particular insurance company

  • Insurance company stockholders and other investors, who need to evaluate the company’s overall profitability

  • Policyowners, who need to be able to evaluate the financial strength of insurers from whom they purchase policies

  • Reinsurers, which need to determine whether to enter into a reinsurance arrangement with a particular insurer

  • Independent agents, who need to be able to assess the financial strength of the insurers whose products they sell

Sometimes internal analysis and external analysis are combined. For example, within an insurer’s marketing department, the competitive intelligence area may take the insurer’s financial ratio results and compare them to those of the insurer’s major competitors.

In this chapter, we discuss types of financial ratios commonly used in the life insurance industry. We categorize these ratios according to what they measure:

  • Liquidity

  • Operating performance

  • Leverage

  • Capital and surplus adequacy

  • Profitability

Throughout the chapter, we illustrate the different types of ratios by applying them to a fictional U.S. stock insurer, the Evergreen Life Insurance Company. The data for these ratios comes from Evergreen’s statutory and GAAP-based financial statements.

 

Liquidity

In Chapter 2, we defined liquidity as the ease with which an asset can be converted into cash for an approximation of its underlying value. Recall that insurers must have enough cash and other liquid assets when needed to pay their contractual benefits and general business expenses on time. For insurers, illiquidity—that is, the lack of liquidity—means that an insurer lacks sufficient cash, which is not an option for an insurer, even on a short-term basis. On the other hand, highly liquid assets produce little or no return. Thus, excessive liquidity damages profits. The goal for insurance companies is to maintain a moderate level of overall liquidity. So, what’s a “moderate level”? We explain this phrase in a minute.

Liquidity ratios measure a company’s ability to meet its maturing short-term obligations. The basic liquidity ratio contains assets in the numerator and liabilities in the denominator.

Liquidity ratio = Assets
Liabilities
 

Current Ratio

The current ratio, which compares an insurer’s current assets to its current liabilities, indicates an insurer’s ability to satisfy short-term obligations without having to sell long-term investments or borrow money.

Current ratio = Current assets
Current liabilities

Recall from Chapter 2 that

  • Short-term assets—or current assets—are assets that an insurer expects to readily convert into cash or consume within the current accounting period, typically one year. For insurers, current assets include cash and cash equivalents.

  • Short-term liabilities—or current liabilities—are financial obligations that a company must pay in one year or less. A significant portion of an insurer’s current liabilities are contractual benefit obligations expected to come due within one year.

Now let’s look at the phrase “moderate level of overall liquidity.” In terms of the current ratio, life insurers generally aim for a value of at least 1.0. A current ratio result of 1.0 indicates that an insurer’s current assets equal its current liabilities. What if the value for this ratio is less than 1.0? In this case, the insurer has less in current assets than it has in current liabilities. This insurer could be forced to sell long-term or less liquid investments at a discount or borrow money to satisfy its short-term obligations.

What about values of greater than 1.0? An insurer with a current ratio result of 2.0 has twice as much in current assets as it has in current liabilities. Remember, though, that an insurer doesn’t want the value of this ratio to be too high, because a high value typically indicates that the insurer is holding too much in current assets, which don’t provide much of a return.

So far, we’ve been discussing the values of the current ratio at a single point in time. However, insurers and analysts generally track the changes in the current ratio over time. For example, an increase in the value of a current ratio between two consecutive balance sheet dates generally indicates that the insurer has more liquidity now than during the previous reporting period. An increase in the value of the current ratio results when there is (1) an increase in the value of current assets in the numerator and/or (2) a decrease in the value of current liabilities in the denominator.

EXAMPLE

Example. In 2018, Evergreen had current assets of $9,900,000 and current liabilities of $11,000,000.

Analysis. For 2018, Evergreen’s current ratio was 0.90, found as $9,900,000 ÷ $11,000,000. In 2017, Evergreen’s current ratio was 1.25, so Evergreen had lower liquidity in 2018 than it had in 2017.

Analysts also find it helpful to compare one company’s ratio results with that of another.

EXAMPLE

Example. In 2018, the Poplar Life Insurance Company had current assets of $12,000,000 and current liabilities of $6,000,000.

Analysis. Poplar’s current ratio for 2018 was 2.0, found as $12,000,000 ÷ $6,000,000, which means that Poplar had greater liquidity in 2018 than did Evergreen, all other factors remaining equal.

 

Nonadmitted Assets Ratio

Another liquidity ratio that insurers use is the nonadmitted assets ratio, which compares an insurer’s nonadmitted assets to its surplus.

Nonadmitted assets ratio = Nonadmitted assets
Surplus

Recall that, under SAP, nonadmitted assets comprise an insurer’s highly illiquid assets. Therefore, this ratio measures the extent to which an insurer’s asset portfolio may be illiquid. In general, the lower the value for this ratio, the better, because a lower value indicates that the insurer has a smaller amount of nonadmitted, or highly illiquid, assets.

EXAMPLE

Example. Use the following statutory data for 2018 to calculate the nonadmitted assets ratios for Evergreen and Poplar:

Annual Statement Value Evergreen Poplar
Nonadmitted Assets $172,800 $200,000
Surplus $2,880,000 $5,000,000

Analysis. For 2018, Evergreen’s nonadmitted assets ratio was 0.06, or 6%, found as $172,800 ÷ $2,880,000. Poplar’s nonadmitted assets ratio was 0.04, or 4%, found as $200,000 ÷ $5,000,000. Because it was lower, Poplar’s nonadmitted assets ratio would be considered better than Evergreen’s ratio, all other factors remaining equal.

In general, a value of at least 1.0.

Operating Performance

Insurers use several types of ratios to measure their operating performance, such as the general expense ratio, the benefits ratio, and the lapse and surrender ratio. The first two ratios indicate how an insurer’s products are performing, by comparing expenses or benefits paid to premium income. The lapse and surrender ratio measures how well the company is doing in retaining its customers.

Insurers generally use statutory data to calculate these three ratios, because this data is more conservative than is GAAP data.

 

General Expense Ratio

For insurance companies, the general expense ratio expresses, for a given reporting period, an insurer’s general insurance expenses as a percentage of premiums, annuity considerations, and considerations on supplementary contracts with life contingencies. General insurance expenses include such items as rent, salaries and wages, legal fees, medical examination fees, advertising, and rental of equipment. Note that contractual benefit expenses are not a component of general insurance expenses.

General expense ratio = General insurance expenses
Premiums and considerations

Analysts use general expense ratios to compare insurers, as well as to analyze an insurer’s performance over time. In general, the lower the general expense ratio, the better. For example, a general expense ratio below 100 percent indicates that the insurer is collecting more premiums and considerations than it is paying out in general insurance expenses. Conversely, an insurer that has a general expense ratio above 100 percent is paying out more in general insurance expenses than it is collecting in premiums and considerations. In recent years, average general expense ratios for life insurers have ranged from 8.5 percent to 10.0 percent. 1

EXAMPLE

Example. Use the following statutory data to calculate the general expense ratios for Evergreen and Poplar:

2018 Statement Value Evergreen Poplar
General Insurance Expenses $700,000 $975,000
Premiums and Considerations $7,000,000 $6,500,000

Analysis. For 2018, Evergreen’s general expense ratio was 0.10, or 10%, found as $700,000 ÷ $7,000,000, whereas Poplar’s general expense ratio was 0.15, or 15%, found as $975,000 ÷ $6,500,000. These results indicate that Evergreen’s expenditures were less of a percentage of new premiums written than were Poplar’s. In addition, Poplar’s results exceed the typical range in the industry, indicating that it is not managing its general insurance expenses as well as most other life insurers.

 

Benefits Ratio

For life insurance companies, the benefits ratio compares, for a reporting period, the benefits paid by an insurer to premiums, annuity considerations, and considerations on supplementary contracts with life contingencies.

Benefits ratio = Benefits paid
Premiums and considerations

Examples of benefits paid include death benefits on life insurance policies, benefit payments on annuities, and disability benefits.

For this ratio, insurers typically aim for a result of less than 90 percent, and the recent industry average ranges from 40 percent to 45 percent. 2

EXAMPLE

Example. In 2018, Evergreen’s benefits paid were $2,940,000, and its premiums and considerations were $7,000,000.

Analysis. For 2018, Evergreen’s benefits ratio was 0.42, or 42%, found as $2,940,000 ÷ $7,000,000. For 2018, Evergreen’s benefits ratio fell within the range for the industry average.

 

Lapse and Surrender Ratio

Another important ratio for insurers is the lapse and surrender ratio, which compares the number of life insurance policies or annuity contracts that either lapsed or were surrendered during the current year to the average number of policies in force during the current year.

Lapse and surrender ratio = # of policies lapsed or surrendered during current year
Average number of policies in force during current year

where

Average number of policies in force during current year = (Number of policies in force at end of prior year + Number of policies in force at end of current year)
2

In this context, a lapse is defined as the termination of an insurance policy or annuity contract for nonpayment of premium. Lapse and surrender ratios can vary from product to product, but in general, an insurer wants its lapse and surrender ratios to match those specified by actuaries when they priced the product. In recent years, the industry average for this ratio has been between 5 percent and 6 percent. 3

EXAMPLE

Example. During 2018, 5,500 of Evergreen’s term life insurance policies either lapsed or were surrendered. The number of policies in force at the end of 2017 was 105,000; and the number of policies in force at the end of 2018 was 95,000.

Analysis. The average number of policies in force during 2018 was 100,000, calculated as (105,000 + 95,000) ÷ 2. Therefore, the lapse and surrender ratio for these policies was 5.5%, calculated as 5,500 ÷ 100,000, which falls within the range for the industry average.

In recent years, the industry average has been between 5% and 6%.
