pages.title: Comparative Analysis
pages.contents:
Comparative Analysis

In the chapter on financial ratios, we showed how a ratio result is typically more useful when it is compared to something else, rather than looked at in isolation. Similarly, the numbers on an insurer’s financial statements are generally more useful when insurers engage in comparative analysis. In comparative analysis, an insurer can (1) analyze the change in an item over two or more accounting periods, in which case the analysis is known as horizontal analysis; or (2) compare two sets of numbers that reflect company operations during the same accounting period, in which case the analysis is known as vertical analysis. To achieve the most meaningful results, an insurer typically uses both forms of analysis in tandem.

 
 

Horizontal Analysis

Horizontal analysis is a type of comparative analysis that involves calculating the absolute monetary amount of change in a particular account value on a specified financial statement from one reporting period to another. Horizontal analysis uses comparative financial statements, which present data for two or more accounting periods side by side. Comparative financial statements can be formed from multiple balance sheets, income statements, cash flow statements, and statements of owners’ equity. Comparative financial statements can present year-to-year changes in terms of (1) absolute numerical amounts or (2) percentages or ratios.

Figure 14.1 shows excerpts from the comparative balance sheets and income statements of the Luna Life Insurance Company.

The financial reporting period chosen as the reference point for horizontal analysis is known as the base period. A base period could be a specific month, quarter, year, or other appropriate period of time. In most cases, the base period is the earliest period. In the above example, the base period for Luna’s comparative balance sheet is 2017, the earlier financial reporting period. For truly accurate analysis, a company must be sure it is including identical categories for analysis in each period. A category that is present in one period and absent in another can weight the findings, which makes the analysis less accurate and useful.

To calculate the absolute monetary amount of the change being analyzed, subtract the base period amount from the amount of the period under study. To calculate the percentage change, divide the absolute monetary amount by the base period amount, and then multiply the result by 100, as follows:

Absolute monetary amount =

Period under study amount – Base period amount

Percentage change =
Absolute monetary amount		 x 100
Base period amount

EXAMPLE

Example. The Aries Life Insurance Company had total assets of $13,901,278 in 2017 and total assets of $14,825,060 in 2018. Because 2017 is the earlier period, it is the base period, and 2018 is the period under study. The absolute monetary amount of the change in assets is $923,782, which represents a 6.6% increase in total assets from 2017 to 2018. This increase in total assets is calculated as follows:

($14,825,060 – $13,901,278) ÷ $13,901,278 = 0.066 x 100 = 6.6%

 

Trend Analysis

A trend is a consistent pattern of change displayed over time. Trend analysis, also called trend percentages or index-number trend analysis, is a specific type of horizontal analysis that involves calculating percentage changes in financial statement items over several successive accounting periods, rather than over just two periods. Comparative financial statements indicate the direction and velocity of trends:

  • Direction refers to whether a trend displays an increase or decrease in an account.

  • Velocity refers to whether the increase or decrease in an account is gradual or rapid.

To conduct trend analysis on financial statements, use the following procedure:

  1. Select a base period. Suppose you wanted to conduct a trend analysis on the years 2014–2018. Typically, the base period would be the earliest period in the series: 2014 would be the base year—that is, the year to which you would compare all other years. However, if you chose to compare all years to 2015, then 2015—not the earliest year of 2014—would be the base period. Note that the amounts in the base period must be positive amounts; a trend cannot be accurately analyzed if it has a negative amount in the base period.
  2. Next, list all the amounts in the base period as 100. Each 100 represents 100 percent and is an index number. An index number is a statistical method for measuring the change in a variable.
  3. Finally, express each corresponding amount from nonbase years—the periods under study—as a percentage of the applicable base year amount. To do so, first divide the nonbase value by the base value, and then multiply the result by 100. For example, if the base year of 2014 had an amount of $20,000 and the nonbase year of 2015 had an amount of $15,000, then you would record an index number of 75 ($15,000 ÷ $20,000 = 0.75, or 75%). Index numbers can be calculated only when the amounts are positive.

Use the following rules to interpret index numbers:

  • An index number greater than 100 indicates an increase in the variable from the base period. For example, an index number of 120 indicates a 20 percent increase from the base period.

  • An index number less than 100 indicates a decrease in the variable from the base period. For example, an index number of 80 indicates a 20 percent decrease from the base period.

Note that in many cases, a company will conduct trend analysis using multiple base periods. For example, an insurer conducting a trend analysis on the years 2014–2018 might use 2014 as the base period for analyzing the 2015 amounts, use 2015 as the base period for analyzing the 2016 amounts, and so on. This approach helps analyze growth over time. Watch Video 14.1 for an example of trend analysis.

Check your answer

 

Vertical Analysis

Vertical analysis is a type of comparative analysis that reveals the relationship of each financial statement item to a specified financial statement item during the same reporting period. Vertical analysis provides additional context for the figures on a financial statement, thus making it easier for managers to determine if an amount represents a particular strength of the company or if it indicates a potential cause for concern. Figure 14.2 compares vertical analysis and horizontal analysis.

Vertical analysis can be applied to many financial statements. Most commonly, insurers conduct vertical analysis on the balance sheet and the income statement, as summarized in the following table.

Balance Sheet

Income Statement

Divide asset item by total assets

Divide revenue item by total revenues

Divide liabilities and owners’ equity item by total liabilities and owners’ equity

Divide expense item by total revenues or by total expenses, depending on the purpose of the vertical analysis

Vertical analysis on the balance sheet and income statement allows management to detect potential problems across the company.

EXAMPLE

Example. Murcielago Life Insurance runs a vertical analysis to compare last year’s premium income to last year’s total revenues. The analysis reveals that premium income made up 57% of Murcielago’s total revenues last year. This percentage is higher than Murcielago’s management usually anticipates for premium income.

Analysis. Murcielago’s management can easily see that premium income played a larger role in the company’s success last year than anticipated. Murcielago’s next action would probably be to use horizontal analysis to investigate whether premium income was much higher than anticipated last year, or whether its invested assets had lower income than anticipated, thus leaving premium income to contribute a greater overall percentage of the company’s total revenues.

We can also use vertical analysis to compile a common-size financial statement, which is a financial statement that includes the percentages obtained from vertical analysis. Common-size financial statements often display only percentages; monetary amounts for each item may not be given. The balance sheet and the income statement are often exhibited as common-size statements.

Each item on a common-size balance sheet is expressed as a percentage of (1) total assets or (2) total liabilities and owners’ equity. In other words, the amount of a company’s total assets is the “common size” to which we reference the balance sheet’s other asset amounts. Similarly, total liabilities and owners’ equity is the “common size” to which we reference the balance sheet’s liability amounts and owners’ equity amounts.

Most commonly, insurers use common-size financial statements to compare their company with other companies in the industry. Common-size balance sheets allow insurers to compare financial strength and liquidity, among other qualities. Similarly, an insurer can use common-size income statements to compare profitability, expense control, and other measures. Figure 14.3 shows a simplified example of a common-size balance sheet.

Because amounts on common-size financial statements are stated in relative terms rather than in absolute terms, insurers can use common-size statements to more accurately compare companies of different sizes in the same industry.

EXAMPLE

Example. For 2018, the Immensity Insurance Company’s net income of $580,000,000 is greater than the Humility Life Insurance Company’s net income of $110,000,000. As net profits are determined after expenses are subtracted, you might assume from this information that Immensity is the more profitable company. However, let’s examine the simplified common-size income statements for both companies, presented below.

Analysis. Here we see that Humility’s net income represents a greater percentage of its total revenues (14%) than does Immensity’s net income (11%). Therefore, although Humility’s net income is lower in amount, Humility appears to be operating more efficiently than is Immensity.

Benchmarking

Common-size financial statements are useful for benchmarking purposes. Benchmarking, or running a benchmark, is a process that consists of (1) identifying the best outcomes that other companies have achieved for a specific activity or process and the practices that produced those outcomes, and (2) implementing those practices to equal or surpass the best outcomes. Insurers may benchmark for both financial and nonfinancial practices; here, we focus on financial benchmarking.

To conduct expense analysis using benchmarking, an insurer first determines a set of selection criteria, such as company size or region of operations, and selects a group of appropriate companies according to these criteria. The insurer then acquires data regarding these companies’ expense experience by line of business, function, or another classification.

Where possible, insurers commonly benchmark against other insurance companies, other financial services organizations—such as banks and mutual fund companies—and even companies in other industries. An insurer may also run a comparison between the company’s own operations and expenses and the average results of the entire industry. Because the industry average contains data from companies that may be much larger or smaller than the insurer running the benchmark, the analysis may indicate larger variations than the insurer might have received from benchmarking against companies of similar size. However, an industry-wide comparison can indicate whether a company is exceeding or falling behind in any particular area. An insurer might also have a larger or smaller competitor in a specific market.

EXAMPLE

Example. The Trio Life Insurance Company decides to run a benchmark to compare its expenses with the expenses of other companies in the industry. Trio Life gathers publicly released financial statements from three companies of similar size—Alpha Life, Beta Financial, and Gamma Life—and prepares common-size financial statements based on these statements. Trio Life discovers that both Alpha Life and Gamma Life have lower total expenses as a percentage of total revenues on their income statements, compared to Trio Life. Trio Life’s management decides to research further what cost control measures these companies are using, in hopes that Trio Life might benefit from similar measures.

pages.title: Activity-Based Costing
pages.contents:
Activity-Based Costing

Recall from Chapter 13 that an activity is any procedure that generates work. Activity-based costing (ABC) is the process of linking costs to products or services based on the activities performed in producing the products or services. In other words, ABC identifies the costs of each activity within a particular function, and then assigns the activity costs to the appropriate products. For example, an insurer might first trace the activity of printing marketing brochures for agents to the payments made to an outside printer, and then trace the printer payments (costs) to the lines of business that used the marketing brochures.

Note that activity-based costing recognizes direct costs in the same way that other forms of costing do; ABC differs in how it assigns indirect costs. Traditional cost accounting systems assume that products generate costs; ABC assumes that activities generate costs. Compared to traditional cost accounting systems, ABC is more complex but provides greater accuracy. Companies that use ABC consistently are practicing activity-based management (ABM).

 

Activity-Based Costing Terminology

ABC uses special terminology. Recall that an activity driver is the output of an activity being performed. For example, investigating a claim is an activity for an insurer, and a processed claim is an activity driver. The following terms are also important to ABC:

  • An activity cost is the cost attributable to a specified activity. For example, a customer service call is a specified activity, and telephone charges therefore are an activity cost of customer service centers.

  • A value-added activity is an activity that makes the product more valuable to the customer. Because a customer is generally willing to pay more for better products or service, a company can typically pass costs associated with value-added activities through to a company’s customers in the form of higher prices. For example, mobile-friendly online tools are the outcome of value-added activities because they strongly appeal to customers, and therefore the costs associated with developing such tools typically can be passed on to customers.

  • A non-value-added activity is an activity that does not make the product or service more valuable to the customer. Because customers are not generally willing to pay more for non-value-added activities—such as fixing an error in a flawed product—such activities do not generate profit. Therefore, a company should usually minimize these activities. For example, because unnecessary steps in processing claims are non-value-added activities, a company would minimize these costs by streamlining the claims process rather than attempting to pass these costs on to customers by charging higher premiums.

To provide products, a company engages in activities. These activities consume resources—such as labor, supplies, and computer time—and produce outputs, such as a check for an approved claim. ABC identifies each activity, calculates the costs of performing each unit of activity, and then assigns the cost of each unit of activity to a unit of output or production. ABC also includes activities that do not link directly to a specific product. For instance, an online security upgrade safeguards all of a company’s products; therefore, ABC might classify the upgrade as an indirect cost and distribute the cost of this upgrade among all of the company’s products.

The primary benefits of ABC are that it provides a solid basis for assigning costs to products and assists management in identifying non-value-added activities. By identifying the specific costs of performing tasks and activities, management can determine the relationship between costs and products. The intended result of ABC is more accurate pricing and more effective cost control. To establish an ABC system, a company generally follows the steps illustrated in Figure 14.4.

Figure 14.5 shows a simple comparison of costs accumulated in a traditional way and costs accumulated by activity. Note that the bottom line is the same for both methods. In other words, the total costs incurred do not change.

 

Functional Cost Analysis

Recall that functional costs are the total activity costs within a function, regardless of which department or cost center incurred the costs. A company should design its cost accounting system to support functional cost analysis, which is a subset of activity-based costing. Functional cost analysis, or function cost analysis, is the process of accumulating the costs that are involved in each activity within a function. Functional cost analysis is distinct from ABC in that it groups costs by function as well as activity. For example, to apply functional cost analysis to the function of collecting renewal premiums, an insurer would accumulate the following types of costs:

  • Cost data from the automated processes associated with receiving and recording premium income

  • Machine costs for preparing and mailing premium notices

  • Selling costs and administrative costs by product line

  • Other indirect costs incurred by any department involved in collecting renewal premiums

An insurer’s accounting system should accumulate costs for workflow processes, organizational structures, or departments. Insurers use functional cost analysis to

  • Price products

  • Monitor and control current operational procedures

  • Identify trends that are not recognizable with conventional forms of analysis

  • Develop more accurate budget estimates

  • Benchmark operations against other companies

 

Functional Cost Accounting System

A functional cost accounting system requires a granular level of detail. The system must be able to identify each function within the company—marketing, claims processing, information processing, underwriting, etc.—as well as each line of business. These functions, lines of business, and so on, may not coincide with the company’s departmental units. For example, at one company the policy issue function might be the responsibility of a single subdivision of one department, whereas at another company the function might span two or more departments. When developing a functional cost accounting system, system designers must be careful to include all activities and costs—and only those activities and costs—that are relevant to the specific function under study. The entire functional cost accounting system should be flexible enough to change as the company grows or diversifies. The system should also be able to provide for exceptions and peculiarities within any function or line of business.

 

Functional Unit Costs

To analyze functional costs, a company usually establishes a functional unit cost as a basis. A functional unit cost is a type of functional cost that is calculated by dividing the total functional cost by an appropriate base unit. This appropriate base unit of measure depends on both the function and the line of business being analyzed. The unit of measure may be monetary or nonmonetary in nature: a payment, a product, or some other trackable unit. pages.title: Cost-Volume-Profit Analysis
pages.contents:
Cost-Volume-Profit Analysis

Three critical factors in making business decisions are cost, volume, and profit. Management accounting evaluates the way each factor influences the others—in particular, how cost and volume affect profit. If volume increases, to what extent do costs and profits increase, and which increases more quickly? If profits are down, is it a result of growing costs or insufficient volume? To answer these questions—and many more—managers turn to cost-volume-profit analysis. Cost-volume-profit (CVP) analysis, sometimes called breakeven analysis or profit-volume analysis, is a type of cost analysis used to determine how changes in product prices, sales volume, fixed costs, variable costs, and the type of products a company offers affect its profit. CVP analysis uses both unit costs and costs that are classified by behavior—fixed costs, variable costs, and semi-variable costs.

CVP analysis offers many applications for management accounting. A company’s managers use CVP analysis to test scenarios using different cost, volume, and price assumptions for each product. With CVP analysis, managers can find the most profitable combination of variables to maximize the performance of their products, product lines, and organizations.

CVP analysis also has certain limitations, especially in the life insurance industry. The most significant limitation from an insurer’s perspective is that life insurance products turn a profit over time, as opposed to at the moment of sale. Further variables, such as mortality, also affect life insurance products. These variables can affect profits even when costs and volume remain constant. For these reasons, insurers tend to use CVP analysis for general business purposes, such as analyzing profitability on a divisional or company level.

 

Contribution Margin

Fundamental to CVP analysis is the concept of contribution margin, which is the difference between a product’s total revenues and its total variable costs.

Contribution margin = Product’s total revenues – Product’s total variable costs

To calculate a product’s contribution margin, an insurer must separate the product’s fixed costs—such as rent, utilities, and some employee salaries—from its variable costs, such as agent commissions and operating expenses. Contribution margins tell us how much revenue is available to (1) cover fixed costs and (2) contribute to net income or profit. Note that a product can have a net loss if its costs exceed its revenues.

The unit contribution margin is the difference between the selling price of one unit of product and the variable costs for one unit of product.

Unit contribution margin = Selling price per unit – Variable cost per unit

A sample selling price per unit for an insurance product would be the price per $1,000 of coverage or the price per policy.

EXAMPLE

Example. The Evening Life Insurance Company sells a whole life insurance product that has a unit premium (unit selling price) of $1 per $1,000 of face amount of insurance per month and a unit variable cost of $0.60 per $1,000 of face amount per month. By subtracting the variable cost per unit from the selling price per unit, Evening determines that the unit contribution margin for this product is $0.40 ($1.00 – $0.60).

 

Breakeven Point

The point at which a product’s revenues are equal to its costs (expenses) is called the breakeven point. The product generates no profit and no loss at this point. By calculating the breakeven point, a manager can determine the level of sales at which the product will produce a net gain. The breakeven point could be found by trial and error, but most companies prefer to use a breakeven formula. This equation can be written in one of two ways:

Breakeven point = Fixed costs
Unit contribution margin
Breakeven point = Fixed costs
(Unit selling price – Unit variable cost)

EXAMPLE

Example. The Moondrop Life Insurance Company sells a whole life insurance product that has a unit premium (sales price) of $1 per $1,000 of face amount of insurance per month and a unit variable cost of $0.60 per $1,000 of face amount per month. The unit contribution margin for this product is $0.40 ($1.00 – $0.60). If Moondrop sells 2,000,000 units of whole life insurance during a specified accounting period and has $400,000 in fixed costs during the same period, the net gain on this product for the accounting period is $400,000, as shown on the following contribution income statement:

The process of CVP analysis becomes more complex as a company sells a larger variety of products, especially products that are profitable over time, such as life insurance. A company selling many products must find the right volume of each product to sell in order to improve net gain from operations.

INSIGHT

Additional CVP Analysis Calculations

The contribution margin ratio is the relationship between a product’s contribution margin and its revenues.

Contribution margin ratio = Contribution margin
Revenues

The larger the contribution margin, the greater the net gain will be from an increase in sales.

To further narrow down which activities are contributing the most to net gain, a company can also calculate a segment margin for various segments of each profit center. In this context, a segment is a product, line of business, or responsibility center. Examples of segments might include a specific annuity product, the group life insurance line of business, or the underwriting responsibility center. A segment margin is the amount that remains after the segment’s variable costs and direct fixed costs are subtracted from the revenues generated by the segment. In other words, a segment margin is the portion of the contribution margin that remains after a segment has covered its direct fixed costs. The formal calculation can be written as follows:

Segment margin = Contribution margin – Direct fixed costs

A segment margin indicates the segment’s profitability. A positive segment margin indicates profitability, and a negative segment margin indicates that a segment cannot recover its own costs. A company may maintain negative segment margins under certain circumstances, such as when a segment contributes to the company’s bottom line by covering shared indirect costs.

Segment margins, when put in ratio form, can also help managers with performance evaluation. We calculate the segment margin ratio, a measure of a segment’s operating performance efficiency, by dividing the segment margin by the segment’s total revenues, as follows:

Segment margin ratio = Segment margin
Segment’s total revenues

alt:
Step 1: Identify activities. Example: Underwriting an individual life insurance application.

Step 2: Identify the activity drivers for each activity. Example: The underwriting decision is one activity driver for underwriting.

Step 3: Assign costs to each activity. Example: Managers track underwriting time and relevant costs for salaries, equipment, and supplies.

Step 4: Determine the unit cost of each activity for comparative purposes. Example: The insurer divides total underwriting costs by the number of applications underwritten. Therefore, $43,750 underwriting costs ÷ 350 applications underwritten = $125 unit cost.

Step 5: Identify all areas for which the costs of that activity apply. Example: The outputs for underwriting unit costs are individual life insurance policies for which a decision was made.

Step 6: Assign each activity cost to the smallest meaningful organizational unit for which it has meaning. Example: The insurer assigns the activity costs for underwriting individual life insurance to the individual life line of business.

  1. Helps allocate scarce resources effectively

As individuals, we think about when we should save and when we should spend. We weigh essential purchases versus nonessential purchases. We consider saving and investments to ensure we have a sound financial future. A company makes similar decisions, both in the short term and in the long term. But insurers are responsible for the financial security of their business and they provide products and services that protect and/or preserve the financial security of their customers. When a company carries so much responsibility, it cannot make financial decisions randomly based on hunches and guesswork. All companies, especially those in the financial services industry, need a plan. Budgeting is an accounting process that includes creating a financial plan of action designed to help an organization achieve its goals. As you recall from Chapter 12, a budget is a financial plan of action, expressed in monetary terms, that covers a specified period, such as one year. A budget contains estimates of management’s expectations for the company’s performance over the next period. During the next period, the company can compare its actual results to expectations, and adjust its operations accordingly.

pages.title: Why Budget?
pages.contents:
Why Budget?

No company has infinite resources. Therefore, all companies budget to varying degrees. The budgeting process enables a company to

  • Communicate information throughout the company. A company budget contains information on the company’s financial position, resources, and expenses. Also, because a budget is a formalized plan, employees can use the budget to understand what actions management plans to take, and the reasons for taking those actions.

  • Allocate scarce resources effectively. A company must distinguish between wants and needs, and allocate resources accordingly. A budget helps a company prioritize expenses that are essential for the company to remain in operation. Once the company has accounted for all essential operating expenses, the company can allocate any remaining resources to other expenses.

  • Control and reduce expenses. A budget shows a company’s expenses side by side, thereby enabling management to compare expenses between operational areas or between time periods. By doing so, a company can determine which costs take precedence and which costs it can more easily reduce.

  • Prioritize necessary technological improvements. Technology changes rapidly, whether a company is ready for it or not. A budget helps determine which upgrades a company cannot afford—and which upgrades a company cannot afford to do without.

  • Monitor and evaluate ongoing operations. A budget provides the context necessary to determine if a business operation is doing well or poorly. Management achieves this goal by measuring the operation against the budget to see if the operation is meeting expectations.

  • Evaluate managerial performance. Accurate budgets indicate how well company managers are achieving the company’s goals or meeting company expectations.

  • Motivate employees. Managers can recognize and reward employees who meet or exceed the expectations laid out in the budget. In addition, employees are more confident when they understand and agree with their company’s plan of action. However, employees should agree that a budget is realistic. If a budget is unrealistic, employees may feel the company is destined to fail.

We can see that the advantages of budgeting are clear. However, budgeting also has some possible disadvantages, including the potential for management to

  • Consume too much time. Budgeting takes time. If management devotes too much time to creating and monitoring a budget, then the reduced time available for other managerial duties may lead to a loss of productivity or company focus.

  • Spend unnecessary amounts. Management may be tempted to consider the resources set aside to cover budgeted costs as “money already spent.” Management might also anticipate that their budgets will be reduced in the future if they do not use all the resources allocated to them. Therefore, they may feel compelled to spend the entire budgeted amount, even when some expenditures prove to be unnecessary.

  • Overestimate costs. Managers may be tempted to overestimate costs so that if they overspend, upper management will not blame them for contributing to a loss. This phenomenon makes accurate budgeting much more difficult.

  • Avoid innovation. With a strict budget in place, managers may be less inclined to experiment, especially in response to changing market conditions. While this conservative approach expends fewer resources, it also may prevent a company from discovering innovative solutions.

  • Disregard quality and customer service. Budgetary constraints may tempt managers to focus on volume over quality, or on gaining new customers at the expense of retaining existing customers. These choices may result in increasing numbers of dissatisfied customers who take their business elsewhere.

With all of these advantages and disadvantages to consider, the budgeting process requires careful planning and execution to be successful. In many companies, a budget committee formed by top executives and managers from the company’s main functions oversees the budgeting process. The budget committee reviews proposed budgets and works to integrate responsibility center budgets into a balanced, realistic main budget.

pages.title: Budgeting Approaches
pages.contents:
Budgeting Approaches

A company carefully selects an approach to the budgeting process to ensure that the budget supports the attainment of company goals. For example, if management has set a goal of increasing employee confidence in the company, the company may choose a budgeting approach that increases employee involvement in the budgeting process. Most companies prefer to use one or more of the following approaches: top-down budgeting, bottom-up budgeting, zero-based budgeting, and activity-based budgeting.

 

Top-Down Budgeting and Bottom-Up Budgeting

Top-down budgeting is a method for developing a budget that begins with a company’s senior management and is passed down to lower-level management. Senior management bases a top-down budget’s monetary amounts both on the strategic plan and on financial information about the company’s activities in prior years. In contrast, bottom-up budgeting starts at the bottom of a company, with lower-level managers generating budgets for their areas, which they then present in the form of recommendations to senior management. Bottom-up budgets reflect the input and participation of the area managers and employees who will be responsible for achieving the company’s goals.

Compared to top-down budgeting, bottom-up budgeting

  • Typically takes more time and includes a larger number of employees

  • Is more likely to reflect the realities of the company’s core business operations

  • Often has more grassroots support among company employees

In practice, a company typically uses some elements of both top-down and bottom-up budgeting. For example, senior management must still ensure that a bottom-up budget adheres to overall corporate objectives. Many companies combine both approaches by using a group decision method, in which senior management works with the company’s responsibility managers. This method is time-consuming, but otherwise incorporates many advantages of both top-down and bottom-up budgeting. Figure 15.1 contrasts top-down and bottom-up budgeting.

 

Zero-Based Budgeting

Despite their differences, both top-down and bottom-up budgeting typically use the current year’s budget, along with actual financial results and strategic plans, as a starting point for making adjustments to the next year’s budget. In addition, these budgeting approaches apply to both revenue and expense budgets, which we describe in a later section. Zero-based budgeting, however, does not start with the current year’s budget, and generally applies only to a company’s expense budgets. Under zero-based budgeting (ZBB), a company treats each activity as though it were a new project and allocates resources only if planners can link expense amounts to the company’s strategic and operational goals. In other words, planners must begin each accounting period at “zero.” For every accounting period, each responsibility center must justify its continued existence and operation.

In essence, ZBB treats each activity and function as though it were a new project under consideration. Unlike the top-down and bottom-up budgeting approaches, ZBB does not automatically assume that current-year expense levels are reasonable starting points for developing the expense budget for the next accounting period. Instead, ZBB imposes cost analysis on all levels of management to evaluate each activity in terms of efficiency and need. The advantages of ZBB include

  • Key roles for lower-level employees. The company often calls upon lower-level employees to provide details that help the company assess the importance and financial requirements of each activity. This aspect of ZBB can improve communication and trust within a company, and usually offers the benefit of additional training and education for employees who participate.

  • Breadth and quality of financial information. ZBB is an exacting process, which requires managers to identify required resources and an absolute minimum level of spending to operate.

  • Drive for improvement. Every manager must consider and evaluate a level of spending lower than the current operating level. This feature of ZBB encourages managers to ask vital questions, rather than remaining complacent.

Like other budgeting approaches, ZBB also has its disadvantages, which include

  • Cost. ZBB is a complicated budgeting system that requires a significant investment of resources.

  • Time. Managers at all levels of the company must help prepare and administer a zero-based budget. Much of the work associated with ZBB involves (1) collecting and analyzing data to justify each item and (2) preparing contingency budgets in case unanticipated expenses arise.

  • Risk of self-interest. ZBB requires managers to rank projects or activities as necessary or desirable. This aspect of ZBB may create temptation for managers to overstate the amount of resources required for activities or products.

Because of these disadvantages, many companies use a modified ZBB process. For example, one company might apply ZBB to specified activities or functions, while another company performs ZBB only every other year.

 

Activity-Based Budgeting

Another comprehensive budgeting approach relies on activity-based costing. Recall from Chapter 14 that activity-based costing (ABC) assigns costs based on the activities performed in producing products or services. Therefore, activity-based budgeting (ABB) begins with the premise that costs are linked to products or services based on the activities performed in producing the products or services. The focus of ABB is to create a plan of action based on which activities are most cost-efficient.

ABB’s advantages include

  • Detailed information. Because the ABC process is exacting, ABB helps a company to anticipate and control costs in great detail. For instance, ABB is very effective at distinguishing between direct and indirect costs.

  • A focus on efficiency. ABB is particularly useful when a company’s main goal is reducing unnecessary expenses and focusing on cost-efficient products and services.

ABB also has its disadvantages, which are tied to the demands of the ABC process. Specifically, ABB requires more information and time than do other forms of budgeting, and is therefore comparably more expensive.

In comparing top-down budgeting and bottom-up budgeting, it is correct to say that (top-down / bottom-up) budgeting typically takes more time but often has more grassroots employee support.

pages.title: Budget Classifications
pages.contents:
Budget Classifications

The budgeting approach describes the process by which a company creates a budget, but it does not determine the budget’s classification. We can classify any budget using each of the following comparisons:

  • Static versus flexible

  • Short-term versus long-term

  • Rolling versus period

For instance, we might classify one company’s budget as a static, short-term, period budget, while another company’s budget might be a flexible, short-term, rolling budget.

 

Static Budgets and Flexible Budgets

When we classify budgets by their degree of variability, we typically refer to them as either static or flexible budgets. The amounts in a static budget, also known as a fixed budget or a fixed-amount budget, are generally not subject to change unless management has approved the changes. Static budgets are more useful when a company’s operations and growth levels are consistent, but less useful when a company’s budgeted amounts of revenues and expenses are uncertain. A static budget lacks the flexibility to provide alternate financial projections when a company’s experience differs from the assumptions underlying the budgeted figures. Therefore, a static budget is most appropriate for budgeting fixed costs.

In contrast, a flexible budget, also known as a flexible-amount budget, a dynamic budget, or a variable budget, provides alternative sets of budget estimates to use under different circumstances that may arise during an accounting period. Essentially, a flexible budget comprises a series of static budgets prepared for each alternative budget estimate. Because the potential financial scenarios for any given accounting period are nearly infinite, a company typically focuses on budgeting for a limited number of scenarios. For instance, a flexible budget commonly focuses on the company’s projections for the best-case, worst-case, and expected levels of activity.

Watch Video 15.1 to see a comparison of static and flexible budgets.

Short-Term Budgets and Long-Term Budgets

We can also classify budgets by time frame. A short-term budget, also called an operating budget, generally covers a period of one year or less and relates mainly to a company’s operations during that period. A company often divides a short-term budget into quarterly, monthly, weekly, or sometimes daily budgets. A long-term budget, also called a strategic budget, generally covers periods of more than one year. Many insurers produce long-term budgets covering the next five to 10 years, which estimate the revenues and expenses that correspond to the company’s strategic goals.

A company should use the current period’s short-term budget when defining the most current year of the long-term budget. Thus, a long-term budget incorporates a company’s short-term budgets.

 

Rolling Budgets and Period Budgets

A rolling budget, also known as a continuous budget, allows a company to continually maintain projections for a specified period into the future. A company that uses a six-month rolling budget would update the budget at the end of each month, generally removing the past month and adding another month in the future, so that budget projections always apply to the coming six-month period. A period budget covers a specific time frame, such as one month or one year, and expires at the end of that time frame. A period budget may be short-term or long-term, depending on the length of the time frame covered. The figures in the period budget do not change during the time frame covered by the budget. As variances occur, a company would incorporate the variances into the process of projecting the figures for the next period’s budget.

A rolling budget is in essence a series of smaller period budgets. Because a company regularly updates a rolling budget based on the results of the most recent period, a rolling budget can maintain a higher degree of accuracy than can a period budget. However, maintaining a rolling budget generally requires a higher level of management attention and resources compared to a period budget. Figure 15.2 depicts a rolling sales revenue budget.

As previously noted, this rolling budget is also a series of period budgets: January–June, February–July, March–August, and April–September. However, the rolling budget structure allows Electrum to adapt its budget more frequently than would be possible if Electrum simply used one six-month-period budget after another. Here, Electrum can revise its figures every month and not every six months.

pages.title: Types of Budgets
pages.contents:
Types of Budgets

When management engages in profit planning, which is the process of taking actions to achieve a specified profit level, the most critical element in the process is a sound master budget. The accounting function combines the individual budgets for each department or responsibility center into the company’s master budget, which shows the overall operating and financing plans for the company during a specified accounting period. Companies may refer to the master budget by different names, such as comprehensive budget, corporate budget, or performance plan. Most companies compile the master budget annually and update it semiannually.

To develop the master budget, a company begins by assembling a forecast of the company’s revenues, expenses, cash flows, and capital budgeting activities. The master budget generally consists of several types of budgets, including

  • Operational budgets

  • Cash budgets

  • Capital budgets

We’ll look at each of these types of budgets in the following sections.

 

Operational Budgets

An operational budget is a budget that covers part or all of a company’s core business operations, such as underwriting and claims. An operational budget reflects the financial steps the company will take during the coming year to achieve its objectives, such as releasing new products or reducing overhead. Typically, a company incorporates multiple operational budgets into the master budget, as discussed previously.

All operational budgets begin with a forecast of sales revenues and investment income. Insurers use one or more forecasting techniques to create this projection. Although the format and content of operational budgets vary widely among companies, operational budgets show the revenues or expenses that a company expects during a specified accounting period. Two basic types of operational budgets are revenue budgets and expense budgets.

 

Revenue Budgets

After developing the sales forecast and the investment forecast, a company then develops its revenue budget. A revenue budget indicates the amount of income from operations—premium income, investment income, and fee income—that the company expects in the coming budget period. The revenue budget may differ from the sales forecast and investment forecast; the forecasts are raw estimates, whereas the budget outlines management’s goals and expectations after reviewing other available data. For example, if an investment forecast anticipates that a market will continue to remain strong, management may instead create a more conservative revenue budget, to minimize the risk that an unforeseen drop in the market would negatively affect the company’s investments.

The revenue budget determines the limits of the other budgets, whether they are expense budgets (which also are operational budgets), cash budgets, or capital budgets. Therefore, a company must develop its revenue budget before other budgets. Some insurers divide the revenue budget into the sales budget and the investment budget:

  • A sales budget projects first-year and renewal premium income. The insurer bases its sales budget estimates on historical data, reviews of the marketplace, regulatory conditions, and premium rates charged by competitors, among other factors. An insurer often itemizes its sales budget by line of business, such as individual life insurance and individual annuities.

  • An investment budget projects the types of investments the insurer will make and the expected amount of investment income for each type of investment. A company often itemizes its investment budget by investment type, such as bonds, mortgages, and stocks.

 

Expense Budgets

After developing its revenue budget, a company then prepares its expense budget. An expense budget is a schedule of expenses expected during an accounting period. The insurer bases the expense budget in part on revenue projections, but also on historical expense data, economic trends, and management goals, among other factors. An expense budget is useful in controlling expenses, measuring management performance, and assigning responsibility for expenses. Common components of the expense budget for insurance companies include the

  • Benefits budget, which indicates the amount of money the insurer expects to pay for insurance policy or annuity contract benefits, such as claims, cash surrenders, and policyowner dividends, during the next accounting period. Most expenses in benefits budgets are variable expenses because these expenses vary with changes in sales volume.

  • Sales expense budget, which indicates the costs incurred in selling insurance. These expenses include the costs of commissions, advertising, promotions, travel, branch office operations, and salaries for marketing staff. Sales expense budget figures are also typically variable expenses.

  • General and administrative expense budget, which includes expenses—typically fixed expenses—needed for insurance company operations. Usually, this budget is the sum of all departmental expense budgets. The general and administrative expense budget also includes such company-wide expenses as administrative salaries, rent, and utilities.

Figure 15.3 shows a simplified revenue budget, divided into its sales and investment components.

Figure 15.4 shows an expense budget, divided into benefit expenses, sales expenses, and general and administrative expenses.

 

Cash Budgets

Cash budgeting is a budgeting activity that anticipates the cash flows into and out of a company during an accounting period. Many companies divide the annual cash budget into quarterly, monthly, weekly, and sometimes daily budgets to monitor cash flow more closely. Automated accounting systems make real-time cash reporting available. A cash budget is a type of budget that projects a company’s beginning cash balance, cash inflows, cash outflows, and ending cash balance for a specified accounting period, typically by quarter.

The cash budget is not part of the operational budget, but it provides context for the operational budget by letting the insurer know how much cash is available to invest or to spend. Budgeting for cash helps a company in both the short term and the long term. In the short term, the company can plan for both cash shortages and cash excesses; in the long term, company management can decide the company’s investment strategy.

Cash inflows and outflows are unique to each company. Insurers use forecasting techniques to project cash inflows and cash outflows. A cash budget consists of a cash receipts budget (cash inflows) and a cash disbursements budget (cash outflows). A company plans for its cash inflows through a cash receipts budget, which is a schedule of cash receipts expected during the accounting period. To project both the timing and amount of its cash receipts, a company constructs the cash receipts budget using data from both the sales and investment forecasts. Figure 15.5 shows an example of a cash receipts budget.

A cash receipts budget resembles a revenue budget, such as the budget shown in Figure 15.3. For simplicity’s sake, this budget assumes no timing differences between income and cash receipts. In most cases, the figures in a cash receipts budget will vary from the figures in a revenue budget because the timing of cash payments may vary.

In the cash disbursements budget, an insurer estimates the timing and amount of cash disbursements expected during the accounting period. Estimating cash disbursements for fixed expenses such as salaries is relatively easy and accurate. Cash disbursements for variable expenses, such as contractual benefit payments and commissions, can be less predictable. The accuracy of these projections depends in large part on the accuracy of the sales forecast. Figure 15.6 shows an example of a cash disbursements budget.

Once an insurer has created the cash receipts budget and the cash disbursements budget, the next step is to combine them into the cash budget. Information contained in the cash budget includes the

  • Beginning cash balance, which equals the ending cash balance from the prior period

  • Available cash for the period, which equals the beginning cash balance plus cash receipts expected during the period

  • Minimum cash balance, an amount that is determined by the company

  • Cash needed for the period, which equals cash disbursements plus the minimum cash balance

  • Excess cash or cash shortage, which equals available cash minus cash needed for the period

  • Amount of any cash borrowed or repaid, including interest

  • Ending cash balance, which equals excess cash or shortage of cash plus any borrowing or repayment activity

The minimum cash balance is the amount of cash that a company determines is necessary to pay all obligations in an accounting period without having excess cash. Setting this figure too low raises the risk of running out of cash. Setting this figure too high carries an opportunity cost because this cash is not earning a return for the insurer. Insurers use many methods to derive the minimum cash balance. Some insurers set the minimum cash balance equal to the budgeted cash disbursements for one month. Others use computer spreadsheet simulations to set the minimum cash balance.

By examining the cash budget, an insurer can estimate the timing and amount of cash shortages. The insurer can then plan to counteract any shortages, such as through short-term borrowing or liquidating assets. The insurer can also calculate the amount of excess cash to invest in liquid assets.

Figure 15.7 shows an example of a cash budget. In this example, Noonday has established a minimum cash balance of $3,250,000 for each quarter. Noonday expects that, by the end of the first quarter, it will encounter a cash shortage of $2,021,000. To make up for this shortage, Noonday has planned for a short-term loan in the amount of $2,500,000, which it expects to be able to repay, with interest, in the fourth quarter.

Capital Budgets

Capital budgeting is the process companies undertake to analyze decisions about investing in long-term projects or assets. Capital budgeting often includes many steps, which are beyond the scope of this textbook. A capital budget shows a company’s plans for the financial management of its long-term, high-cost investment proposals. In the context of capital budgeting, the word “investment” typically does not refer to the direct purchase of bonds, mortgages, or stocks. Rather, these long-term, high-cost investments include

  • New acquisitions of equipment or real estate

  • Remodeling of or major repairs to existing capital investments

  • Acquisitions of other companies or lines of business

  • Mandated safety and environmental improvements

  • Expense reduction projects

  • Purchases of new computer systems and equipment

  • Revenue expansion projects

A common trait of capital budgeting is that these investments are expected to produce income or other benefits for more than one year. Figure 15.8 presents an example of a capital budget for a proposed new facility.

 

Pro Forma Financial Statements

The master budget culminates in a set of pro forma financial statements. In other contexts, the term pro forma, meaning “for the sake of form,” describes an action taken for the purpose of formality or politeness. In accounting, a pro forma financial statement is a financial statement that a company develops using forecasted amounts. In this context, the term “pro forma” indicates that the statement is a projection. The term usually implies that the statement was prepared to consider the effects of a potential activity. For example, an insurer considering a major acquisition might create pro forma financial statements to review its projected post-acquisition financial situation.

Pro forma financial statements include a pro forma balance sheet, a pro forma income statement, and a pro forma cash flow statement. For example, a pro forma income statement contains projected amounts for a company’s revenues and expenses. Insurance companies typically develop a series of pro forma financial statements for

  • Financial modeling purposes

  • Reporting to external parties, such as the SEC or insurance regulatory authorities

  • Considering the financial effects of specific events, such as a new product launch, a change in corporate form, or a change in accounting methods

Objectives

An insurer’s financial statements need to be accurate so that interested third parties can evaluate the company’s financial condition. What actions do insurance companies take to ensure the accuracy of their financial statements?

  1.  
  2.  
  3.  

Submit

An insurer’s financial statements need to be accurate so that interested third parties can evaluate the company’s financial condition. What actions do insurance companies take to ensure the accuracy of their financial statements?

  1. They undergo internal audits.
  2. They undergo external audits.
  3. They put in place an effective system of internal controls.

Check your answer

All insurers have a control function, which measures and monitors an insurer’s transactions as it pursues its corporate objectives, such as solvency and profitability. The activities associated with accounting and financial reporting are an integral part of this control function. In this chapter, we discuss two key aspects of the control function that directly affect all insurance operations: internal control and financial auditing.

Internal control is a process in which a company takes actions designed to

  • Protect its assets

  • Monitor the reliability of its accounting records

  • Encourage both operational efficiency and adherence to the company’s management policies

  • Comply with applicable laws and regulations

In general, internal controls are designed to prevent or reduce losses arising from (1) mistakes or irregularities in transaction processing and asset handling and (2) unexpected events or contingencies.

Back in Chapter 1, we briefly discussed audits. An audit is the examination and evaluation of company accounting records, policies, and procedures to ensure that (1) the financial information, financial statements, and source documents comply with accounting standards and are a fair and consistent depiction of the company’s financial condition and performance, and (2) a company’s operational procedures and policies are effective. Auditing is the process of conducting an audit.

Later in the chapter, we discuss different types of audits. However, this chapter primarily focuses on financial audits, which represent the vast majority of all audits conducted. Therefore, when we use the terms auditing and audit, we generally mean financial auditing and financial audit.

Typically, the internal control and auditing functions are separate from the duties of the accounting department. To perform their analysis effectively and without bias, audit and control personnel must maintain a high degree of independence and objectivity regarding other departments.

×

pages.title: Internal Control
pages.contents:
Internal Control

Two general types of internal control are administrative controls and accounting controls:

  • Administrative controls are the policies and procedures that guide employees in conducting their normal day-to-day tasks. An example of an administrative control is a policy that requires a manager to check business references before hiring a new employee.

  • Accounting controls are the policies and procedures used to authorize financial transactions, safeguard assets, and provide reliable, timely, and fairly presented financial information about a company. In insurance companies, accounting controls generally include the preparation and analysis of financial statements, internal auditing, and other measures of financial performance.

Although administrative controls and accounting controls have unique qualities, they are sometimes difficult to distinguish in practice.

By adhering to accounting controls, an insurer can be reasonably certain that only authorized employees

  • Record accounting entries for the insurer’s financial transactions

  • Prepare financial statements that comply with applicable accounting principles and regulatory requirements

  • Access the insurer’s assets

  • Compare the insurer’s assets with its accounting records for those assets

 

Preventive Controls and Detective Controls

An insurer’s internal controls should include both preventive controls and detective controls. A preventive control is an internal control that is designed to keep—that is, “prevent”—an error or a problem from occurring. Normally, preventive controls involve steps that must be taken before a business transaction occurs. Examples of preventive controls in insurance companies include internal procedures that require

  • Proper documentation—for example, original documents or acceptable copies of original documents—before claims processors disburse benefit payments

  • Two signatures on checks written over a specified dollar amount

  • Valid codes to be entered for each transaction

A detective control is an internal control that identifies—or “detects”—an error or a problem after it has occurred. Most detective controls are undertaken after a series of business transactions. Examples of detective controls for insurance companies include procedures such as a

  • Monthly review of claims disbursements

  • Daily balance of department accounts

  • Daily review of reports of questionable data

Preventive controls are usually more effective at reducing errors or problems than are detective controls, but preventive controls are also typically more expensive. As with any other expense, insurers analyze both preventive and detective controls to ensure that they provide benefits that are worth their costs.

Figure 16.1 summarizes administrative, accounting, preventive, and detective controls.

Figure 16.2 compares preventive controls and detective controls in terms of cost and effectiveness.

 
 

Limitations of Internal Controls

Internal controls are a necessary part of a life insurance company’s operations. However, no system of internal controls is infallible. Internal controls are designed for specified conditions. As these conditions change, the internal controls must also be changed. An insurer may need to review its internal controls due to external or internal changes:

  • External changes would include changes to accounting standards or amendments to the federal income tax code.

  • Internal changes would include the introduction of a new product or the modification of an existing product.

An insurance company’s internal controls are designed in part to reduce or avoid employee errors. However, employees can make mistakes in implementing the internal controls. Improperly implemented controls are unlikely to detect the problems they were designed to detect. Common preventive controls that companies use to manage employee errors include

  • Hiring the best-qualified people available

  • Training new employees thoroughly in the proper use of established internal controls

  • Involving experienced employees in the development of new internal controls

Internal controls are also designed to reduce the incidence of criminal acts, such as theft against a company by employees. Because no system is perfect, however, a determined employee occasionally can circumvent a company’s internal controls, at least temporarily.

A company must examine and evaluate its policies and procedures, and then develop controls that fit the company’s operations. Internal controls must be workable from an operational point of view as well as provide greater benefits than they cost.

 

Principles of Effective Internal Control

To be effective, an insurer’s internal control system must

  • Facilitate employee training

  • Facilitate communication of policies and procedures

  • Provide warning signals for prompt error detection

  • Indicate whether the company is complying with regulatory requirements

Note that an insurer could be subject to fines and other penalties for noncompliance with regulatory requirements. For example, regulators can impose a fine on a life insurance company that continues to file late quarterly financial statements. The payment of fines and penalties decreases an insurer’s net income and ultimately its surplus.

All effective internal control systems follow certain principles, including segregation of duties, execution of transactions as authorized, recording of transactions as executed, safeguarding of assets, and physical comparison of recorded amounts.

 

Segregation of Duties

The principle of segregation of duties, also known as the principle of dual control, requires an employer to design jobs so that incompatible functions are assigned to different individuals. In this context, incompatible functions are job duties that, when combined, place an employee in a position to commit an illegal act or to conceal errors or irregularities in the normal course of his employment. When incompatible functions are combined, an insurer is also less likely to detect unintentional employee errors. Segregating—or “separating”—duties among employees provides an environment in which an insurer can protect its assets and detect and correct errors and irregularities quickly.

In general, an effective internal control system separates the (1) custodial tasks, (2) authorization tasks, and (3) accounting tasks associated with an insurer’s assets. In this context, custody is defined as the physical or electronic handling of assets. Under segregation of duties, the employees typically work in different areas or functions of the company.

EXAMPLE

Example. At the Evergreen Life Insurance Company, Julio assumes custody of all securities, whereas Shu-Ling is authorized to sell these securities. Finally, Marisela maintains the records associated with these securities.

Analysis. If Evergreen had not separated these incompatible functions, a dishonest employee would be able to conceal irregularities associated with selling these securities; even an honest employee could make a serious mistake that would potentially go undetected.

Complicating an insurer’s adherence to the segregation of duties is the trend toward employee empowerment, especially the delegation of start-to-finish processing by one employee. Under employee empowerment programs, many insurers delegate authority to employees at the lowest possible level in specified functions. This delegation can result in a blurring of incompatible functions. Therefore, under an employee empowerment program, an insurer should conduct random internal audits of business transactions more frequently than in a more hierarchical organization. We discuss internal auditing in detail later in the chapter.

Figure 16.3 illustrates balancing segregation of duties and employee empowerment.

Insurers usually purchase a fidelity bond on each employee who oversees particularly sensitive areas, such as investment management or cash management (treasury operations). A fidelity bond is an indemnity insurance agreement that provides coverage for a financial loss caused by (1) the act or default of a third party, such as an employee or a business partner, or (2) some contingency, such as fire, over which the third party may have no control. Fidelity bonds can help protect an insurer from the risks associated with employee violation of internal controls. Some insurance companies purchase fidelity bonds on all employees.

 

Execution of Transactions as Authorized

The execution of transactions as authorized is the element of the internal control system that concerns the delegation of authority to perform specified tasks and the communication of that authority. In an insurance company, many different types of monetary transactions—such as issuing policies, paying benefits, purchasing and selling securities, and paying operating expenses—require employee authorization. No financial transaction should occur without some form of official authorization.

Authorization levels should be realistic and a company should communicate them clearly. Within the context of an internal control system, an authorization level is the maximum monetary amount that a company employee has been granted official power to approve for disbursement. Whatever the type of transaction, a specified employee authorizes each transaction at the appropriate level. Each authorization level should reflect the transaction and the experience and responsibility of the employee concerned.

EXAMPLE

Example. A claims processor with only two months’ work experience may have to obtain authorization for all claim payments over $2,500, whereas an experienced claims processor may be authorized to approve claim payments up to $50,000, within specified guidelines.

Note that, under execution of transactions as authorized, the employees typically work in the same area or function, but at different levels.

 

Recording of Transactions as Executed

The recording of transactions as executed means that a company records all authorized and executed transactions in the correct accounting period, in the correct accounts, and in the correct monetary amounts. In this way, the company can summarize all transactions for that accounting period in its financial statements.

EXAMPLE

Example. An insurer records premium income when it is received. The accounting entry includes the proper amount of the cash receipt, posted to the correct record in the policyowner master file and to the correct bank account.

Communicating the policies and procedures necessary to document a financial transaction is an essential part of recording transactions as executed. Employee training sessions, prenumbered checks and purchase orders, and written procedures manuals help support the documentation of an insurer’s financial transactions.

 

Safeguarding of Assets

The safeguarding of assets is the process of (1) limiting access to offices, documents, and records; (2) storing certain documents in vaults to which no person has sole access; (3) maintaining written recovery plans and off-premises storage of back-up files for all critical records in case of a business disaster; (4) investigating the integrity of employees hired to fill sensitive positions; (5) taking a physical inventory of all assets and comparing this count to a written record; and (6) reviewing the adequacy of insurance coverage, given a company’s risk exposure.

Safeguarding assets is a balancing act. An insurer needs to make sure that certain assets are widely accessible so that it can conduct normal business operations, but access to other assets should be restricted to authorized persons. An insurer’s computer system may be safeguarded, for example, by

  • Requiring the use of passwords before employees are allowed access to software applications

  • Maintaining adequate insurance and service contracts on the system

  • Requiring employees to follow appropriate virus protection procedures

  • Providing back-up copies of critical records and housing them in an off-site facility

  • Separating the incompatible functions between those who program the database software and those who enter records into the database

Figure 16.4 illustrates the balancing act of safeguarding assets while providing access to those assets.

 

Physical Comparison of Recorded Amounts

The physical comparison of recorded amounts means that a company counts its assets on a periodic basis and compares this count to the amounts in its accounting records. This physical comparison is typically accomplished by means of an inventory. An inventory is an itemized count and listing of a company’s assets, such as property, products, materials, or securities.

Figure 16.5 summarizes the principles of an effective internal control system.

The insight below lists some examples of effective internal controls at an insurance company.

INSIGHT

Effective Internal Controls at an Insurance Company

 

Approval, review, checking, or recalculation

  • Senior management approves all claim payments over a specified dollar amount
  • Actuarial staff recalculates premiums charged on a block of policies
  • Claims processors complete a checklist that indicates the insurer has received all required documents before the insurer pays a claim

Prenumbering

  • Checks and purchase orders are printed with sequential numbers
  • Policy applications and claims are numbered as they are received
  • Internal auditors check the numbering sequence and reconcile any number that is missing or out of sequence

Maintenance of control totals

  • All policy loans are listed and subtotaled separately, and then the subtotals are reconciled to the insurer’s total policy loans
  • Premium checks are grouped and totaled to obtain a batch total, which is entered into the insurer’s automated system

Comparison with third-party information

  • The insurer’s cash receipts and disbursements are reconciled with the insurer’s bank statement, cash accounts, and suspense accounts
  • Information in the insurer’s accounting records concerning its notes payable is reconciled with statements provided by the notes’ owners
  • Notifications of errors in payments or policy records or confirmation of amounts receivable from persons or companies that owe the insurer money are routinely compared

Cancellation of documentation

  • Cancelled or voided documents are defaced or shredded in some way so that they cannot be sent through normal processing channels

Timeliness of operation

  • All transactions are processed promptly, including daily deposits of cash receipts
  • Periodic reviews of new business are conducted to resolve insurance policies that have neither been issued nor denied after a specified time
