pages.title: Auditing
pages.contents:
Auditing

All insurance companies undergo periodic internal and external audits:

  • An internal audit is a financial audit that is performed by company employees.

  • An external audit, also known as an independent audit, is a financial audit performed by external auditors, who are employed by public accounting companies, insurance regulators, or reinsurers.

Both internal and external auditors typically have the following responsibilities:

  • Verifying that a company’s assets are accounted for and that they are safeguarded from loss

  • Ensuring that employees follow specified policies and procedures

  • Verifying the reliability of the company’s accounting records and financial reports

  • Assessing the soundness and the application of the company’s administrative and accounting controls

Watch Video 16.1 to see some common questions answered in an audit.

Video 16.1 Questions to Be Answered in an Audit

Questions to Be Answered in an Audit

 
 
0:00 / 1:05
  • 1.75x
  • 1.50x
  • 1.25x
  • 1.00x
  • 0.75x
  • 0.50x
  • 0.25x
Transcript
Video 16-1 Transcript

Auditors review an insurer’s records in part to uncover unintentional errors or false information in the insurer’s accounting records and financial statements. Auditors also look for evidence of fraud, which is the intentional use of false information to mislead another party. Although an insurer’s internal controls may be effective against fraud committed by one person, they may be less effective at detecting fraud that arises from collusion. Collusion is a secret agreement entered into by two or more persons to perpetrate an illegal act. People use collusion to circumvent controls, such as segregation of duties or authorization levels.

Auditors often use an audit trail, which is a chronological, sequential set of accounting records and reports from the beginning to the end of a business transaction. By following an audit trail, an auditor may be able to isolate any breach of control and bring it to the attention of the insurer and insurance regulators. An auditor who examines an insurer’s audit trails for a variety of financial transactions can also identify the overall strengths and weaknesses of the insurer’s system of internal controls.

Examining every accounting entry to verify each financial transaction would be impractical and costly. Instead, auditors rely on a system of statistical sampling in which they examine a portion of the company’s accounts, transactions, and operations. Samples are chosen according to sound statistical methods, which provide auditors with a reasonable level of confidence that all the company’s accounts, transactions, and operations are as valid as those in the sample. In many cases, an auditor reviews transactions at only two or three key points in the process. Such a review indicates whether related transactions have been processed similarly.

 

Internal Auditing

Typically, internal audits focus on an insurer’s (1) accounting records and financial statements, (2) regulatory compliance, (3) external auditor findings, (4) tax reporting, and (5) operating efficiency with respect to company policies and procedures. An insurer may organize its internal auditing function by regional office, distribution system, or line of business.

To conduct a thorough internal audit, internal auditors may need to consult with a specialist in certain technical areas. For example, an internal auditor who has a question about how the insurer determines contractual benefit payments for specific life insurance products may need to consult an actuary.

Most companies view internal audits as a preventive measure, to uncover potential problems, or to discover ideas for improving a particular process. To remain objective, a company’s internal auditors should have unrestricted access to all records, procedures, files, and reports that concern the scope of the audit. In addition, they should not directly supervise or report to the areas they audit. Internal auditors usually report to a senior-level executive or to the audit committee of the insurer’s board of directors.

Figure 16.6 is a flowchart of general activities typically involved in an internal audit.

 

External Auditing

The purposes of an external audit are to (1) issue an opinion as to whether a company’s financial statements are presented fairly, in all material respects, and in accordance with a given set of accounting standards; (2) review the company’s system of internal control; and (3) prepare reports of audit findings. An external audit is conducted primarily for the benefit of interested third parties, including an insurer’s stockholders, policyowners, reinsurers, creditors, and regulators. An independent public accountant who audits a company’s Annual Report—a topic we discussed in Chapter 4—is performing an external audit.

The use of independent auditors helps ensure that a company’s financial performance is evaluated objectively. Typically, an insurer’s external audit focuses on accounting and financial reporting functions, including the insurer’s solvency, regulatory compliance, and tax reporting. Recall from Chapter 1 that all U.S. insurance companies undergo periodic financial condition examinations, which are a specific type of external audit.

Figure 16.7 presents a flowchart of the typical external audit process.

 

Auditor’s Opinions

External auditors also prepare and sign the auditor’s opinion or report, which is included in a company’s Annual Report. An auditor’s opinion is a statement prepared by a public accounting company that indicates (1) whether the information contained in an insurer’s Annual Report fairly represents the insurer’s financial position, the results of its operations, and its cash flows, and (2) whether the audit was conducted in accordance with applicable auditing standards. An auditor’s opinion does not, however, guarantee the accuracy of the financial statements.

Depending on the results of the audit, auditors issue one of several different types of auditor’s opinions, which are summarized below.

INSIGHT

Types of Auditor’s Opinions

Unqualified opinions

  • Unqualified opinion (also known as an unmodified opinion or a clean opinion): Indicates that the financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position, results of operations, and cash flows of the entity in conformity with GAAP or, for “special purpose” financial statements, in accordance with SAP. Insurance companies prefer to receive this type of auditor’s opinion.
  • Unqualified opinion with explanatory language (also known as an unmodified opinion with explanatory language): Contains explanatory language concerning specific circumstances, such as material inconsistencies resulting from a change in accounting principles.

Modified opinions

  • Qualified opinion: States the area of exception to an otherwise unqualified opinion. For example, an auditor expresses a qualified opinion when she has obtained sufficient appropriate evidence and concludes that the financial statements contain misstatements that are material but not pervasive.
  • Adverse opinion: States that the financial statements do not fairly present the insurer’s financial condition. An auditor expresses an adverse opinion when he/she has obtained sufficient appropriate evidence and concludes that the financial statements contain misstatements that are both material and pervasive.
  • Disclaimer of opinion: Indicates that the auditor has no opinion on the financial statements. For example, an auditor disclaims an opinion when he is unable to obtain sufficient appropriate evidence on which to base the opinion. In the insurance industry, this type of opinion is extremely rare.
 

Other Types of Audits

We have discussed financial audits throughout this chapter. Other important types of audits are compliance audits and performance audits. All three types of audits can be conducted on either an internal or external basis. Let’s take a brief look at compliance audits and performance audits.

A compliance audit verifies that an insurer’s financial statements adhere to the laws, regulations, policies, and procedures prescribed by internal or external regulatory authorities. Compliance auditing also focuses on the market conduct of an insurer’s agents. External auditors in the United States use specified guidelines in conducting compliance audits.

A performance audit measures and evaluates progress toward achieving management objectives for a particular function or goal. A performance audit typically contains an explanation of the processes uncovered in the audit and a report of the auditor’s findings and recommendations for improvement. Performance audits require more subjective judgment than financial audits or compliance audits because the purpose of a performance audit is to measure departmental efficiency or effectiveness, rather than adherence to an established set of accounting principles. Two types of performance audits are common:

  • A management audit focuses on improving the effectiveness and efficiency of an insurer’s operations.

  • A program results audit determines whether the desired results or benefits are actually being achieved under a specified program.

Figure 16.8 summarizes the different types of audits.

Regulations on Internal Control and Auditing

In the United States, two important regulations that govern an insurer’s internal control and auditing activities are

  • The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, or SOX, which applies only to life insurers that are public companies, or stock insurers

  • The NAIC’s Annual Financial Reporting Model Regulation, also known as the Model Audit Rule, which applies only to large U.S. life insurers

 

Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002

Recall from Chapter 1 that SOX is a U.S. federal law that requires public companies to take specific precautions to prevent fraudulent behavior on the part of management and the company’s external auditors. The Act focuses specifically on internal control and reporting and more stringent requirements for external auditor independence. According to SOX, each stock insurer in the United States must

  • Contract with independent external auditors—typically a public accounting firm—to perform an annual audit of the financial information included in the insurer’s Annual Report.

  • Ensure that its chief executive officer (CEO) and chief financial officer (CFO) certify the accuracy of its financial statements. Notice the difference here between what external auditors do and what SOX requires of CEOs and CFOs: whereas external auditors do not express an opinion as to the accuracy of an insurer’s financial statements, a stock insurer’s CEO and CFO are required to attest to the accuracy of the insurer’s financial statements.

  • Have a “financial expert” on the audit committee of the board of directors and disclose information about this expert in the Annual Report.

  • Select an internal control framework and assess and report on the design and operating effectiveness of the insurer’s internal controls annually. In this context, the term framework refers to a system of principles and components designed to aid an organization in achieving certain objectives. In the United States, the most popular internal control framework was developed by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission, known as COSO. The insight below discusses COSO frameworks.

INSIGHT

COSO Frameworks

COSO is a private-sector initiative dedicated to improving organizational performance and governance through effective internal control, enterprise risk management, and fraud deterrence. COSO’s two frameworks are

  • COSO’s Internal Control—Integrated Framework, commonly known as the COSO framework, which, as noted, is the most widely used internal control framework in the United States. Numerous other countries and businesses around the world also use this framework. Under the COSO framework, an organization’s internal control should provide reasonable assurance regarding (1) the effectiveness and efficiency of operations, (2) the reliability of financial reporting, and (3) compliance with applicable laws and regulations.
  • COSO’s Enterprise Risk Management—Integrating with Strategy and Performance, commonly known as the COSO ERM framework, which was updated in 2017. Enterprise risk management (ERM) is a system that identifies and quantifies risks both from potential threats and potential opportunities and manages these risks in a coordinated approach that supports the organization's strategic objectives. The purpose of the updated framework was to integrate ERM into all aspects of an organization’s operations.

Although some overlap exists between the two COSO frameworks, they are designed to complement one another.

Both frameworks consist of a set of principles organized into five components. For the framework to be effective, a company must adhere to the principles provided under each of the five components. The COSO framework presents 17 principles divided among five interrelated components: the control environment, risk assessment, control activities, information and communication, and monitoring activities.

Annual Financial Reporting Model Regulation

The purpose of the NAIC’s Annual Financial Reporting Model Regulation is to improve the ability of state regulators to oversee the financial condition of insurance companies. The Model Regulation, which has been adopted by virtually all the states, has three requirements:

  • An annual audit of an insurer’s financial statements by an independent certified public accountant (CPA), who serves as the external auditor in this situation

  • The filing of a report called Communication of Internal Control Related to Matters Noted in the Audit

  • The filing of a report called Management’s Report of Internal Control over Financial Reporting

The audit and both reports must be filed with the appropriate state insurance commissioner.

 

Annual Audit

The annual audit is due by June 1 following the preceding December 31 year end. For example, the filing of the audit for the year ending December 31, 2018, must be done by June 1, 2019. This audit must be conducted in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards, or GAAS.

 

Communication of Internal Control Related to Matters Noted in the Audit

The CPA who conducted the annual audit prepares this report within 60 days after the filing of the audit. In the report, the CPA describes any unremediated—that is, “uncorrected”—material weaknesses noted during the course of the audit. According to GAAS, a material weakness is defined as “a deficiency, or a combination of deficiencies, in internal control such that there is a reasonable possibility that a material misstatement of the entity’s financial statements will not be prevented, or detected and corrected on a timely basis.” 1

If the CPA’s report does not describe the specific actions taken by the insurer to correct an unremediated material weakness, then the insurer is required to provide this description to the state insurance commissioner. If the CPA found no unremediated material weaknesses, she should disclose this fact in her report.

 

Management’s Report of Internal Control over Financial Reporting

This report describes an insurer’s internal control as of December 31 of the immediately preceding year. Important content in this report includes management’s

  • Statement that it is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting

  • Assertion that its internal control over financial reporting is effective in providing reasonable assurance as to the reliability of the company’s financial statements in accordance with statutory accounting principles

  • Description of the approach or processes by which it evaluates the effectiveness of its internal control over financial reporting

SOX requires publicly traded insurers to prepare a comparable report. Therefore, stock insurers are permitted to use this report to satisfy this requirement of the Model Regulation.

figure16-1.title: Types of Controls
alt:
Administrative controls guide employees in day-to-day tasks; accounting controls authorize financial transactions, safeguard assets, and ensure reliable financial reporting.

Preventive controls are implemented before a transaction to prevent errors or problems from occurring; detective controls are undertaken after a transaction to detect an error or problem after it occurs.

figure16-2.title: Preventive vs. Detective Controls: Balancing Effectiveness and Cost
alt:
Insurers face a balancing act with preventive controls and detective controls:

Preventive controls are usually more effective, but detective controls are usually less expensive.

figure16-3.title: Balancing Segregation of Duties and Employee Empowerment
alt:
Insurers have to balance segregation of duties with employee empowerment:

Strict segregation of duties minimizes opportunities for error, dishonesty, and crime; but employee empowerment can improve efficiency and employee satisfaction. On the other hand, employee empowerment requires more frequent internal audits.

figure16-4.title: Balancing Act: Safeguarding Assets While Providing Access
alt: Insurers must balance the need to keep assets secure from theft, damage, or loss with the need for employees to access the assets to do their jobs.

figure16-5.title: Principles of an Effective Internal Control System
alt:
Segregation of duties means that jobs are designed so that incompatible functions are assigned to different individuals.

Execution of transactions as authorized means that individuals are authorized to perform transactions of appropriate magnitude and importance.

Recording of transactions as executed means that transactions are recorded in the correct accounting period, in the correct accounts, and in the correct amounts.

Safeguarding of assets means that the company is protected against loss of items of value.

Physical comparison of recorded amounts means that actual assets owned are compared to recorded amounts.

figure16-8.title: Types of Audits
alt:
An internal audit is performed by company employees for the company’s benefit and improvement.

An external audit is performed by external auditors, primarily for external stakeholders.

A financial audit examines company accounting records, policies, and procedures.

A compliance audit verifies adherence to financial and/or marketing laws and regulations.

A performance audit evaluates progress towards company objectives.

video16-1.title: Questions to Be Answered in an Audit
alt: 1. The company’s assets. Are they properly accounted for? Are they safeguarded from loss?
[A person counts a number of piles of cash and stock or bond certificates and then puts them in a safe and closes the safe.]
2. The company’s policies and procedures. Do employees follow them properly?
[A person has a list of duties and puts a check mark next to one of them.]
3. The company’s accounting records and financial reports. Are they reliable?
[A person looks at and checks a pile of papers, then gives a thumbs up.]
4. The company’s internal controls. Are they sound? Are they applied correctly?
[Two puzzle pieces connect.]
In the meantime, auditors answer these other questions.
Has anyone at the company made unintentional errors or provided false financial information?
Has any person committed fraud?
Have any people colluded to provide false information?
